column1: $2.3 million NIH grant will support efforts to stop mosquito-borne diseases
column2: National Institutes of Health award to UCR’s Naoki Yamanaka recognizes highly innovative research

column1: Boyle Heights: Cemented in history
column2: Capturing the essence of a place requires more than time. It requires confianza. Trust.    That’s why for more than a year a team co-led by a UC Riverside cultural and urban historian interviewed, researched, and documented the lives of Boyle Heights residents — all in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic. For centuries, Boyle Heights, a community three miles east of downtown Los Angeles, has been home to generations of immigrants and social justice movements.

column1: Natural gas engine can reduce smog from heavy-duty trucks
column2: Simulated on-road testing shows the engine maintains near-zero emissions during all duty cycles

column1: Unwritten history: Seattle, a city built by immigrants and Indigenous people
column2: ‘Seattle from the Margins,’ a new book by assistant professor Megan Asaka points to the overseen contributions of the Duwamish, Japanese, Filipino, Chinese, and other immigrant communities.

column1: Gift to School of Medicine aims to alleviate inland Southern California’s physician shortage
column2: Inland Empire Health Plan’s gift of $2.6M will create up to 23 awards designed to encourage students to practice in the region

column1: Researcher honored for work in English language learner education
column2: The James Irvine Foundation recognized Linda Navarrette as one of six change-makers in California.

column1: Governor’s budget proposal allocates $25 million for UCR School of Medicine
column2: Additional ongoing funding would help the medical school expand enrollment

column1: Ghost Light, Marvel’s new cosmic hero, is Black
column2: The once human character is now a superhero, envisioned by UCR professor John Jennings.

column1: Want to know L.A.'s Latinx story? Follow the music posters
column2: Beginning around 1990, the demographic landscape of the Los Angeles area changed dramatically through an infusion of immigrants from Mexico and Central America. But historian Jorge Leal says its impact on the neighborhoods of the Los Angeles area has never been charted in earnest. With his recently published research, Leal has taken a furtive step into documenting the Latinx community’s emerging L.A. footprint, using an unconventional source. If you want to know about the Latinx community’s presence in L.A. over the past 30 years, Leal says to follow the music posters.

column1: Project Moving Forward: A benchmark for student success
column2: RIVERSIDE, Calif. - As a young teacher, Linda Navarrette traveled to South Africa with one assignment: help teachers develop critical thinking skills in their students. Little did she know that her efforts in those impoverished communities would change her life. The experience catapulted her career into education, cementing her support for students who are learning English as a second language.

column1: Mrs. Panda conquers online
column2: The innovative Rule of 3 English-learning program completes its shift to an online portal.

column1: Campus community gets first look at OASIS
column2: On a campus already actively growing its footprint in Inland Southern California, a proposed clean technology park would lead to a reinvention of UC Riverside’s relationship with the city and region. The park is Phase I of a more ambitious research and economic development project.

column1: State OKs $25M to double UCR medical students
column2: Budget allocates ongoing funding to the medical school

column1: Four professors receive $270K in grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities
column2: The awards will allow for book projects and innovative curriculum development.

column1: UC Riverside crests 76% for six-year graduation rate
column2: In the past six years, UC Riverside's six-year graduation rate has improved by 10 percentage points

column1: Free dataset archive helps researchers quickly find a needle in a haystack
column2: UCR STAR visualizes public spatio-temporal datasets through an interactive map

column1: Clearing the air (inside your car)
column2: UC Riverside research can improve car cabin air quality and help you choose your next car

column1: Cleaning your car may not protect you from this carcinogen
column2: It is unlikely that a cancer-causing chemical inside your car can be dusted or wiped way, according to new UC Riverside research.

column1: What Makes Kids With Autism Less Social Than Their Typically Developing Peers?
column2: Pick a hand, any hand. That familiar refrain, repeated in schoolyards the world over, is the basis of a simple guessing game that was recently adapted to study how and why kids with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) interact with the people around them.

column1: Does the presence of colleges and hospitals increase home prices?
column2: The institution’s size and the ZIP code’s population can have positive and negative effects

column1: Epidemiologist answers questions on COVID-19 ranging from grocery store visits to wearing masks and gloves
column2: Brandon Brown is an associate professor in the Center for Healthy Communities in the School of Medicine

column1: Faculty member pens book to help researchers work ‘Online, Offline, and In Between’
column2: Work includes field notes and observations of in-person and virtual research.

column1: UC Riverside Fall 2018 admissions show surge in transfer student numbers
column2: In two years, UCR transfer applications have climbed by 23 percent.

column1: NEH grant helps research Pueblo, Colorado’s music history
column2: Xóchitl C. Chávez, assistant professor of music at UCR, is a co-principal investigator.

column1: Wildfire dataset could help firefighters save lives and property
column2: WildfireDB contains over 17 million data points that capture how fires have spread in the contiguous United States over the last decade

column1: Who’s responsible for roadside rubbish?
column2: New UC Riverside research reveals that items in litter typically originate less than two miles from where they’re found — and unless humans remove them, most of these items will never leave the environment.

column1: To curb sexual assault, help people better understand consent
column2: Research suggests more effort is needed to help college men apply the concept of sexual consent to their everyday lives

column1: Graduate student received Ford Foundation fellowship
column2: Donovan Argueta, a first-generation college graduate at the University of California, Riverside, has won a Ford Foundation 2018 Dissertation Fellowship. The $25,000 fellowship begins June 1, 2018. As a fellow, Argueta will receive additional support to attend an annual conference of the Ford Foundation fellows this fall.

column1: Older adults: Daunted by learning a new task? Learn three
column2: Learning several new things at once increases cognitive abilities in older adults, according to new research from UC Riverside. UCR psychologist Rachel Wu says one important way of staving off cognitive decline is learning new skills as a child would. That is, be a sponge: seek new skills to learn; maintain motivation as fuel; rely on encouraging mentors to guide you; thrive in an environment where the bar is set high.

column1: NOVA Wonders episode to feature UCR expert on dark matter
column2: RIVERSIDE, Calif.

column1: Research identifies possible on/off switch for plant growth
column2: New research from UC Riverside identifies a protein that controls plant growth —  good news for an era in which crops can get crushed by climate change.

column1: Why multifamily housing is expensive to build in Los Angeles
column2: Report calls for policymakers to enact zoning and other reforms

column1: Climate change predicted to bring more extremes to inland southern california
column2: Regional report authored by UCR researchers is included in California’s Fourth Climate Change Assessment

column1: Villa-Lobos: An evening of cello and piano in Riverside
column2: The festival was born from a partnership between Paulo C. Chagas, professor with the University of California, Riverside’ Department of Music, and internationally renowned cellist Lars Hoefs.

column1: Study finds natural fires help native bees, improve food security
column2: Native bees that boost food crops are in decline but changing fire management policies could help them. Most flowering plant farms employ honeybees, a non-native species originally imported from Europe and managed by beekeepers. However, research shows that farms surrounded by natural bee habitat have higher crop yields.

column1: Climate-induced soil changes may cause more erosion and flash flooding
column2: More intensive water cycle could have impact on biodiversity, human health, and water and food security

column1: Music lecturer recognized by the National Endowment for the Arts
column2: For the past 20 years Tagumpay Mendoza De Leon has been teaching Filipino rondalla music at UCR.

column1: Climate change: a dirt-y business
column2: Groundwater is essential for growing crops, but new research shows climate change is making it harder for soil to absorb rainfall.  While the idea that soil particles rearrange themselves in response to environmental conditions is not new, scientists once thought these shifts in the ground happened slowly. Not anymore.

column1: California’s worst wildfires are helping improve air quality prediction
column2: New method measures and predicts air quality in areas with insufficient monitoring

column1: Testing chemicals for birth defects using stem cells, not mice
column2: UC Riverside researchers are helping the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency eliminate animal testing

column1: Agricultural area residents in danger of inhaling toxic aerosols
column2: Excess selenium from fertilizers and other natural sources can create air pollution that could lead to lung cancer, asthma, and Type 2 diabetes, according to new UC Riverside research.

column1: New commuter concern: cancerous chemical in car seats
column2: A new UC Riverside study concludes the longer your commute, the more you're exposed to a chemical flame retardant that is a known carcinogen, phased out of furniture use because it required a Proposition 65 warning label in California.

column1: Climate change will decimate Palm Springs, Coachella Valley tourism
column2: A new UC Riverside study finds that climate change will have a devastating effect on the greater Palm Springs area’s dominant industry — tourism. Thousands known as “snowbirds” flock to the region annually from elsewhere in the country to escape freezing winters. However, due to climate change, the number of days above 85 degrees between November and April is projected to increase by up to 150% by the end of the century.

column1: Fundraising head at HBCU Morehouse to lead Advancement
column2: UC Riverside has named Monique Michelle Dozier as its vice chancellor for University Advancement. Dozier is currently vice president for Advancement and chief advancement officer at Morehouse College in Atlanta, which is the nation’s only historically Black liberal arts college dedicated to educating and developing men of color, specifically Black men. She will begin her new role at UCR on Aug. 1 overseeing University Advancement, which includes Development, Alumni Engagement, Advancement Finance and Administration, and University Communications.

column1: Shrub encroachment on grasslands can increase groundwater recharge
column2: Vegetation changes can outweigh climate change in rangeland water budgets

column1: Wildfires can cause dangerous debris flows
column2: Wildfires don’t stop being dangerous after the flames go out. Even one modest rainfall after a fire can cause a deadly landslide, according to new UC Riverside research.

column1: Researchers move toward understanding deadly citrus disease
column2: UCR study will aid the development of new strategies to combat huanglongbing

column1: Nobel Laureate Barry Barish joins UC Riverside faculty
column2: Physicist, whose contributions enabled the first observation of gravitational waves, is the university’s second Nobel Prize winner

column1: Graduate students create mental health support network
column2: R’Grad Peer Support Group meets weekly and is designed to be a nonclinical outlet.

column1: UCR faculty weigh in on 'American Dirt'
column2: "American Dirt" is the No. 1 New York Times bestseller, has been called this generation’s "Grapes of Wrath" and received strong reviews from Publishers Weekly and Kirkus. It has received support from prominent Mexican American and Latina authors, including Sandra Cisneros, Erika Sánchez, Reyna Grande, and Julia Alvarez, who predicted the book would “change hearts and transform policies.” Stephen King loves it. So does John Grisham. Oprah Winfrey has anointed it in her Oprah's Book Club.

column1: Why the Salton Sea is turning into toxic dust
column2: The Salton Sea, California’s most polluted inland lake, has lost a third of its water in the last 25 years. New research has determined a decline in Colorado River flow is the reason for that shrinking.

column1: Grains in the rain
column2: Of the major food crops, only rice is currently able to survive flooding. Thanks to new research, that could soon change -- good news for a world in which rains are increasing in both frequency and intensity.

column1: Color tiers will end; UCR revisits fall plans
column2: Gov. Gavin Newsom’s announcement  about a full California reopening on June 15 didn’t scramble UC Riverside’s plans for fall 2021, but it threw in some hot sauce. “It made us more progressive in our planning,” UCR Chancellor Kim A. Wilcox said. “If COVID-19 vaccinations continue to trend as they are, and if there isn’t a COVID-19 outbreak, campus will look more like ‘normal’ than we thought it would even a short time ago.”

column1: Post-lockdown auto emissions can’t hide in the grass
column2: University of California scientists have a new way to demonstrate which neighborhoods are most affected by air pollution from vehicle emissions. Their technique could help ensure people most affected by pollution will benefit from efforts to reduce it.

column1: Biocompatible glue for corneal repair is a sight for sore eyes
column2: The adhesive would replace stitches and conventional adhesive to speed healing and reduce complications and cost

column1: First comprehensive fundraising campaign nears its end
column2: UC Riverside is closing in on the end of its first-ever comprehensive fundraising campaign. The total raised through August 23 was $298,116,805.

column1: UCR poll: 'If it's Trump vs. Newsom, Newsom wins'
column2: A poll of UC Riverside social sciences professors holds that Gov. Gavin Newsom should prevail in the current recall effort against him. Two committees, RescueCalifornia.org and RecallGavin2020.com, have launched efforts to gain 1.5 million signatures to put a Newsom recall on the ballot. The deadline for submitting signatures is March 17, with signatures verified by April 29. Proponents predict more than two million signatures, and Newsom supporters concede recall proponents probably have enough.

column1: New School of Medicine Education Building receives full approval from UC Regents
column2: The Regents of the University of California have given final approval for the construction of the School of Medicine’s new Education Building II at UC Riverside. The vote, which approved the final design, the full budget, and the California Environmental Quality Act, or CEQA, findings, took place during the Regents’ meeting on Wednesday, March 17, 2021.

column1: UCR admits most California freshmen among UCs
column2: UC Riverside has admitted a record number of freshmen for fall 2021 with a total of 34,671 admits — an increase of 1,964 students from the year before, according to data released by the University of California on July 19.

column1: UCR joins Big Brothers Big Sisters in new virtual mentoring program
column2: Born from the pandemic, College Bigs, will count on nearly 150 UCR students to work with local high school mentees.

column1: The day the ‘60s protest movement came to UCR
column2: Fifty years ago, Gov. Ronald Reagan visited UCR, and the campus’s largest-ever student protest erupted

column1: $1.6 million grant helps high school students get to college
column2: The federal grant supports UCR’s work in San Bernardino area schools.

column1: The newest California water-worry is the megastorm
column2: Research from UCLA and other sources recently predicted another “big one” to hit the West Coast. This time, it’s not an earthquake, but a “megastorm.” Such a flood typically hits California every 100 to 200 years, but the dynamics and frequency of this storm will be exacerbated by climate change. That is, warmer temperatures mean much of the precipitation will fall as rain, and not snow.

column1: UC Riverside partners with City of Riverside on Eastside revitalization project
column2: CE-CERT will track greenhouse gas reductions, indicators of public health, and economic impacts from the $31 million dollar project

column1: Deadline to provide vaccination proof is Aug. 16
column2: Aug. 16 is the deadline for UC Riverside employees and students to upload vaccination records for fall 2021. The announcement was made in a July 16 message from Chancellor Kim A. Wilcox to the campus community.

column1: New program aims to increase Latinx students conducting environmental research
column2: A $342,000 grant has allowed the expansion of a UC Berkeley program to UCR.

column1: School of Medicine signs agreement with AIDS Healthcare Foundation
column2: Partnership provides opportunities for UCR medical students to train at a Riverside clinic focused on AIDS treatment

column1: UCR School of Medicine and Eisenhower Health establish training affiliation
column2: Partnership addresses long-term healthcare needs of Coachella Valley

column1: Living the Promise campaign hits $300 million goal
column2: UC Riverside surpassed its $300 million goal on Sept. 10 for its first comprehensive fundraising campaign, “Living the Promise: The Campaign for UC Riverside.” Although the overall dollar goal has been reached, the campaign isn’t yet over. The effort, which was publicly launched on October 15, 2016, will close on Dec. 31, 2020, and university fundraisers hope to encourage greater participation from UCR alumni and friends, particularly in support of students.

column1: UC Riverside celebrates campaign completion Feb. 18-20
column2: More than 66,000 donors made gifts during the Living the Promise campaign, and the total amount raised will be announced at a live virtual event on Feb 20.

column1: Buckley was invited; the pig who peed wasn't
column2: Considered by itself, William F. Buckley Jr. having offered the commencement address to the UC Riverside Class of 1970 might lead one to infer this was a time of greater kumbaya among conservatives and liberals. One would be dissuaded by a retelling of the day’s events, including the on-stage introduction of a pig—the pig not being Buckley.

column1: $1 million grant advances study of California’s missions
column2: Funding will connect UC scholars across campuses to launch an entirely new field: Critical Mission Studies

column1: Would you get bored of eternal life?
column2: John Martin Fischer’s videotaped lectures on near-death experiences and immortality have garnered the most views of any content on UCR’s YouTube site.

column1: Veterans history project receives VA funding through 2020
column2: Federal funding will enable thousands more Inland Empire K-12 students to join in documenting the histories of those interred at Riverside National Cemetery

column1: Meet the women who battled tuberculosis in Indian country
column2: In his latest book, a scholar of Native American history explores a little-known collaboration that made big impacts

column1: Professor shares tips for surviving ‘Pandemic University’
column2: Juliette Levy has taught online for almost a decade; here’s what she wants professors and students to keep in mind as they navigate the transition to online learning

column1: Leader effectiveness may depend on emotional expression
column2: When they don’t express negative emotions, women are seen as more effective leaders than men

column1: Graphic Novelist John Jennings reflects on relevance of X-Men story ‘God Loves, Man Kills’ in an essay for Marvel
column2: In an essay for Marvel, John Jennings, a professor of media and cultural studies, reflects on the 1982 graphic novel “X-Men: God Loves, Man Kills” by Chris Claremont and Brent Anderson, which is being re-released this year in a two-part extended cut.

column1: Back in Camp: Men's Tennis Aims to Keep Making History
column2: With the 2018-2019 season just one day away, the UC Riverside Men's Tennis Team is poised to continue its tradition of building and growing year by year. Since Head Coach Mattias Johansson's arrival before the 2015-16 season, a year in which he led the team to a DI record 13 wins, the Highlanders have consistently surpassed their previous accomplishments every year. In 2017 the team earned 14 wins and just last year set the current record of 16. This year Johansson and the squad have their sights set on not only reaching internal milestones, but making some noise in the Big West.

column1: Physicist to use optical trapping methods to study basic properties of solid-state materials
column2: NSF-funded research represents a new approach to the field of 'crystal engineering'

column1: Should we be double masking?
column2: UC Riverside epidemiologist answers this and other questions in Q&A

column1: Campbell family gives $10 million to UC Riverside
column2: The gift from the mother-daughter philanthropists is tied for the largest ever to the university from individual donors

column1: Why don’t veterans share their stories?
column2: What ma

column1: UCR responds to broadening COVID-19 impacts
column2: As COVID-19 coronavirus impacts broaden across the world, UC Riverside is pointing its campus community to a frequently updated website for the latest related news. The site, https://ehs.ucr.edu/coronavirus, includes updates and frequently asked questions.

column1: The chemical controlling life and death in hair follicles
column2: A single chemical is key to controlling when hair follicle cells divide, and when they die. This discovery could not only treat baldness, but ultimately speed wound healing because follicles are a source of stem cells.

column1: New dean of School of Education named
column2: Joi Spencer has been named the dean of UC Riverside’s School of Education, effective Jan. 1, 2023.  Spencer is a professor of Mathematics Education at the University of San Diego, in the School of Leadership and Education Sciences, or SOLES. During 16 years at USD, Spencer has been associate dean and, most recently, interim dean of SOLES.

column1: When restricting capital movement, don’t go it alone
column2: When it comes to avoiding reputational costs of economic policy controls, there is safety in numbers. That’s the finding of a recent study of capital controls, or government restrictions on the cross-border movement of money and capital. The researchers assert it’s one of the most systematic studies yet of the reputational risks associated with capital controls among emerging markets.

column1: Is there still a benefit to masking?
column2: UC Riverside epidemiologist weighs in on how protective your mask is when nobody around you is masked

column1: The world is much more alike than different
column2: The cornerstone of discrimination is the belief that other people, including people of other races from other countries, are different. They experience life differently; they react differently.  What if research could demonstrate that’s not true? A new study from UC Riverside asserts the world population may have much more in common than it has differences.

column1: UC Riverside and Eurosemillas partner to bring the next generation of avocados to market
column2: Eurosemillas will test some of UCR’s avocado scion and advanced rootstock selections on other continents

column1: Scientists profile FDA-approved drugs to potentially treat hundreds of genetic disorders
column2: New method developed by UC Riverside researchers quickly assesses drug potential for rare disorders

column1: It's back to the classroom on Jan. 31
column2: UC Riverside resumes in-person instruction on Jan. 31.

column1: $6.3 million will help UC Riverside save America’s avocado orchards
column2: New grants totaling $6.3 million will help UC Riverside solve problems facing American avocado orchards, including a lethal fungal disease called Laurel Wilt. The disease can destroy an entire avocado orchard in a couple of weeks once symptoms develop. It is already present in Florida. Without effective treatments, it will inevitably spread to California, the nation’s leading producer of avocados.

column1: How might the coronavirus change the world around us?
column2: Sociologist Richard M. Carpiano weighs in on some of the less obvious ways COVID-19 could restructure life as we know it

column1: A different type of holiday party for Guardian Scholars
column2: The program works to make the holidays special for foster youth, despite the pandemic’s challenges.

column1: $1 million grant reaffirms UCR’s commitment to the humanities
column2: The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation’s gift leverages campaign support to fund 26 faculty fellowships at the Center for Ideas and Society

column1: Connecting the world through images and sound
column2: UCR professor’s research weaves together a visual and auditory presentation of Riverside, Brazil, India, Russia, and Germany.

column1: ‘There are scholars working here’
column2: The Center for Ideas and Society celebrates 30 years of bridging interdisciplinary gaps with Oct. 29 anniversary event

column1: Alzheimer's gene may impact cognition before adulthood
column2: A gene linked to Alzheimer’s disease may impact cognitive health much sooner than previously realized. The APOE gene creates a protein, apolipoprotein E, which packages cholesterol and other fats to transport them through the bloodstream. There are three versions, or alleles, of APOE. One of those is the APOE4 allele, present in about 15% of the population. APOE4 carriers are up to three times more likely to develop late-onset Alzheimer’s disease, which occurs in people 65 and older.

column1: Center for Ideas and Society has new co-directors
column2: Meet professors Dylan Rodríguez and Jeanette Kohl.

column1: Nobel Prize winner to join UC Riverside faculty
column2: UCR alumnus and renowned scholar Richard Schrock will share pioneering science with faculty and students

column1: Chemist receives Department of Energy award
column2: Early Career Research Program award will support Ming Lee Tang’s research on developing hybrid organic-inorganic materials

column1: Product authentication at your fingertips
column2: UC Riverside-led research brings rapid and reversible switching of plasmonic color to solids

column1: Nanomaterial gives robots chameleon skin
column2: A new film made of gold nanoparticles changes color in response to any type of movement. Its unprecedented qualities could allow robots to mimic chameleons and octopi — among other futuristic applications.

column1: Scientists discover potential cause of Alzheimer’s Disease
column2: Prevailing theories posit plaques in the brain cause Alzheimer’s disease. New UC Riverside research points to cells’ slowing ability to clean themselves as the likely cause of unhealthy brain buildup.

column1: Light-powered soft robots could suck up oil spills
column2: A floating, robotic film designed at UC Riverside could be trained to hoover oil spills at sea or remove contaminants from drinking water.

column1: Mystery of four-stranded DNA begins to unravel
column2: DNA is usually depicted as double-stranded, but not much is known about parts of the genome that adopt four-stranded structures known as quadruplexes. UC Riverside researchers have discovered that they play a key role in keeping cells healthy.

column1: No Thanksgiving for bacteria or fungus
column2: UC Riverside scientists have developed a technique for solving a decades-old mystery involving the chemical in turkey that makes people sleepy. Their new ability to map the atoms involved in the production of tryptophan opens the door to new antibiotic and antifungal drugs.

column1: Injections for diabetes, cancer could become unnecessary
column2: Researchers at UC Riverside are paving the way for diabetes and cancer patients to forget needles and injections, and instead take pills to manage their conditions.

column1: Genetic background may affect adaptions to aging
column2: UC Riverside-led study evaluated individual differences in DNA methylation across 10 years in two Scandinavian samples of same‐sex aging twins

column1: Beyond Brilliant: Cam Calkins: The secret ingredient is love
column2: UCR Dining Services employee donates $52,000 to the Graduate School of Education, and an additional $10,000 to the R'Pantry.

column1: Asian American shootings: This is ‘not an exception’ and other issues that need to be discussed
column2: Farm working, mental health, and social and cultural barriers that some Asian American communities face.

column1: Genetically engineered virus spins gold into beads
column2: The discovery could make production of some electronic components cheaper, easier, and faster

column1: Small magnets reveal big secrets
column2: Work by international research team could have wide-ranging impact on information technology applications

column1: Faster, Cheaper Wastewater Treatment Through Improved Oxidation Reactions
column2: UCR researchers have developed a simple way to improve Advanced Oxidation Processes

column1: A shot in the arm
column2: UC Riverside experts answer questions on Americans needing just one COVID-19 booster vaccine each year

column1: Addressing the anxiety crisis
column2: UC Riverside mental health professionals answer questions specific to adults, children, and students

column1: Booster mandate explained; students vaccines available
column2: Emails to students and employees this week stressed the need to comply with booster mandates. This effectively refreshes the mandate requirements students and employees were asked to comply with this past fall, based on UC requirements. That mandate was met with more than a 95% vaccination rate among UCR’s students and employees.

column1: UC Riverside study busts myths about gossip
column2: A first-of-its-kind UC Riverside study asserts that women don’t gossip negatively more often than men, lower income people don’t gossip more than more wealthy people, and younger people are more likely to gossip negatively than their older counterparts.

column1: Cancer Patients’ Conversation Topics Reflect Well-Being, Study Finds
column2: Substantive dialogue may help, but emotional exchanges likely don't. Research finds that substantive conversation – conversation about news and ideas – is reflective of greater well-being among breast cancer patients.

column1: 'A Happy Homecoming' for Michael Drake
column2: In a crisp blue suit, new UC President Michael Drake addressed the challenges facing the UC system in terms of the pandemic and budget shortfalls, and announced the advent of his personal “looking and listening tour.”

column1: Trust the power of markets
column2: People trust decisions made by groups, but information markets are more accurate

column1: Detection of very high frequency magnetic resonance could revolutionize electronics
column2: UC Riverside-led research has applications in ultrafast and spin-based nanoscale devices

column1: To impress females, Costa’s hummingbirds “sing” with their tail feathers
column2: UCR Researchers show how male Costa’s control the acoustics of a tail song produced during high speed dives

column1: Switching magnetic polarity at record speed
column2: Researchers develop way to use magnetic materials for data storage that is 50 times faster than previous attempts

column1: Simple experiment explains magnetic resonance
column2: UC Riverside physics students design a table-top experiment for the classroom

column1: Gun control legislation is popular; why won't it pass?
column2: The routine has been too familiar for too many years. A school shooting or mass shooting event occurs and stirs the American consciousness for a moment. But a week or two passes and talk of gun-control legislation fades. The issue goes into hibernation until the next mass shooting event. In 2018, an opinion article by UCR political science Professor Ben Bishin was published in The Washington Post. It was Bishin's attempt to explain why the cycle keeps repeating itself, and who's to blame.

column1: Reducing aerosol pollution without cutting carbon dioxide could make the planet hotter
column2: Humans must reduce carbon dioxide and aerosol pollution simultaneously to avoid weakening the ocean’s ability to keep the planet cool, new UC Riverside research shows.

column1: UC Riverside surpasses ambitious vaccination goal
column2: Almost 95% of the students who have returned to campus this fall are fully vaccinated against COVID-19. UCR earlier this month passed its campus-wide goal of 90% vaccination, representing a journey that gathered significant momentum in the past few weeks.

column1: Why is 90% the magic number?
column2: With a month until fall quarter begins, the number of verified vaccinations at UCR reached about 65% for students, and just over 75% for employees. The numbers were updated Aug. 20.  In late July, the University of California system moved the goal line for what constitutes a fully vaccinated campus, from 75% to 90%.

column1: Vaccine deadline comes and goes, and reporting surges
column2: The deadline to verify one’s vaccination status or file for an exemption passed Aug. 16, with a late surge in reporting by students and employees. In only one week, there was a 13-point spike — from 51% to 64% — in students who verified having received a vaccination, according to UC Riverside numbers reported on Aug. 18. The number of employees climbed by 9%, to almost 74%.

column1: UC Riverside startup receives National Science Foundation grant
column2: Small Business Innovation Research Program provides seed funding for BEAM-CA, LLC

column1: Breast cancer study by UCR medical student could help patients live longer
column2: Surgery is associated with increased survival for patients with HER2-positive stage 4 breast cancer

column1: Study examines ‘black boxing’ in breast cancer survivorship care
column2: UC Riverside researcher argues important post-treatment information is concealed

column1: The Colorado River is imperiled; why it matters to you
column2: UC Riverside experts discuss the decline of this major water source for nearly 40 million people in seven states.

column1: Gamma-ray laser moves a step closer to reality
column2: Calculations by UC Riverside’s Allen Mills predict metastable positronium bubbles in liquid helium

column1: Voters and multiracial candidates? It's complicated
column2: There is a whole new dynamic that pundits, campaign managers, and voters will be negotiating in American politics, and the starting gun has already been fired. That is, the complicated — so says the research — dynamic of how voters regard multiracial candidates. On the national stage, it began with Barack Obama, and continues in this election cycle with Democratic nominee Joe Biden’s running mate, California U.S. Sen. Kamala Harris.

column1: Marginalized communities of color face high COVID-19 risk
column2: UC Riverside study focused on farm-working communities in California’s Eastern Coachella Valley

column1: Superbloom? If you say so
column2: Superbloom is a term concocted by the media, but this year’s wildflowers are still spectacular, especially for the creatures that depend on them

column1: David Leonhardt presents Feb. 27 Hays P-E Lecture
column2: New York Times columnist David Leonhardt will offer the Feb. 27 Hays Press-Enterprise Lecture, which will take place between 4-6 p.m. at the UC Riverside Extension Center.

column1: After four years of hard work, Match Day arrives for UC Riverside medical students
column2: 38 students in Class of 2019 were matched for a residency program of their choice

column1: School of Medicine celebrates Match Day online
column2: Nearly 70 graduates were accepted into residency programs of their choice in 2020

column1: New report highlights key findings on the health, mental health, and social service needs of Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders in California
column2: Data from the California Health Interview Survey and the American Community Survey highlight diversity and needs of California’s fastest growing population groups.

column1: When COVID-19 darkens your door
column2: The Villanueva twins graduated from UCR a month after their father, Manuel, died from COVID-19.

column1: Gun violence pressures elected officials to make reforms
column2: With three mass shooting within a week leaving 24 Californians dead, public policy makers are searching for answers.

column1: Researcher-community partnership uses collaborative process to yield novel insights
column2: Until recently, psychologist Kalina Michalska had never used community-based participatory research, or CBPR, in her work, but now she can’t imagine not using it. CBPR, which dates to the early 1930s, is an intensive research approach that involves partnerships between researchers and community members throughout the research process, giving communities a voice in how the research proceeds and allowing them to make use of the findings more effectually.

column1: Chemicals in your living room cause diabetes in mice
column2: A new UC Riverside study shows flame retardants found in nearly every American home cause mice to give birth to offspring that become diabetic.

column1: Why some people vote against their own beliefs
column2: Many low-education voters who embrace social welfare programs vote against their own beliefs, new UC Riverside research holds. The mitigating factor is education: The more education one has, the more likely one is to stick to one’s policy preferences.

column1: Political scientists make battleground state predictions
column2: UC Riverside political science professors were polled on their predictions for eight battleground states, and the results carry some optimism for the Joe Biden camp.

column1: Murder hornets invade headlines, not the U.S.
column2: Though “murder hornets” are dominating recent headlines, there are no Asian Giant Hornets currently known to be living in the U.S. or Canada, according to UC Riverside Entomology Research Museum Senior Scientist Doug Yanega.

column1: Can ethics classes actually influence students’ moral behavior?
column2: Philosophers and ethicists have never had scientific proof that university ethics classes affect student moral behavior — until now. A research team led by a philosopher at the University of California, Riverside, has conducted the first controlled study aiming to discover whether such a correlation exists using direct observational data rather than self-reported information.

column1: UCR scientist rediscovers insect lost for 105 years
column2: Little is known about elusive beetle species, despite role in wildflower pollination

column1: Gay migration happens but not always to gay-friendly places, reports new study
column2: Study also shows that straight people prefer to live in places that match their attitudes toward sexuality

column1: UCR expert: President Biden’s new same-sex marriage law ‘is a reminder that a right won is not a right secured’
column2: The Respect for Marriage Act ‘seems to be an evolution on same-sex marriage support. But I want to caution that we don’t conflate that with LGBTQ support.’

column1: UC Riverside No. 1 in U.S. News social mobility rankings
column2: For the second consecutive year, UC Riverside is the No. 1 university in the country for social mobility in the U.S. News & World Report Best Colleges rankings.  UCR rose up the charts in the overall rankings as well, now placing No. 34 among all public universities and No. 88 overall.

column1: UCR among national leaders in degrees that 'pay off'
column2: UC Riverside ranked No. 14 among universities nationally in CNBC Make It’s annual “50 Colleges that Pay Off the Most” list. Editors for CNBC Make-It, which is a business-news site, said the ranking carries greater weight due to scrutiny of higher education costs-benefits in the COVID-19 pandemic.

column1: Media's framing of disease may lead to AAPI discrimination
column2: Describing diseases as originating from animals foreign to the Western diet serves to boost stereotypes of Asian culture and increase discrimination, according to new research from UC Riverside, Texas Tech, and Texas A&M.

column1: UCR again named a top social mobility university
column2: UCR was named the No. 4 university in the country in terms of social mobility, which gauges a school's success in elevating its graduates to higher income brackets.

column1: UC Riverside reaches 77.3% for six-year graduation rate
column2: UC Riverside’s six-year graduation rate — considered a leading measure of higher education excellence — has realized a new record. According to new numbers from UCR’s Office of Institutional Research, among freshmen who entered UCR in 2014, 77.3% graduated by 2020. That breaks the previous record of 76%, set last year.

column1: Payless stunt shows how expectation guides experience
column2: Sometimes quality is in the eye of the beholder

column1: It's a three-peat: UCR again tops social mobility ranking
column2: For the third consecutive year, U.S. News & World Report has named UC Riverside the top university in the nation for social mobility. The social mobility category considers the degree to which a university elevates its low-income graduates to a higher standard of living. As rankings leaders such as U.S. News have adjusted their formulas in the past few years, they increasingly consider social mobility among the leading measures of higher education success.

column1: Money magazine ranks UCR No. 40 among 623 colleges
column2: UC Riverside was ranked No. 40 on Money magazine’s latest “Best Values” college ranking, released May 16.  It represents an increase of eight places over Money's last best value list, on which UCR ranked No. 48. Among public universities, UCR ranked No. 31 on the list, up from No. 32.

column1: Jewish Studies expert discusses rise in antisemitic attacks
column2: The Associated Press reported this week that preliminary data compiled by the Anti-Defamation League shows an increase in violent attacks, vandalism and harassment of Jews in the U.S., around the world, and online, since fighting broke out between Israel and Gaza’s militant rulers Hamas earlier this month.

column1: Should companies let employees choose their tasks?
column2: The tactic can be useful with very skilled employees and independent projects

column1: U.S. News names UCR No. 1 public for social mobility
column2: UC Riverside is the top public university in the U.S. for social mobility, according to the just-released 2022-23 U.S. News & World Report college rankings.

column1: Forbes magazine ranks UC Riverside No. 33 public university
column2: UC Riverside is the No. 33 public university in a college ranking from Forbes magazine. UCR was among several UC campuses and 17 public universities in the top 50. The methodology for the Forbes list relies on data from two federal databases, the Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, or IPEDS, and the College Scorecard, as well as several databases that gauge graduates’ earning.

column1: UC Riverside reaches No. 1 in social mobility
column2: University of California, Riverside, is the top university in the United States for social mobility in the 2020 U.S. News & World Report Best Colleges rankings.

column1: Tetris: It could be the salve for a worried mind
column2: Tetris could be the salve for a worried mind.  The venerable video game was used in a recent experiment to create a state of “flow” – the term psychologists use to describe a state of mind so engaged it makes the rest of the world fall away, and time pass more quickly. UCR researcher Kate Sweeny and her team have found that state of perfect disengagement may improve the otherwise-emotionally unpleasant experience of awaiting uncertain news.

column1: Beyond Brilliant: Campaign highlights inspiring people of UC Riverside
column2: Dramatic growth in rankings – including increasing 80 spots in two years (Forbes) and 41 places in one year (Center for World University Rankings) – two Nobel Prize winners joining the faculty, and recognition as the nation’s leader for social mobility (U.S. News & World Report) have positioned UC Riverside as America’s fastest rising university. A new campaign, titled Beyond Brilliant, goes beyond the rankings and profiles UCR students and alumni whose inspiring personal stories demonstrate how the university contributes to the well-being of California and the world.

column1: Gordon Watkins: The man who willed a university into being
column2: Most things, including universities, start with a whisper, a tremor. UC Riverside bolted from the starting gate, founded as the University of California system’s answer to the esteemed private liberal arts colleges of the East. The chief architect was its first provost, Gordon Watkins, who died 50 years ago, on May 5, 1970. The character of UCR at its founding was said to be the character of Watkins. In fact, UCR’s popular designation at the time was “Watkins college.”

column1: ‘You All Look Alike to Me’ is hard-wired in us
column2: You often hear it framed in a comic sense, though it’s a form of stereotyping, and even prejudice.  “You all look alike to me.”  To one race, the tired adage implies, people in other races are tough to differentiate from each other. Some call it the “other-race effect.”

column1: Center for Social Innovation tapped for equity project
column2: The Southern California Association of Governments, or SCAG, the nation’s largest metropolitan planning organization representing six counties, 191 cities, and more than 18 million residents, has chosen the Center for Social Innovation at UC Riverside to conduct research and offer insights and recommendations to advance economic inclusion and equity across Southern California.

column1: Agile organizations should look to knowledge, not tasks
column2: Employees with diverse skills, knowledge, and goals will design their work better from the get-go

column1: Why renting can be better than owning
column2: Purchasing a skill-based product can be self-defeating

column1: Retailers can manipulate consumer regret to beat competitors
column2: Offering an everyday low price might not be the best strategy for retailers facing the threat of new competitors in their market

column1: Cruise buyers’ counterintuitive response to prices could help the industry rebound post-pandemic
column2: The post-pandemic cruise industry should plan ticket sales to attract loyalists, who book early in advance and are less price sensitive

column1: Beyond Brilliant: Born to succeed
column2: Elñora Tena Webb grew up in the foster care system; UCR gave her a clean canvas and after becoming a college president, she is now a success coach .

column1: Study explains why tall individuals are more prone to cancer
column2: UC Riverside evolutionary biologist says increased cancer risk associated with height is due primarily to an increase in the number of body cells

column1: Winter quarter to begin with remote instruction
column2: In an announcement to the UC Riverside campus, Chancellor Kim A. Wilcox announced that instruction will be delivered remotely for the first two weeks of the winter quarter. He cited the emergence of the Omicron variant and the start of the quarter taking place just after the New Year’s holiday.  The campus will remain open during this period and in-person instruction is expected to begin the week of Jan. 17.

column1: Using Earth’s history to inform the search for life on exoplanets
column2: UC Riverside is leading one of the NASA Astrobiology Program’s eight new research teams tackling questions about the evolution and origins of life on Earth and the possibility of life beyond our solar system.

column1: Experts address anxiety about returning to work during pandemic
column2: UC Riverside is set to reopen in fall 2021

column1: An 'awe-full' state of mind may set you free
column2: An induced feeling of awe, or state of wonder, may be the best strategy yet for alleviating the discomfort that comes from uncertain waiting. Kate Sweeny’s research explores the most excruciating form of waiting: the period during which one awaits uncertain news, the outcome of which is beyond one’s control. It’s waiting for news from a biopsy, or whether you aced — or tanked — the exam. That’s distinguished from waiting periods such as when looking for a new job, when you have at least some control over the outcome.

column1: Tiny desk, huge accomplishments – and his own bed
column2: The bed

column1: Silver linings playbook: Think bad news before it's delivered
column2: Psychologists have known there’s value in finding a “silver lining,” in coaxing oneself through bad news. You didn’t get the job? Just as well: That new boss seemed edgy during the interview. Someone outbid you at the last second for that antique something-or-other on eBay? You didn’t really have the money to spend anyway. Those coping strategies result in less depression, and greater life satisfaction and self-esteem. Finding silver linings can even mean better physical health.

column1: Business activity in the Inland Empire is still on the rise and expected to continue growing in 2023
column2: Business activity in the Inland Empire has continued to rise and despite the turbulence in today’s macroeconomy, is forecast to continue its upward climb in the near-term future.

column1: Psychologist to study how motor development changes infants’ learning experiences
column2: John Franchak has long been interested in how learning a new motor skill, such as sitting or walking, changes how infants interact with their surroundings. He has now been awarded a grant from the National Science Foundation to pursue this research question.

column1: New method detects deepfake videos with up to 99% accuracy
column2: Two-pronged technique detects manipulated facial expressions and identity swaps

column1: Engineering college interim dean to become dean at Drexel University College of Engineering
column2: The interim dean of the Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering at UC Riverside will become the new dean of the College of Engineering at Drexel University in Philadelphia, beginning Sept. 1. Sharon Walker has been interim dean since July 2016, replacing Reza Abbaschian, who had been dean for 11 years, and who became director of the Winston Chung Global Energy Center at UCR.

column1: Medical school led the way for safe return to classrooms
column2: The School of Medicine has lessons to share after several months of in-person classes with no documented cases of COVID-19 transmission

column1: Chatbots for dementia patients and caregivers need more work
column2: Systematic review of apps finds need for evidence-based chatbots that have undergone end user evaluation

column1: When the world took notice
column2: The course is named “Seminar in Social Psychology,” but it could be “Wednesdays with Bob.” At 85, Robert Rosenthal is in his last year teaching at UC Riverside. Distinguished Professor David Funder — who first worked with Rosenthal at Harvard University in the early 1980s — urged Rosenthal to host a semester-long brain dump. Funder is the emcee, the inquisitor. Says Rosenthal: “It’s a strange course. It’s a class about me.”

column1: Lonely? These odd rituals can help
column2: Personal rituals around everyday tasks ease loneliness

column1: Is ChatGPT a threat to education?
column2: UC Riverside experts share thoughts on the AI-powered language model that understands and responds to natural language

column1: Scientists are using AI originally developed for producing deepfake videos to stop future pandemics
column2: Generative adversarial networks are being used to predict the structure of antibodies that could neutralize a previously unknown virus

column1: Surprising number of exoplanets could host life
column2: A new UC Riverside study shows other stars could have as many as seven Earth-like planets in the absence of a gas giant like Jupiter.

column1: How the brain stores remote fear memory
column2: UC Riverside mouse study could lead to novel therapies for people living with PTSD

column1: New technology offers fighting chance against grapevine killer
column2: Scientists at UC Riverside have a shot at eradicating a deadly threat to vineyards posed by the glassy-winged sharpshooter, just as its resistance to insecticide has been growing.

column1: Fall instruction roadmap released
column2: Final decisions about which fall 2021 classes will be in-person are at least several weeks away. But with May registration for fall classes looming, an Instructional Continuity working group has released a roadmap for what fall 2021 will look like. A March 2 letter from Interim Provost Thomas Smith said UCR’s strategy is a return to 75-80% in-person instruction, with department chairs responsible for determining which courses will be in-person and which will be remote.

column1: New security flaw discovered in Wi-Fi routers
column2: Hackers can use your wireless router to extract information, and there’s not much you can do to stop them

column1: Business activity in the Inland Empire expands again
column2: Trade activity strong to date but future outlook cloudy

column1: Networking in life and business
column2: This Nigeria native came to UC Riverside ready to make friends and learn about finance.

column1: Acclaimed industry designer Scott Saltsman presents summer youth workshop in video game design
column2: Gear-up for a future in technology at UCR Extension and UCR Palm Desert

column1: Celebrity sightings have a built-in contradiction
column2: UC Riverside research helps explain a tradeoff in human behavior

column1: Fundraising effort seeks to aid at-risk Afghan scholars
column2: Public donations will help scholars fleeing from danger, offer them safety .

column1: Eleven students awarded study-abroad scholarships
column2: Eleven UC Riverside students have been selected for two prestigious national scholarships to study or intern outside of the United States.

column1: Australia enables UCR to dig into Earth’s wild past
column2: Australian officials signed an agreement last night allowing UC Riverside to continue its pioneering research on a government-owned goldmine for unusual fossils. Nilpena Station is a city-sized plot of land in the Australian Outback. It harbors the richest collection on Earth of animal species around 550 million years old. Some of its fossil beds are the size of a tennis court and contain entire communities of organisms.

column1: Graduation with a global perspective
column2: An international education was key for these UCR students’ futures.

column1: Virtual program links students around the globe
column2: UC Riverside’s International Affairs shifted into a nearly 24/7 operation earlier this year, especially in its efforts to recruit new international students. The team spent thousands of hours redesigning programs for virtual platforms — all made accessible to students in the United States and around the world.

column1: Partners help us stay connected during pandemic
column2: A pair of UCR studies reveal that living with a romantic partner helps people feel more socially connected during COVID-19. But no other pandemic-era social dynamic carries notable benefits, the researchers found: not your kids, not kibitzing with your bestie on FaceTime, and not your adorable-adoring pets.

column1: How do insects survive on a sugary diet?
column2: Study offers clues to how aphids capitalize on relationship with beneficial bacteria through changes in gene expression linked to DNA methylation

column1: UCR Joins Pen America in Reading Original Works of Resistance
column2: For thousands, it was a week to march for civil and human rights. For the Department of Creative Writing, it was also a week to write and speak out for them.

column1: Supercomputing improves biomass fuel conversion
column2: Researchers combine supercomputing with nano-imaging to reveal how to efficiently break down plant biomass and transform it into transportation fuels

column1: Research suggests the happiest introverts may be extraverts
column2: If you are an introvert, force yourself to be an extravert. You’ll be happier.  That’s the suggestion of the first-ever study asking people to act like extraverts for a prolonged period. For one week, the 123 participants were asked to – in some cases – push the boundaries of their willingness to engage, by acting as extraverts. For another week, the same group was asked to act like introverts.

column1: UC Riverside reaffirms MOU with EPA
column2: A number of environmentally focused activities with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) will be continuing, thanks to the renewal of a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between EPA’s Region 9 and the University of California, Riverside.

column1: Meet the 2021 Goldwater, Fulbright scholars
column2: Goldwater scholars Shayan Saeed and Ryan Gates; and U.S. Fulbright scholars Jacqueline Aguirre de la O and Zehra Qazi are recipients of two of the nation’s most prestigious awards.  The Barry M. Goldwater Scholarship is one of the country’s most competitive honors in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics fields, or STEM. The application process is rigorous and asks students to think deeply about their research and long-term goals.

column1: In sexual conflict, ant queens prevail in evolutionary arms race
column2: It’s hidden from sight, but there’s an epic battle of the sexes raging in the leafcutter ant species Atta colombica. Competing males deliver sperm in a fluid that’s toxic to rivals’ sperm, while females quash their efforts in order to ensure their own reproductive success.

column1: Symposium celebrates 50 Years of clean air leadership
column2: CARB’s 50th Anniversary Technology Symposium and Showcase highlighted CARB’s history driving innovative technologies that have made monumental improvements to California’s air quality

column1: Study examines straight men and their sexual attraction to transgender women
column2: An analysis of online Reddit conversations also revealed a paradox: the same men devalue both trans and cisgender women.

column1: Experiments in growing algae without sunlight
column2: Elizabeth Hann, a doctoral student in plant biology at UC Riverside, is using a two-year, $60,000 fellowship from the Link Foundation to test whether she can grow algae for biofuels completely in the dark using solar-generated electricity.

column1: Study finds childhood diet has lifelong impact
column2: Eating too much fat and sugar as a child can alter your microbiome for life, even if you later learn to eat healthier, a new UC Riverside study in mice suggests.

column1: UC Riverside enrolls second-highest rate of first-generation freshmen in UC system
column2: A systemwide initiative was launched in 2016 to increase support for these students.

column1: UC Riverside helps secure the future of food
column2: If you’re eating fruits, nuts, grains, or vegetables in a few years, you’ll likely owe a debt of gratitude to UC Riverside. The university has created a program to transition today’s undergraduates into professional scientists solving tomorrow’s farming challenges. The program, called Plants-3D, will train students to discover, design, and deploy biology and engineering solutions to the projected problem of massive-scale food insecurity due to climate change.

column1: Slime travelers
column2: New UC Riverside research settles a longstanding debate about whether the most ancient animal communities were deliberately mobile. It turns out they were, because they were hungry.

column1: Trade disputes have little effect on Inland Empire economy
column2: The region’s economy continues to grow despite ongoing trade disputes that many feared would inhibit the logistics industry

column1: New study dramatically narrows the search for advanced life in the universe
column2: In a new study, a UC Riverside–led team discovered that a buildup of toxic gases in the atmospheres of most planets makes them unfit for complex life as we know it.

column1: Pioneering UC Riverside geoecologist elected to the National Academy of Sciences
column2: Marilyn Fogel, a University of California, Riverside endowed geoecology professor, received one of the highest honors in science this week with her election to the National Academy of Sciences, or NAS. Membership in the NAS is rare. According to the Congressional Research Service, there are 6.9 million scientists in the U.S. However, there are only 2,347 active NAS members and 487 foreign associates.

column1: Space travel can make the gut leaky
column2: UC Riverside-led study tested the effects of microgravity on intestinal epithelial cells

column1: Meteor magnets in outer space
column2: Astronomers believe planets like Jupiter shield us from space objects that would otherwise slam into Earth. Now they’re closer to learning whether giant planets act as guardians of solar systems elsewhere in the galaxy.  A UCR-led team has discovered two Jupiter-sized planets about 150 light years away from Earth that could reveal whether life is likely on the smaller planets in other solar systems.

column1: Star tours
column2: Astronomers have a new tool in their search for extraterrestrial life – a sophisticated bot that helps identify stars hosting planets similar to Jupiter and Saturn.

column1: NASA’s TESS mission finds ‘missing link’ planets
column2: NASA’s newest planet-hunting satellite has discovered a type of planet missing from our own solar system.  Launched in 2018, the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite, or TESS, has found three new worlds around a neighboring star. Stephen Kane, a UC Riverside associate professor of planetary astrophysics, says the new star system, called TESS Object of Interest, or TOI-270, is exactly what the satellite was designed to find.

column1: Making sense of a ‘7.1’
column2: Abhijit Ghosh, UCR associate professor of geophysics, is racing to understand everything he can about the fault that was unknown until it produced a 7.1 magnitude earthquake on July 5. Ghosh's work could help officials prepare for the next big shake.

column1: Scientists develop new method to detect oxygen on exoplanets
column2: UC Riverside scientists have developed a new method for detecting oxygen in exoplanet atmospheres that may accelerate the search for life.

column1: The thrust of the problem
column2: A new understanding of a fault that caused a deadly 7.8 magnitude earthquake can help scientists better predict where and when the next big one will hit.

column1: Ancient meteorite site on Earth could reveal new clues about Mars’ past
column2: UC Riverside scientists have devised new analytical tools to break down the enigmatic history of Mars’ atmosphere — and whether life was once possible there.

column1: To survive asteroid impact, algae learned to hunt
column2: Tiny, seemingly harmless ocean plants survived the darkness of the asteroid strike that killed the dinosaurs by learning a ghoulish behavior — eating other living creatures.

column1: UCR offers the first Cahuilla language course in UC system
column2: Students in the four-class series also study Cahuilla society and culture.

column1: Native American students experience college life during a one-week summer program
column2: For 17 years Native American Student Programs has been hosting Gathering of the Tribes, the longest running Native American youth summer program in the UC system.

column1: Expert available to comment on Mexico’s presidential election
column2: UC Riverside’s Armando Navarro will travel to Mexico City in advance of the July 1 election to survey voters and visit polling places

column1: Extension offers first-of-its-kind ethnic studies certificate program
column2: University Extension is the first continuing education program in California to offer teachers a professional development certificate for a newly state-mandated course.

column1: Nutrient-recycling microbes may feel the heat
column2: Study led by UCR researcher explores how climate change affects nature’s ability to recycle

column1: Physicists name and codify new field in nanotechnology: ‘electron quantum metamaterials’
column2: UC Riverside’s Nathaniel Gabor and colleague formulate a vision for the field in a perspective article

column1: Computers, nematodes, and curiosity
column2: Alejandro De Santiago Perez wants more lab experience before pursuing a doctorate in bioinformatics.

column1: Salton Sea restoration efforts could fail without science
column2: There are finally efforts under way to improve the environmental health disaster that is the Salton Sea — California’s largest and most polluted lake. However, a group of UC Riverside scientists, engineers, medical experts, and economists has published a new report warning that without science, these efforts may not succeed.

column1: How well do you know the Salton Sea?
column2: What was once a destination for Hollywood's biggest stars is now one of California's gravest environmental threats. Test your knowledge to see how much you know about the Salton Sea.

column1: From juvenile detention to college graduation
column2: A felony conviction gave Ramón Leija the determination to turn his life around.

column1: Why voting is important
column2: A UC Riverside student leads voter registration campaign to get classmates to the polls.

column1: Upward ventilation offers better protection from indoor coronavirus transmission
column2: A simple change in the direction of the air forced through indoor gathering spaces by heating, air conditioning, and ventilation systems, could reduce the spread of infectious diseases like COVID-19.

column1: University lends a hand by lending doctors a bed
column2: The top floor of the UC Riverside Extension building has a new and esteemed set of occupants: doctors and other health care workers on the front lines of the battle against the COVID-19 pandemic. About two weeks ago, the university received two requests to provide healthcare workers with alternative housing. The requests came from the Riverside County Medical Association and on behalf UCR School of Medicine residents.

column1: Engineering her family's future
column2: Andrea Cruz Castillo pushed through self-doubt and maternal guilt to launch a career in data administration and database management

column1: On the front line of medicine
column2: Medical school graduate Hurnan Vongsachang will start her residency in emergency medicine this summer

column1: For the love of caterpillars
column2: A first-generation student’s journey into entomology.

column1: Patricia Cardoso directs TV episodes for Netflix and The CW
column2: “In the Dark” and “The Society” are now airing.

column1: 'Falling out of love' led to record-breaking tennis career
column2: A shift from soccer to tennis jostled Kyle McCann's Irish footballer-father, but a storied UCR career affirms it was the right move.

column1: Connecting through culture
column2: This psychology major from Dubai made it her mission to connect local and international students.

column1: Making higher-energy light to fight cancer
column2: Researchers use nontoxic silicon nanocrystals to convert low-energy photons into high-energy ones, bringing scientists closer to developing photodynamic treatments for cancer

column1: Microbiome study suggests marine nematodes are not picky eaters
column2: UCR research finding no relationship between nematode species and microbial profile suggests marine worms don’t have a restrictive diet

column1: Botnet buster finds IoT command and control centers
column2: Tool fools malware twice and can trick it into revealing itself

column1: Biomedical scientist explains how Covid-19 vaccines work
column2: Dr. David Lo at the UC Riverside School of Medicine is an expert on vaccines

column1: $1 million gift empowers next generation of scientists
column2: Undergraduate research is benefactor of gift from Rochelle Campbell and Professor Sue Wessler

column1: UCR recognizes longtime generosity of Campbell family with building renaming
column2: The University Laboratory Building is being renamed the “Rochelle and Allison Campbell Hall”

column1: Fallout 'serious' for noncompliance to UC vaccination policy
column2: As the Aug. 16 deadline looms for compliance with the UC vaccination policy, the fallout for those who fail to comply is being made clear.  In a campus announcement this week, Human Resources delineated protocols for employees who haven’t provided proof of full vaccination or requested an exemption or deferral by Aug. 16.

column1: How stressed-out plants produce their own aspirin
column2: Plants protect themselves from environmental hazards by producing salicylic acid, also known as aspirin. A new understanding of this process may help plants survive climate change.

column1: Ladies’ choice: What drives faster, flashier formation of new animal species
column2: Evolution is actually a Sadie Hawkins dance, as new research shows females not only determine whether male animals develop bright colors, but also how fast new species develop.

column1: Flame retardants linked to autistic-like behavior
column2: UC Riverside-led study shows maternal transfer of PBDEs causes brain changes in female mice offspring

column1: Fiber-optic probe can see molecular bonds
column2: Pointing the new nanoscopy tool like a Harry Potter wand reveals a high-resolution image of molecules

column1: Stanislavski at UC Riverside: A place where actors, scholars meet
column2: What does it take to bring together actors and scholars? For Bella Merlin, professor of acting and directing at the University of California, Riverside, it takes a practical acting laboratory. A place where ideas and facts will come together.

column1: Economic Forecast Conference delivers good news
column2: A decade after the recession of 2008, the region is home to the fastest job growth in Southern California and is the most improved among the major surrounding metro areas

column1: Student Shoutout: From summer memories to favorite classes
column2: Temperatures are rising and UCR students are dreaming of vacations.

column1: COVID-19: Some faculty-student teams figured out how to continue their research
column2: In the midst of the pandemic, faculty mentored research projects are being supported through CAMP.

column1: UCR has money to help students re-enroll
column2: More than $188,000 in HEERF funds are available for students who stopped coming to UCR during the 2020-21 school year for COVID-19 related reasons.

column1: UC Riverside receives Diversity Award
column2: INSIGHT into Diversity recognition acknowledges recruitment, retention efforts for underrepresented, first-generation students and faculty

column1: Family is our focus during pandemic, study finds
column2: More fully appreciating family and engaging in more conflict are among the heightened experiences during the coronavirus pandemic, according to a new UC Riverside study. The study from David Funder’s psychology lab looked at how people experience everyday life and its situations and how those experiences change because of an extraordinary event – the global pandemic.

column1: Guppies teach us why evolution happens
column2: Guppies, a perennial pet store favorite, have helped a UC Riverside scientist unlock a key question about evolution: Do animals evolve in response to the risk of being eaten, or to the environment that they create in the absence of predators? Turns out, it’s the latter.

column1: Childhood diet and exercise creates healthier, less anxious adults
column2: Exercise and a healthy diet in childhood leads to adults with bigger brains and lower levels of anxiety, according to new UC Riverside research in mice.

column1: Scientists decode DNA secrets of world’s toughest bean
column2: UCR scientists have decoded the genome of black-eyed peas, offering hope for feeding Earth's expanding population, especially as the climate changes.

column1: UCR alumna’s story on rapper Nipsey Hussle results in Emmy nomination
column2: The Fox 11 reporter’s profile ran four months before the artist’s murder.

column2: The widely circulated publication Inside Higher Ed published a story this past week that features a "virtual roundtable" at UC Riverside with the secretary of the U.S. Department of Education.

column2: African Student Programs, Chicano Student Programs celebrate a milestone on campus. At the center of it is student success.

column1: How drones can help dairy farms manage methane emissions
column2: Accurate atmospheric measurements directly over their farm can help farmers fight climate change
