column2: UCR’s Campus Collective has more than 2,000 mentees in four months.

column1: Astronauts might soon grow SPACE tomatoes
column2: Grant to UC Riverside could help put tiny tomato plants on the International Space Station

column1: 'I know that we're going to get through it'
column2: As election day morphs into election days, UC Riverside’s students are like voters red and blue alike: seeking comfort where they can find it. “I think everyone wanted a definite result. We did not get that,” said political scientist Shaun Bowler.

column1: Pumpkins, trunk-o-treat, and family fun at UC Riverside
column2: UCR’s Community Garden will host its inaugural Fall Festival and Pumpkin Patch on Oct. 26.

column1: Culture war battles at schools harm public education, UC report finds
column2: Educators have sought to avoid controversy by pulling back on teaching lessons in civics, politics, and the history and experiences of America’s minority communities.

column1: How are epilepsy and autism linked?
column2: UC Riverside and Rutgers University scientists explore this question in a study on mice

column1: Families of children with autism can get free help from UC Riverside’s SEARCH Center
column2: Inland Empire families don’t have to wade through school and service systems alone

column1: Study confirms link between spatial and math skills
column2: Improving students’ spatial skills could improve math skills as well

column1: Pheromones lure deadly palm weevils to their doom
column2: UC Riverside scientists have a new chemical weapon to seduce and kill the invasive, long-nosed beetles destroying California palm trees by the tens of thousands.

column1: Sundance: Guerrero to star as Wilma Mankiller in ‘The Glorias’
column2: The film premieres this weekend at the Sundance Film Festival .

column1: Early intervention following traumatic brain injury reduces epilepsy risk
column2: UC Riverside-led rat study finds an immune receptor in the hippocampus is responsible for the onset of the disease after brain injuries

column1: Experts on anti-Asian racism and violence
column2: Anti-Asian Racism and Violence For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu.

column1: UCR offers commencement compromise
column2: A plan announced by Chancellor Kim A. Wilcox on Wednesday aims to address graduates' urge to walk at commencement, while respecting the caution still required by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.  Under the plan, graduates can have their photos taken on stage, but no guests will be permitted. A prerecorded 30-minute program will be made available for students and their families to watch from home.

column1: Study shows how memory function could be preserved after brain injury
column2: UC Riverside-led study identifies role played by an immune signaling molecule in regulating memory function in the normal and injured brain

column1: Everything you’ve ever wanted to know about bees
column2: World Bee Day is May 20. To mark the occasion, we gathered some of UC Riverside’s top bee experts to answer questions submitted on our Instagram page. The response created, for lack of a better term, quite a buzz! We got so many questions — hundreds — that we could not answer them all on social media. For those interested in lengthier answers to some of the questions, we’ve posted many of them here, organized by topic.  Entomology

column1: Study links high cholesterol, cardiovascular disease to plastics
column2: UC Riverside-led mouse study finds a receptor greatly contributes to the harmful effects of plastic-associated chemicals

column1: Sustainable laundry dryer lands third in design competition
column2: The solar thermal technology directs heated air from the attic into a closet where wet clothes are hanging

column1: From the streets to the stratosphere: clean driving technology enables cleaner rocket fuel
column2: A chemical used in electric vehicle batteries could also give us carbon-free fuel for space flight, according to new UC Riverside research.

column1: Study identifies new temperature sensing mechanism in plants
column2: Phytochrome foci have different behaviors at different temperatures and types of light

column1: Scientists identify how plants sense temperature
column2: When it gets hot outside, humans and animals have the luxury of seeking shelter in the shade or cool, air-conditioned buildings. But plants are stuck. While not immune to changing climate, plants respond to the rising mercury in different ways. Temperature affects the distribution of plants around the planet. It also affects the flowering time, crop yield, and even resistance to disease.

column1: A guide to understanding the Ukrainian conflict
column2: UCR experts discuss topics surrounding Russia's invasion in Ukraine

column1: Top 5 films and video games for winter break
column2: Use them as gift ideas — or just to treat yourself.

column1: Kimberly Guerrero co-starring in CBS drama pilot
column2: The show is described as “Northern Exposure” meets “The West Wing.”

column1: Health impact of chemicals in plastics is handed down two generations
column2: UC Riverside mouse study finds paternal exposure to phthalates increases risk of metabolic diseases in progeny

column1: UC Riverside discovers first effective treatment for citrus-destroying disease
column2: UC Riverside scientists have found the first substance capable of controlling Citrus Greening Disease, which has devastated citrus farms in Florida and also threatens California.

column1: Microbiome confers resistance to cholera
column2: Many parts of the world are in the midst of a deadly pandemic of cholera, an extreme form of watery diarrhea. UC Riverside scientists have discovered specific gut bacteria make some people resistant to it — a finding that could save lives.

column1: Researchers develop molecular traps to target SARS-CoV-2
column2: Joint effort by UC Riverside and UCLA scientists aims to stop the COVID-19-spreading virus from attacking immune cells

column1: Let them eat rocks
column2: UC Riverside is leading an effort that could help ensure food security and improve the worst effects of climate change — by studying rock-eating bacteria and fungi.

column1: Expert: NATO has a workaround to naval blockade
column2: NATO member countries have walked a line in the months since Russia invaded Ukraine: Supporting Ukraine short of triggering large-scale war with Russia. That line may soon become more difficult to navigate, with Russia now threatening a member of NATO. We asked UCR political scientist and NATO expert Kelechi Kalu to assess Russia's current calculus in Ukraine.

column1: Drug decreases gut leakiness associated with ulcerative colitis
column2: UC Riverside-led study is the first to show how tofacitinib affects epithelial cells lining the gut

column1: New tools in the fight against lethal citrus disease
column2: Scientists are closer to gaining the upper hand on Huanglongbing, a disease that has wiped out citrus orchards across the globe. New models of the bacterium linked to the disease reveal control methods that were previously unavailable.

column1: Drug found to correct gene defect that causes immune-driven gut leakiness
column2: UC Riverside-led study is the first to show how tofacitinib rescues gut barrier function from overactive immune cells

column1: Ukraine advances don't equal Russian retreat
column2: The past week has been one of alternately hopeful and discouraging news in the 7-months-long invasion of Ukraine by Russia. We asked Ukraine expert Paul D'Anieri for guidance on whether the developments signal a winddown in Russian aggression or if they foretell a next, more perilous chapter. D'Anieri wrote the 2019 book “Ukraine and Russia" and a 2007 book, “Understanding Ukrainian Politics: Power, Politics and Institutional Design.” For the 2017-18 academic year, he served as a fellow in the Harvard University Ukrainian Research Institution.

column1: What is your moral responsibility in Ukraine?
column2: Letters to the editor populate the pages of media outlets, speaking to America's and Americans' moral authority to act, or not to act, in Ukraine. You and I didn't cause this. Then why do we feel we should be doing something more - and what do we do with that anxiety? We turned to John Martin Fischer, a UC Riverside philosophy professor who is a world-leading expert on free will and moral responsibility. Fischer's ruminations on near-death experiences have been consumed by millions in his writings and on YouTube videos.

column1: Carb-eating bacteria under viral threat
column2: Strictly speaking, humans cannot digest complex carbohydrates — that’s the job of bacteria in our large intestines. UC Riverside scientists have just discovered a new group of viruses that attack these bacteria.

column1: Root bacteria could help defeat fatal citrus disease
column2: A UC Riverside-led team is looking at tiny underground microorganisms for a way to prevent a huge problem — Huanglongbing, a disease with no cure that has decimated citrus orchards worldwide. The National Institute of Food and Agriculture has awarded the team $10 million to investigate the role of soil and root microbes in the disease.

column1: Turning food waste back into food
column2: UC Riverside scientists have discovered fermented food waste can boost bacteria that increase crop growth, making plants more resistant to pathogens and reducing carbon emissions from farming.

column1: Proteins enable crop-infecting fungi to ‘smell’ food
column2: New UC Riverside research shows the same proteins that enable human senses such as smell also allow certain fungi to sense something they can eat. The study offers new avenues for protecting people from starvation due to pathogenic fungus-induced food shortages. Understanding how fungi sense and digest plants can also help scientists engineer fungal strains that are more efficient at producing biofuels.

column1: Protein discovery could help enable eco-friendly fungicides
column2: New UC Riverside research reveals an essential step in scientists’ quest to create targeted, more eco-friendly fungicides that protect food crops.

column1: New degree fills a gap in biotechnology labor force
column2: The Professional Science Master’s Degree in Industrial Biotechnology prepares students for the most in-demand, highly skilled jobs

column1: Making mezcal is an art; science shows us why
column2: Experiments show how bubbles indicate alcohol value

column1: A potential antiviral for SARS and SARS-like coronaviruses
column2: UC Riverside-led study shows how an effective therapy against SARS-CoV-2 could be developed

column1: Experts on brain-eating amoeba
column2: For fast access to experts, email news@ucr.edu  Haizhou Liu, associate professor of chemical and environmental engineering. Professor Liu works to discover new and improved methods of removing impurities from drinking water and ensuring the safety of our water supply. Liu can speak to the difference between chloramine and chlorine, and water treatment chemistry in general. haizhou@engr.ucr.edu

column1: UCR biomedical scientist joins international SARS-CoV-2 group assembled by NIAID
column2: SAVE focuses on mutations in SARS-CoV-2 and emerging virus variants

column1: Human gut bacteria have sex to share vitamin B12
column2: Your gut bacteria need vitamin B12 just as much as you do. Though DNA is usually passed from parent to child, new research shows gut bacteria transfer genes through “sex” in order to take their vitamins.

column1: Bingeing in the time of coronavirus
column2: State and federal officials are asking Americans to stay home during the COVID-19 pandemic.  So is it possible to find an entertaining activity that provides a small respite from our larger societal worries? Derek Burrill, associate professor of media and cultural studies at UC Riverside, has created a list of things to binge on while staying at home.

column1: $1.9 million award could keep Zika virus at bay
column2: A UC Riverside virologist has won a $1.9 million award to help prevent the re-emergence of Zika virus, which causes microcephaly in newborns and Guillain-Barre syndrome in adults.

column1: Why doesn’t fire kill some bacteria and fungi?
column2: UC Riverside scientists will spend the next three years studying the traits that allow soil microbes to respond to fire, as well as the role those microbes play in storing or emitting powerful greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide or nitrous oxide.

column1: Black eyed peas could help eliminate need for fertilizer
column2: Black eyed peas’ ability to attract beneficial bacteria isn’t diminished by modern farming practices, new UC Riverside research shows. Planting it in rotation with other crops could help growers avoid the need for costly, environmentally damaging fertilizers.

column1: After wildfires, do microbes exhale potent greenhouse gas?
column2: Laughing gas is no laughing matter — nitrous oxide is a greenhouse gas with 300 times the warming potential of carbon dioxide. Scientists are racing to learn whether microorganisms send more of it into the atmosphere after wildfires.

column1: Meet the forest microbes that can survive megafires
column2: New UC Riverside research shows fungi and bacteria able to survive redwood tanoak forest megafires are microbial “cousins” that often increase in abundance after feeling the flames.

column1: $1 million award supports first generation students
column2: UC Riverside has been selected as one of 10 American Talent Initiative members to participate in the Kessler Scholars Collaborative. As part of the collaborative, UCR will receive a five-year, $1 million grant. First established at the University of Michigan in 2008, Kessler Scholars provides student financial support and academic, professional, and personal support services to first-generation, limited-income students throughout their four-year college experiences.

column1: Drought increases microbe-laden dust landing in Sierras
column2: Dust from all over the world is landing in the Sierra Nevada mountains carrying microbes that are toxic to both plants and humans. Research from UC Riverside shows higher concentrations of the dust are landing at lower elevations, where people are more likely to be hiking.

column1: A new look at ‘The Chicano Experience’
column2: Professor Alfredo Mirandé’s 1985 foundational sociology book has a completely revised second edition.

column1: Precisely poking cells en masse to cure cancer
column2: Device can mass-produce engineered cells at lower cost, a tipping point for emerging lifesaving therapies

column1: Discovery of antibody structure could lead to treatment for Crimean Congo Hemorrhagic Fever virus
column2: Study provides insights into fighting broad range of pathogen’s viral strains

column1: Scientists discover new avian immunological pathway
column2: UC Riverside-led team identifies a new host protein interaction that produces a robust immune response to viral infection in birds and may lead to better poultry vaccines

column1: Inspired by ‘Get Out,’ UCR professor launches course on Afrofuturism and horror
column2: Class based on the Oscar-nominated film will see students map out their own versions of the “sunken place” in lieu of a final exam

column1: UC Riverside joins UC San Diego, UC Irvine in multidisciplinary research institute Calit2
column2: Calit2 was created by the state of California over 20 years ago to ensure the state remains on the leading edge of information technology, communications

column1: New Livestreaming and Virtual Reality Lab is bringing VR to the masses
column2: The lab aims to democratize virtual reality while also providing students new opportunities in the burgeoning digital media industry.

column1: A match made in neural heaven: How a neuron grows an axon
column2: Scientists unlock new molecular secrets to unravel the mystery

column1: Neuroscientist receives Klingenstein-Simons Fellowship Award in neuroscience
column2: Hongdian Yang is UC Riverside’s first recipient of the prestigious fellowship

column1: Neurons are genetically programmed to have long lives
column2: UC Riverside-led study identifies mechanism that prevents death of neurons

column1: No more flu for you? Discovery blocks influenza virus’ replication in cells
column2: SUMOylation inhibitor could lead to highly effective ways to treat the flu and other respiratory viruses

column1: UC responds to Prop 16 outcome
column2: As California voters again voted down affirmative action, the University of California and UC Riverside affirmed their commitment to building the system’s underrepresented student population. Proposition 16, which failed 56.1% to 43.9%, would have repealed 1996’s Proposition 209, which— among other things—banned the consideration of race, ethnicity, and gender in college admissions decisions.

column1: Physicists explain how large spherical viruses form
column2: UC Riverside-led study deciphers key elements for the assembly of a large virus; understanding its formation could contain viruses’ spread

column1: Can Putin accept peace but also save face?
column2: Wednesday, we asked UC Riverside Professor and leading Ukraine-Russia expert Paul D'Anieri to weigh in on breaking developments related to a 15-point peace plan being discussed that could end the month-long war between Ukraine and Russia. The conditions would surround Ukrainian neutrality — with a peace plan's fate dependent on what that means to Ukraine, Russia, and even the West.

column1: China-Russia: Any alliance is conditional, temporary
column2: Related to Russia's ongoing war with Ukraine, China is fielding as many requests for aid from Russia as it's receiving threats from the West about what will happen if it provides that aid. We asked two UC Riverside China experts to provide perspective about the likelihood of all-in Chinese aid to Russia.

column1: $20M sustainable nanotechnology partnership renewed
column2: The National Science Foundation, or NSF, has renewed funding for a UC Riverside laboratory solving big environmental and agricultural challenges with very small chemical particles called nanomaterials.

column1: E-cigarette users are exposed to potentially harmful levels of metal linked to DNA damage
column2: Zinc excess in the body correlates with oxidative stress

column1: Will economic sanctions make Putin blink?
column2: UCR economist and former EU official considers Switzerland's importance in Russian recriminations

column1: Experts on Ukraine-Russia
column2: The war in Ukraine For fast access to experts, TEXT or call 951-534-8912, or email news@ucr.edu

column2: UC Riverside-led study could inform the design of engineered nano-shells used in drug delivery

column1: Satellite galaxies of the Milky Way help test dark matter theory
column2: UC Riverside physicists demonstrate “self-interacting dark matter” model can be tested using astronomical observations of Draco and Fornax

column2: Brandon Brown is an associate professor in the School of Medicine at UC Riverside

column2: Work on selective immune system suppression in influenza could transfer directly to COVID-19

column2: Edgar Ortega overcame language barriers, injuries in effort to help his new community as a doctor

column2: UCR’s 64th Commencement includes School of Medicine’s Hippocratic oath ceremony

column2: Shannon Sweitzer carries life lessons from her father during UCR journey

column1: Scientists identify hundreds of drug candidates to treat COVID-19
column2: UC Riverside researchers used a powerful machine-learning approach to screen millions of chemicals to find suitable candidates

column2: UC Riverside study applies machine learning to olfaction with possible vast applications in flavors and fragrances

column2: UC Riverside-led team’s technique relied on determining the mass of galaxy clusters

column2: Local wages are not rising enough to keep up with inflation

column2: UC Riverside study identified toxic elements in pod atomizers

column2: UC Riverside study examines molecular pathways that may instigate seizures in some multiple sclerosis patients

column1: Scientists solve long-standing mystery by a whisker
column2: UC Riverside mouse study shows where in the brain sensory input is transformed to movement

column1: Not so quiet, please
column2: UC Riverside mouse study finds early exposure to sounds can address hypersensitivity to noise associated with Fragile X Syndrome

column2: UC Riverside study has implications for children’s television and autism spectrum disorder

column2: UC Riverside study shows food choice decisions require taste input

column1: New funding to significantly boost cancer, ALS research
column2: UC Riverside’s Maurizio Pellecchia receives grants totaling nearly $2.5 million from National Academy of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine; and National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

column1: New hope for people living with a genetic cause of autism
column2: UC Riverside research shows gene reactivation can be used to treat Fragile X syndrome

column1: Six theater employees sew face masks for their colleagues
column2: The goal is to make at least 750 masks, which are free for essential UCR employees.

column1: Revisiting the tragic tale of Willie Boy and Carlota
column2: More than a century ago, a Romeo and Juliet-esque tragedy unfolded in the desert southwest. The antagonist, Willie Boy, shot and killed the shaman, William Mike, and eloped with William Mike’s daughter, Carlota, who met her demise at the hands of the pursuing posse.

column1: New book explores how plague shaped Christianity in the Americas
column2: During the first century of American colonization, as many as 20 million people in Mexico perished from disease, violence, and exploitation. Jennifer Scheper Hughes, a professor in the Department of History at the University of California, Riverside, examines this period from historical and theological perspectives in her new book, “The Church of the Dead: The Epidemic of 1576 and the Birth of Christianity in the Americas.”

column1: Scientists unpack how taste neurons control food intake
column2: UC Riverside-led research on fruit fly could lead to better understanding of how taste information is coded in the brain

column1: How diet influences taste sensitivity and preference
column2: What you eat influences your taste for what you might want to eat next. So claims a University of California, Riverside, study performed on fruit flies. The study, published in the Journal of Neuroscience, offers a better understanding of neurophysiological plasticity of the taste system in flies.

column1: UCR professor is historical consultant to Jason Momoa’s new film ‘The Last Manhunt’
column2: Saban Films just secured worldwide distribution rights to the movie shot in Banning and Joshua Tree.

column1: Winter quarter will bring full return to classrooms
column2: Provost Elizabeth Watkins announced Wednesday that winter quarter will signal a full return to in-person classes. Winter quarter begins Jan. 3, 2022.

column1: Scientists crack structure of a novel enzyme linked to cell growth and cancer
column2: UC Riverside-led study could lead to the development of drugs that target liver and other cancers

column1: Men's Basketball tramples Cornhuskers in season opener
column2: LINCOLN, NEB.- For the second time in three years, the UC Riverside Men's Basketball Team (1-0) opened its season on the road with a big win over a power five conference team. Tuesday night, the Highlanders roasted the Cornhuskers (0-1) from Nebraska 66-47, marking the program's largest margin of victory on opening night against a DI opponent, and the first time the Huskers have lost their home opener since 1980.

column1: UCR's founding School of Public Policy dean to step down after a groundbreaking run
column2: As Anil Deolalikar prepared to step down this week as the founding dean of UCR’s School of Public Policy, he reflected on a groundbreaking career marked by repeatedly choosing a more challenging path. Consider when he completed his Bachelor of Arts degree in economics at Harvard University in 1977 with summa cum laude honors. The world was at his palm, but the obvious option of going to a top business or law school “never really crossed my mind,” he said.  “A lot of my friends were going into business, law, and medicine, and so they thought I was a little crazy,” he said.

column1: Does Ticketmaster have a monopoly?
column2: Two UCR experts to weigh in on whether Ticketmaster is a monopoly and should be subjected to antitrust action.

column1: Pandemic left behind, the Inland Empire economy flourished in 2022
column2: Despite the recession drumbeat getting louder in many quarters across the nation, the Inland Empire’s economy is not only showing strength, but is outstripping California’s other major metros and the state as a whole along some very key measures, according to an analysis released today by the UC Riverside School of Business Center for Economic Forecasting and Development.

column1: Investigating the potential for life around the galaxy’s smallest stars
column2: When the world’s most powerful telescope launches into space this year, scientists will learn whether Earth-sized planets in our ‘solar neighborhood’ have a key prerequisite for life — an atmosphere.

column1: New coronavirus protein reveals drug target
column2: Drugs previously in development for SARS could be effective for COVID-19

column1: New drug target found for COVID-19
column2: Scientists discover critical protein complex that lets virus hide from immune system

column1: Steering into the future of connected and automated vehicles
column2: More than 1 billion motor vehicles travel roadways worldwide and that number is expected to double within one or two decades.  The rise in automobiles and trucks have led to increased social, economic, and safety issues, such as the more than 30,000 deaths from car related accidents on US highways every year, according to a US Department of Transportation (DOT)

column1: Magnonic devices can replace electronics without much noise
column2: Magnonic devices of the future could use low power to avoid performance losses

column1: From foster care to a free MBA
column2: “I have been through a few challenges in my life, but with the support of this school and Guardian Scholars, I have achieved more than I ever thought I would.” - Brandy Renee Taylor

column1: A Ph.D. in punk? Only at UC Riverside
column2: Marlen Ríos-Hernández takes a scholarly approach to the mosh pit

column1: This UCR historian once trained horses; now she studies them
column2: Doctoral student Katrin Boniface turns a lifelong passion into research for a growing field: equine history

column1: This former cop wants to build trust between communities and police
column2: Fulbright Scholar Roberto Rivera looks to Jamaica as a model of restorative justice

column1: Grad Slam spotlights emerging UCR scholars and scientists
column2: The annual competition returns to UC Riverside’s Culver Center on March 4 and Palm Desert Center on April 4

column1: Agreement propels anthropological opportunities for UCR researchers, students in Mexico
column2: Memorandum of understanding strengthens the relationship between UCR’s anthropology department and Mexico’s National Institute of Anthropology and History

column1: Three students receive Barry M. Goldwater Scholarships
column2: Another seven students also received prestigious honors.

column1: A ‘pivotal time in their lives’
column2: Nearly 6,000 students are eligible to graduate this year, with ceremonies running from May 31- June 17.

column1: Earning her chances
column2: Roseanne Carmen Rosenthal’s latest achievements have come by chance — or at least that’s what she thinks. But luck alone doesn’t account for the seven courses she took during spring quarter in order to complete her bachelor’s degree — and the 3.36 GPA she earned doing it — while also meeting deadlines for a doctoral program application.

column1: She sees dead people
column2: History doctoral student Alyse Yeargan studies photographs of the deceased to understand how and why we grieve

column1: 1 (p.m.) is not the loneliest number
column2: The daily 1 p.m. Zoom call has become a lifeline for a team of UC Riverside students and their project scientist.       Sometimes the call focuses on data, driven by the greenhouse emissions research they are conducting for Francesca Hopkins, assistant professor of climate change and sustainability.

column1: Inland Empire business activity still going strong
column2: Business activity in the Inland Empire has continued to grow, and in the context of today’s increasingly uncertain economic environment, stands in stark contrast to growth trends in the nation, according to the new Inland Empire Business Activity Index released today by the UCR School of Business Center for Economic Forecasting and Development. The region’s economy officially transitioned from recovery to expansion in the fourth quarter of 2021 and growth is forecast to continue throughout 2022.

column1: Her mother grew up with no shoes. She's about to become a master’s scholar
column2: Growing up in South Central L.A. meant ditching school, becoming a teen mom, and wrestling with her identity as an Afro-Latina — experiences that made this UCR student want to major in public policy.

column1: Science communication competition — it’s on!
column2: Graduate and undergraduate students in STEM fields are encouraged to participate in this inaugural multimedia event.

column1: UCR offers new research internship for community college transfers
column2: Grant-funded program includes a $5,000 stipend for participants.

column1: School of Public Policy names its second dean
column2: Mark Long has been named dean of UC Riverside’s School of Public Policy effective Jan. 1, 2023. Long is a professor in the Evans School of Public Policy and Governance and an adjunct professor of economics at the University of Washington. He previously served as the Evans School’s associate dean for faculty affairs and associate dean for research.

column1: Fruit fungus for the win at Grad Slam
column2: UC Riverside’s winner, Claire Whitaker, moves onto the UC-level competition in May.

column1: Oldest evidence for animals found by UCR researchers
column2: Molecular fossil evidence suggests sponges lived on the ancient ocean floors 100 million years before the Cambrian period

column1: UCR plant cell biologist elected to National Academy of Sciences
column2: Sean Cutler becomes ninth UC Riverside faculty member elected to the prestigious academy

column1: One-dimensional material packs a powerful punch for next generation electronics
column2: The new technology has applications in nanometer-scale transistors and circuits

column1: Two projects receive NIH grant for breast cancer research
column2: UC Riverside research is supported by a four-year grant worth more than $1.2 million

column1: Grant funds study of sexual abuse in religious communities
column2: Supported by $550,000, a team of researchers led by UCR's Amanda Lucia will examine why and how sexual abuse persists across a range of religious traditions

column1: UCR faculty, staff, and alumni will be at the LA Times Festival of Books
column2: This year’s Los Angeles Times Festival of Books includes a UC Riverside star-studded lineup.  Nineteen UCR faculty, staff, and alumni will be participating in this annual literary event that takes place at the University of Southern California. More than 550 authors, poets, artists, chefs, celebrities, and musicians will gather on April 23-24. See full details: LA Times Festival of Books.

column1: School of Medicine faculty receive grants to increase diversity in biomedical sciences, study incentives in research, boost mental health treatment
column2: Total funding of three grants exceeds $1.2 million

column2: Andrew Subica and Ann Cheney will focus their research on marginalized U.S. populations

column2: Research could lead to the design of new and better treatments to fight disease

column1: UC Riverside receives $4.5 million for engineering graduate education
column2: Five GAANN Awards from the U.S. Department of Education will support 90 engineering graduate students

column1: Grant facilitates research on behavioral development and cognitive aging over lifespan
column2: UC Riverside psychologist Chandra Reynolds will lead the five-year research project

column1: Brain injury research to focus on moderate concussion
column2: Viji Santhakumar, an associate professor of molecular, cell and systems biology at the University of California, Riverside, has received funding from the National Institute of Neurological Disaster and Stroke of the National Institutes of Health to further pursue research on moderate concussive brain injury, which results from car accidents or sports-related concussions.

column1: Psychologist to lead research on Alzheimer’s in Riverside
column2: UC Riverside study is part of a larger landmark study tracking older adults

column1: New pathway facilitates community college students joining UC Riverside medical school
column2: The School of Medicine at the University of California, Riverside, has received a grant of $1.87 million to establish the Inland Empire Regional Hub for Healthcare Opportunity, or IE RHHO, which will create a pre-med pathway for local community college students.

column1: Skateboarder’s view: Photo exhibit captures an inside look at California’s skate parks
column2: A photo exhibit and book launch are set for Sept. 19 in Orange County, with the show traveling to UCR’s Culver Center of the Arts in January 2020.

column1: A 50th anniversary celebration for Tomás Rivera’s seminal book: ‘Y no se lo tragó la tierra’
column2: The free, virtual events will culminate with an inaugural Tomás Rivera Book Prize.

column1: Creating a diverse educational pipeline in microelectronics
column2: Scientists at UC Riverside and UC Irvine have received funding of $5 million from the U.S. Department of Energy, or DOE, to team up with Sandia National Laboratory in Albuquerque, New Mexico, in building a diverse educational pipeline in the field of microelectronics — a priority for industry and government. Of this amount, nearly $4 million is allocated to UC Riverside.

column1: Authors, schedule announced for 45th Writers Week
column2: The February 2022 festival will be virtual. Lifetime Achievement Awards and Costo Medals will be presented to literary giants Sandra Cisneros, Linda Hogan, and Ishmael Reed.

column1: UCR, Inland Empire receive $18 million grant
column2: UC Riverside and the Inland Empire have received $18 million from a statewide investment of $250 million that will establish K-16 Education Collaboratives to address equity gaps and improve education-to-career pipelines in each region of the state.

column1: Tomás Rivera Conference continues online
column2: Weekly programs surrounding Latino/a literature, identities, race, and more, run through early November.

column1: Pandemic driving reductions won't reduce greenhouse gas emissions much
column2: Economists find commuting is the only driving category to remain diminished

column1: Celebrating a decade of support for UCR Guardian Scholars
column2: A decade ago, Tuppett Yates, a professor of psychology at the University of California, Riverside, launched the Guardian Scholars Program in the hopes of creating a support system for students who grew up in foster care.

column1: Confronting loss and loneliness in “If You Have to Go”
column2: Loneliness, while inherently isolating, is also a universal experience. This dichotomy lies at the heart of poet Katie Ford’s newest collection, “If You Have to Go.” Dominated by a crown of 39 sonnets — each linked by the repetition of the last line of a poem as the first line of the next — the book unfolds as a dreamlike narrative loosely threaded together by one solitary, longing voice.

column1: Why Venus rotates, slowly, despite sun’s powerful grip
column2: If not for the soupy, fast-moving atmosphere on Venus, Earth’s sister planet would likely not rotate. Instead, Venus would be locked in place, always facing the sun the way the same side of the moon always faces Earth.

column1: Game changer: New chemical keeps plants plump
column2: A UC Riverside-led team has created a chemical to help plants hold onto water, which could stem the tide of massive annual crop losses from drought and help farmers grow food despite a changing climate.  “Drought is the No. 1 cause, closely tied with flooding, of annual crop failures worldwide,” said Sean Cutler, a plant cell biology professor at UC Riverside, who led the research. “This chemical is an exciting new tool that could help farmers better manage crop performance when water levels are low.”

column1: A project about Zoom... Zoom... Zoom, on Zoom
column2: A pair of short films were a hit at the April 13 “Filmworks – Original Short Films” held at the University Theatre, drawing attention to a suite of pandemic monologues and songs professor Bella Merlin created along with students, entitled “20:20 Vision.” For the first time this week, the short film/music video “Zoom,” and other components of 20:20 Vision are publicly available on YouTube.

column1: UC Riverside to host 42nd-annual Writers Week
column2: Writers Week, California’s longest-running free literary event, will return to the University of California, Riverside, for its 42nd installment Feb. 4-5 and Feb. 11-16, 2019, featuring 22 writers across the two-week span.

column1: Brian Haynes to be appointed UCR Vice Chancellor for Student Affairs
column2: Administrator is currently head of Student Affairs at Cal State San Bernardino

column1: How to eat a poison butterfly
column2: In high enough concentrations, milkweed can kill a horse, or a human. To be able to eat this plant, monarchs evolved a set of unusual cellular mutations. New UC Riverside research shows the animals that prey on monarchs also evolved these same mutations.

column1: Personal stories on sexual abuse, self-worth, and academia
column2: Associate Professor Victoria Reyes published her new book, “Academic Outsider: Stories of Exclusion and Hope.”

column1: New method expands the world of small RNAs
column2: PANDORA sequencing method developed by UC Riverside-led team can detect once-undetectable small RNAs

column1: Parasitic worm venom evades human immune system
column2: It’s likely that billions of people are unaware they have been infected with parasitic worms. A UC Riverside scientist has won $1.8 million to try and understand why.  The National Institutes of Health granted an Outstanding Investigator Award to Adler Dillman, an assistant professor of parasitology, so he can shed light on the mystery of worm infections that escape detection by human immune systems.

column1: Family secret inspires new novel by UC Riverside’s Kate Anger
column2: A story about coming-of-age, betrayal, and revenge, ‘The Shinnery’ is inspired by the author’s family history and a trial that shook 1890s Texas.

column1: Join UCR faculty and alumni at the LA Times Festival of Books
column2: Attend panel discussions and book signings featuring UCR writers at the USC campus April 13-14.

column1: ‘In the Country of Women’ celebrates the ‘love of thousands’
column2: Straight’s new memoir, published Aug. 6, extols the strength and resiliency of six generations of women

column1: Author Susan Straight featured in Alta Asks Live
column2: Straight joined writer and critic Heather Scott Partington for a live chat about writing, teaching, and calling Riverside home

column1: UC Riverside-led project offers new opportunities to commemorate veterans
column2: Several resources, including a series of documentary vignettes, provides visitors numerous ways to enhance their own Veterans Day celebrations

column2: The 43rd annual Writers Week, California’s longest-running free literary event, is heading to UC Riverside, bringing a diverse array of emerging and established authors to the Inland Empire Feb. 10-14.

column2: California’s longest-running free literary festival is now accessible to audiences worldwide

column2: UC Riverside is testing whether a sesame seed-sized wasp can control a pest that could seriously damage California crops including wine, walnuts, and avocados.

column1: ‘I am the product of rape. Here’s why I support abortion rights’
column2: Victoria Reyes, an assistant professor of gender and sexuality studies at UCR, speaks from personal experience in this Q&A.

column2: UC Riverside climbed 37 places in the most recent Forbes magazine rankings, from No. 64 to No. 27.

column2: UC Riverside's episode on the Amazon Prime streaming series “The College Tour” is now live and viewable on YouTube.

column1: Reza Aslan and Rainn Wilson wrestle with life’s biggest questions on new podcast
column2: “Metaphysical Milkshake” sees the scholar and actor discuss weighty topics with contemporary thought leaders, bringing humor and insight to a new subject each week.

column1: Rise of oxygen on Earth: Initial estimates off by 100 million years
column2: New research shows the permanent rise of oxygen in our atmosphere, which set the stage for life as we know it, happened 100 million years later than previously thought. A team including UC Riverside found that oxygen fluctuated dramatically after its early appearance before becoming a permanent constituent of the atmosphere.

column1: Glass nanopore pulls DNA like spaghetti through a needle
column2: The purely electrical technique captures cell-free DNA from the surface of a sample

column1: ‘Forbidden City’ shines light on Mao Zedong’s dancing girls
column2: Vanessa Hua’s latest novel "Forbidden City" explores the little-known history and influence of the teenage revolutionaries in Chairman Mao’s inner circle

column2: Poetry collection captures the author's own life, as well as many of the golden state’s overlooked truths: genocide, environmental degradation, and climate change.

column1: Poetry and music collaborations from Katie Ford strike a chord with audiences

column2: UC Riverside is one the universities making it easier for new discoveries to benefit the public

column1: A new beat on life

column1: UC Riverside is No. 1 in Pell Grant performance
column2: A dive into Washington Monthly’s recent ranking of 393 four-year universities reveals an important success: UC Riverside is the No. 1 university in the nation for Pell Grant performance. The measure considers how many low-income students a university serves compared with statewide earnings. The Pell Grant is the largest federal grant program offered to undergraduates and is typically awarded to students from households earning less than $65,000 per year.

column1: Scientists to study how lungs respond to worm infections
column2: Research supported by five-year NIH grant may have relevance for COVID-19 patients

column1: Washington Monthly ranks UCR No. 28 public university
column2: In its 2021 ranking of top national universities, Washington Monthly magazine has named UC Riverside No. 28 among public universities in the U.S.  In the subcategory of social mobility, UCR was No. 29 among the 380 four-year universities ranked in Washington Monthly’s 2021 list. UCR’s social mobility ranking was No. 34 in 2020. In the category of research, UCR also climbed, from No. 65 in the nation in 2020, to No. 57 in 2021.

column1: Wall Street Journal rankings put UCR in top 50 publics
column2: UCR Riverside moved into the top 50 public universities in a college rankings system from The Wall Street Journal and Times Higher Education. With the 2022 WSJ/THE report, UCR has climbed 184 positions in the overall rankings in the past five years.

column1: UCR is among top 25 'best value' public universities
column2: UC Riverside was named among the top 25 public universities in a college rankings system from The Princeton Review . The Princeton Review rankings are based on “return on investment,” or ROI, that factors low tuition and/or generous financial aid, combined with “strong career prospects for graduates.”

column1: Research reveals why geography is central to product innovation
column2: UCR researcher and colleagues show that businesses in states with confluence of research universities, venture capital, and government funding innovate at 16-times higher rate when demand increases

column1: Magazine ranks UCR No. 4 for Pell Grant performance
column2: Washington Monthly magazine has ranked UC Riverside No. 4 among 444 universities nationwide in terms of its Pell Grant student performance. The accolade, released Monday as part of Washington Monthly’s 2022 college rankings, represents UCR’s excellence in several Pell performance categories that were factored. Those include:

column1: In new economic index, UCR is No. 18 nationally
column2: Anew measure of higher education excellence called the Economic Mobility Index, or EMI, ranks UCR No. 18 nationally. The ranking is from a non-profit think tank named Third Way, and aims to measure the role universities play in catalyzing the economy.

column1: Maria Hinojosa to deliver the 50th Hays Press-Enterprise Lecture
column2: The April 9 event will feature the executive producer of “Latino USA,” a Peabody Award-winning show aired on NPR.

column1: LA Times executive editor is Hays Lecture Series speaker
column2: Kevin Merida, executive editor of the Los Angeles Times, will be the speaker at the 54th Hays Press-Enterprise Lecture at UC Riverside. The May 9 lecture will be in person, on campus for the first time in three years. Merida, 66, took the helm of the largest newsgathering organization in the West in June 2021 and oversees the Times newsroom, as well as Times Community News and Los Angeles Times en Español.

column2: When it comes to mortality, U.S.-born individuals of immigrant descent fare much worse than their foreign-born counterparts — but why?

column2: NSF grant will support research on how fish coordinate different body parts to catch prey

column2: John Jennings discusses the challenge of transforming the beloved classic into a best-selling graphic novel.

column1: UCR, Riverside schools push back against pollution
column2: A grant recently awarded to the Riverside Unified School District and UC Riverside will provide a high school curriculum that addresses air quality, in a region that is among the worst polluters in the country.  The grant is for $1.19 million and is from the National Science Foundation, or NSF.

column1: Dena Plemmons: Research ethics are top of mind
column2: UCR is the first of two UC campuses to have a fully funded research ethics program.

column1: “Fictive Kin” questions how we view the everyday
column2: A new exhibition showcasing the photography of contemporary artists Sarah Conaway, Annette Kelm, and Kim Schoen will debut at the Culver Center of the Arts at UCR ARTSblock on Feb. 24. Much information in our daily lives is consumed through visual cues, like billboards blinking by on a highway, with little time to question authenticity. “Fictive Kin” invites viewers to consider the often-unconscious assumptions we make when looking at photos.

column1: Q&A with Eddie Comeaux
column2: UC Riverside Graduate School of Education professor Eddie Comeaux served as co-chair of a University of California-wide task force deciding the fate of SATs in the UC system.

column1: These inclusive practices help general education teachers foster positive relationships with children with autism
column2: Teachers make time to find students’ interests, celebrate talents, and have one-on-one time to form stronger relationships with students with autism, finds study

Brint has written articles and books on standardized testing and its role in higher education. He is especially interested in solving education inequalities associated with racial and social class gaps. brint@ucr.edu

column2: UCR research shows race evasiveness harms teacher educators and charts a path toward identifying and disrupting racism

column2: A gift from SchoolsFirst Federal Credit Union to UC Riverside School of Education is funding a program to get local education students into graduate or credential programs

column1: UCR researcher addresses incentive disparities in HIV research
column2: To encourage subjects to participate in clinical and behavioral HIV studies, researchers often offer incentives such as cash or gift cards. But such remuneration could distort the sampling and end up inadvertently hurting the research findings. Lured by the incentives, participants could easily conceal information about themselves to qualify. Or they could give false information about themselves in order to stay in the study.

column2: If you think you're not a "math person," you might want to consider why

column1: Winter quarter will be mostly remote again
column2: In communications sent Oct. 23 and Nov. 30, UCR laid out instructional plans for its winter quarter, which will look much like fall quarter. Fifty courses have been approved for in-class instruction in winter quarter. All will offer students the option of remote instruction.

column2: UC Riverside Chancellor Kim A. Wilcox announced today the appointment of Thomas M. Smith as interim provost and executive vice chancellor, pending approval by UC President Janet Napolitano.

column1: Pandemic hasn't deterred UCR applicants; new record is set
column2: Defying pandemic-influenced predictions and national trends, the University of California, Riverside has posted record freshman applications for fall 2021.   A total of 52,263 applications were received for the fall 2021 freshman class. That represents an increase over the previous record of 49,252 for fall 2020.

column1: Fall won't be just 'either-or'; it may also be 'both'
column2: Only a few weeks ago, it appeared UCR instructors had two choices for instruction in fall 2021: in-person, or remote. A group charged with preparing for fall instruction realized something was missing.

column2: UCR research may alleviate concerns about impact of drought on Amazonian trees, which play a critical role in regulating the global climate

column1: Understanding bacteria’s metabolism could improve biofuel production

column1: Making freshman calculus add up for more students

column2: Hackers look for vulnerabilities within computer systems, which are constructed for high performance to meet consumer demand. Tensions between systems administrators protecting the network, and those seeking to attack it, run high.

column1: Graduate School of Education changes name
column2: Effective Monday, Sept. 20, the Graduate School of Education will officially become the School of Education, or SOE. The new name will reflect the scope of the school’s research, community engagement, and academic programs, specifically the undergraduate degree program, which was approved in 2017 and now accounts for 60% of the school’s enrollment.  The simple name change was approved at the University of California-system level in August.

column1: Border surge's cause is more complicated than COVID-19
column2: The United States border has seen an increase in families — primarily men with their children — and most recently a surge in unaccompanied minors traveling north from Central America through Mexico. They are fleeing gang violence, high homicide rates, and lack of economic opportunities. In some cases, such as in Guatemala, even hunger. According to the Pew Research Center, the U.S. Border Patrol apprehended nearly 100,000 migrants in February; this after apprehensions had fallen to about 16,000 in April 2020.
