column2: The money comes from UC Berkeley’s Underground Scholars, via grants from the Andrew Mellon and Crankstart foundations to support the expansion of the Underground Scholars model UC-wide.

column1: UC Riverside joins new NSF center for the preservation of biological systems
column2: The grant is the campus’ first successful bid for an NSF Engineering Research Center

column1: Lasers can weld ceramics without a furnace
column2: Ultrafast pulsed lasers fuse ceramics under ambient conditions and use less than 50 watts of power

column1: Researchers find peptide that treats, prevents killer citrus disease
column2: New UC Riverside research affirms a unique peptide found in an Australian plant can destroy the No. 1 killer of citrus trees worldwide and help prevent infection.

column1: On safari at UC Riverside
column2: Wildlife experts explain why you won’t meet mountain lions in the Botanic Gardens

column1: Focus on the Future: Women's Volleyball
column2: While the UC Riverside women's volleyball team has a solid core of upperclassmen, it will be the seven new additions to the roster that could take the team to the next level in the Big West Conference. "Our freshmen are a really good class," head coach Michelle Patton-Coleman said. "They have a lot to learn when it comes to the system and the speed of the game. They just have to get in games and know what it is like to play at the Division I level." One of the freshmen the team will rely on is outside hitter Marissa Holt, whose physicality will help put balls away.

column1: Double bubbles pierce with less trouble
column2: Two optical cavitation bubbles penetrate soft materials better than one

column1: Why are plants green?
column2: UC Riverside-led research team’s model to explain photosynthesis lays out the next challenging phase of research on how green plants transform light energy into chemical energy

column1: Focus on the Future: Men's Soccer
column2: When a new crop of student-athletes report to camp for the first time, it can be difficult for them to blend in well with the veterans. That hasn't been the case for the UC Riverside men's soccer team. "My new teammates are really the ones that are helping us out by the way they have acclimated to the team's chemistry and our game plan so quickly," said senior forward Antonio Lokossou. The Highlanders come into the season with a 27-man roster that features five freshmen and six transfer students. For the 11 student-athletes, the veterans have already been a great guide.

column1: A warming world increases air pollution
column2: Climate change is warming the ocean, but it’s warming land faster and that’s really bad news for air quality

column1: Athletics Set to Induct 2018 Hall of Fame Class
column2: RIVERSIDE, Calif. – The UC Riverside Athletics Department is pleased to announce its 2018 Athletics Hall of Fame inductees. Scheduled to receive the highest honors during the induction ceremony on Nov. 16 at the Historic Mission Inn Hotel & Spa in downtown Riverside are Larry Cunningham (men's basketball), David Finley (baseball), Fred Morawczski (football), Melissa Sanchez (softball), and the 1982 baseball team.

column1: Former Highlanders Pitcher Joe Kelly Helps Red Sox Win World Series
column2: Walk into the UC Riverside Baseball Complex and you immediately notice framed jerseys on the walls of current and former Major League players. One that stood out a little more than the rest on Monday is of Red Sox reliever Joe Kelly. He won a World Series Championship with the Boston Red Sox Sunday night, playing a pivotal role in the team's run.

column1: Who is and who’s not receiving pandemic-related unemployment aid in Riverside County
column2: Non-Hispanic whites least likely to fall outside of unemployment insurance coverage

column1: 2018 Athletics Hall of Fame Inductee: David Finley
column2: RIVERSIDE, Calif.—David Finley has visited and played on his fair share of baseball diamonds. However, the one he played on at UC Riverside is still his favorite. "When I played at Riverside, our field was on campus. I've been on a million fields since then and our field is by far the best one I've ever played on," Finley said. "When I think of UC Riverside, I think about taking ground balls, taking batting practice and being able to see all of the palm trees and mountains in the distance."

column1: 2018 Athletics Hall of Fame Inductee: Melissa Sanchez
column2: RIVERSIDE, Calif.—When Melissa Sanchez saw the 951 area code pop up on her phone a few months ago, she had a feeling it was someone from UC Riverside. However, she wasn't expecting the news that awaited her. Sanchez, who graduated from UCR in 2006, would be inducted into the 2018 Athletics Hall of Fame. Sanchez, a standout on the softball team from 2003-06, is in the Highlanders' top-10 all-time for batting average, games played, hits, doubles, home runs, RBIs, slugging, and on-base percentage.

column1: Men's Soccer Wins First Big West Conference Championship
column2: RIVERSIDE, Calif.—The loud, raucous roars resonated throughout UCR Soccer Stadium Saturday, Nov. 10 as Daniel Castaneda belted the deciding penalty kick past UC Davis goalie Jon Laughlin, giving the Highlanders their first Big West Conference Championship in school history. The second the ball went past Laughlin to give UCR the win after a 4-2 decision in penalty kicks, fans stormed the field as the team began hugging and jumping up and down.

column1: 2018 Athletics Hall of Fame Inductee: Fred Morawczski
column2: RIVERSIDE, Calif.—It's been nearly 50 years since Fred Morawczski finished playing football at UC Riverside, but his memories are as fresh as ever. "The best thing was the comradery and really having a sense of purpose," Morawczski said. "I had great teammates and really inspiring coaches." Morawczski, who is a 2018 UC Riverside Athletics Hall of Fame inductee, holds the career rushing record with 1,035 yards, even though he only played on the team for two years (1968-69).

column1: 2018 Athletics Hall of Fame Inductee: 1982 Baseball Team
column2: RIVERSIDE, Calif.—It's a feeling very few people get to experience, but for the 1982 UC Riverside Men's Baseball team, each player is able to call themselves a National Champion. That achievement helped the team become one of the 2018 Athletics Hall of Fame inductees.

column1: 2018 Athletics Hall of Fame Inductee: Larry Cunningham
column2: RIVERSIDE, Calif.—When Larry Cunningham found out a few months ago via phone that he would be a 2018 UC Riverside Athletics Hall of Fame inductee, his first reaction was an unusual one. "I thought someone was prank calling me," Cunningham said with a laugh. "I had no idea. I wasn't expecting it. As they continued talking, I realized it was the truth. I was just so honored." Cunningham, who played basketball for the Highlanders from 2004-08, is still the program's all-time leading scorer, with 1,502 points.

column1: Malou De Kergret Takes on Leadership Role
column2: Forward Malou De Kergret is one-of-a-kind on the UC Riverside women's basketball team this season. She's the only senior. "Something is different about your senior year," De Kergret said. "All seniors from all sports feel it. You know it is your last year and you want to make a difference."

column1: Women's Volleyball Adds Former National Champion Andy Hein to Coaching Staff
column2: RIVERSIDE, Calif.- The UC Riverside women's volleyball team made a huge addition to its coaching staff on March 4 as the Highlanders announced the hiring of Assistant Coach Andrew Hein. The former national champion and Team USA medalist comes to Riverside with a lengthy coaching and player resume in Southern California.

column1: Back in Camp: Track and Field Excited for Competition to Begin
column2: Whether it's the men or women, indoor or outdoor, UC Riverside Track and Field director Nate Browne is excited for the year ahead. The track and field season officially begins on Friday in the Lumberjack Team Challenge. On the women's side, the team has a lot of fresh, new talent that will try to replace many difference makers who have graduated. "Our goal was to get people that could cover two if not three events well. We've had a steady fall and look to express that preparation in some great indoor competitions," said Browne.

column1: Back in Action: Softball Has Sights Set on Success
column2: RIVERSIDE, Calif.—After an incredibly successful and historical 2018 season for the UC Riverside Softball Team, the Highlanders have waited patiently to return to the diamond, flipping their calendars and preparing for an exciting 2019 campaign.  "We are so excited to get this season going," Head Coach Nikki Palmer said. "Each year we continue to climb up the competitive ladder and I know our team is ready to take on the challenge that this tough schedule is going to present."

column1: Back in Action: Baseball Optimistic About Season Ahead
column2: RIVERSIDE, Calif.—With a slew of new faces and a strong core of upperclassmen, the UC Riverside baseball team is optimistic about the season ahead. "People will enjoy watching the style of play we have," head coach Troy Percival said. "We've never had as much speed as we do right now. Our outfield speed is going to be incredible. You are going to see a lot of diving plays and guys who can defend."

column1: Arts patron and UCR supporter Henry Coil dies at 85
column2: Henry W. Coil Jr., a Riverside native and community booster whose construction firm and personal giving preserved historic buildings, built multiple schools and strengthened programs for young people and the arts, died October 3, 2018 at the age of 85.

column1: $10 sensor reduces brewers’ natural gas use
column2: $45,000 UC Riverside investment helps researchers win $1.5 million grant

column1: UCR Bioengineer Awarded Fulbright Grant
column2: A University of California, Riverside scholar has been awarded a Fulbright grant to conduct research at the University of Sao Paulo in Brazil for 2018-19.

column1: EPIC Small Business Development Center will help Inland Empire startups flourish
column2: Center opens April 3; will offer support to technology-focused entrepreneurs

column1: Global warming, El Niño could cause wetter winters, drier conditions in other months
column2: Research indicates warming ocean temperatures will intensify winter rainfall in California

column1: Scientists crack structure of enzyme complex linked to cancer
column2: UC Riverside-led study offers important information for understanding “de novo DNA methylation"

column1: Keto diet may not work for women
column2: Scientists from UC Riverside are studying how the popular keto and intermittent fasting diets work on a molecular level, and whether both sexes benefit from them equally.

column1: Climate change is worsening, but population control isn't the answer
column2: Jade S. Sasser's new book highlights contemporary population control’s consequences for poor women in the Global South

column1: Coastal ecosystems suffer from upriver hydroelectric dams
column2: A recent study demonstrates the widespread environmental consequences of large dam reservoirs in Mexico

column1: Researchers receive $1 million for project challenging long-standing paradigm in endocrinology
column2: W. M. Keck Foundation award supports UC Riverside research aimed at showing membrane transporters guide flow of steroid hormones into cells

column1: Mapping the first family tree for tropical forests
column2: An international team of researchers has unraveled the evolutionary history of the world’s tropical forests

column1: Measuring greenhouse gases on the go
column2: New mobile emissions van allows UCR researchers to track atmospheric emissions anytime, anywhere

column1: SoCal residents split on vaccine, not on presidency
column2: Southern Californians are on board with masks and willing to sacrifice dollars for health. Those are a couple samplings from the findings of a new survey conducted by UCR’s Center for Social Innovation and the Southern California News Group.

column1: Following rain, desert microbes exhale potent greenhouse gas
column2: New UC Riverside research shows how, after it rains, microbes in desert soil convert one form of pollution into another — laughing gas.

column1: Street-based sex workers perform emotional labor to build customer loyalty
column2: Study finds it is an ordinary service business and more like other types of sex work than previously documented

column1: Biologists decipher a key piece of the odor-detection puzzle in flies, mosquitoes
column2: UC Riverside basic discovery offers path to safer products to protect against disease-carrying mosquitoes, chemicals to control crop-damaging pests

column1: Men's Basketball Announces the Signing of Three Recruits
column2: The UC Riverside men's basketball team has announced that three phenomenal student-athletes will join its 2019 recruiting class. Daniel Mading, Oliver Hayes-Brown, and Akol Mawein have signed their National Letters of Intent to join the Highlander family. Daniel Mading Mading is a former four-star recruit that comes to Riverside from Neosho City College. The South Sudan native grew up in Perch, Austrailia and has been recruited by many programs this year.

column1: Natural mosquito repellent startup wins seed funding
column2: UC Riverside startup Sensorygen beats entrepreneurs from other University of California campuses

column1: Grant will cover childcare costs for student parents at UCR
column2: The University of California, Riverside’s Early Childhood Services center received a four-year grant from the United States Department of Education to provide low income undergraduate students with childcare assistance. The reauthorized $1.4 million grant will give these student parents a financial breather while they balance parenting and college life. Funding comes from the U.S. Department of Education’s Child Care Access Means Parents in School Program, or CCAMPIS, which came into effect on Oct. 1. In 2014 the center received a similar grant amount from CCAMPIS.

column1: Researchers to Target Mosquito Egg Production to Curtail Disease
column2: RIVERSIDE, Calif.

column1: Anxious about the election? Political Scientists explain why
column2: As American voters wrestle with record-setting anxiety leading up to Nov. 3, forthcoming UCR research says Democratic voters are feeling more angst.

column1: Researchers identify new approach for controlling dengue fever and Zika virus
column2: UC Riverside study uses gene-editing tool to disrupt serotonin receptor linked to egg production in Aedes aegypti mosquitoes

column1: Buzzkill?
column2: They say love is blind, but if you’re a queen honeybee it could mean true loss of sight.  New research finds male honeybees inject toxins during sex that cause temporary blindness. All sexual activity occurs during a brief early period in a honeybee’s life, during which males die and queens can live for many years without ever mating again.

column1: Scientists short-circuit maturity in insects, opening new paths to disease prevention
column2: New research from UC Riverside shows, contrary to previous scientific belief, a hormone required for sexual maturity in insects cannot travel across the blood-brain barrier unless aided by a transporter protein. The finding may soon allow scientists to prevent disease-spreading mosquitoes from maturing, or to boost reproduction in beneficial bumblebees.

column1: Studies identify new strategies for insect control
column2: Mosquitoes spread several diseases, such as malaria and dengue. In 2020 about 241 million cases of malaria occurred worldwide, with a few more million cases occurring in 2021.

column1: Sugar-poor diets wreak havoc on bumblebee queens’ health
column2: UC Riverside study shows that without adequate sugar, a bumblebee queen’s fat body, which functions like a human liver, does not correctly produce enzymes required for healthy metabolism and detoxification from pesticides.

column1: Flower faithful native bee makes a reliable pollinator
column2: Just like us, the humble sweat bee has a daily routine

column1: Men's Soccer celebrates 2018 season with chancellor
column2: Thursday morning, the UC Riverside Men's Soccer Team took a walk across campus to the office of University's Chancellor, Kim Wilcox, to be honored for a successful and historical 2018 season. The Highlanders piled into Wilcox's conference room with their Big West Tournament trophy in hand as each coach and student-athlete met with the Chancellor and received his applause for their accomplishments this past year.

column1: ‘Adventurous Music for Curious Ears’
column2: The 2021-22 Outpost Concert Series kicks off the five-concert season on Nov. 3.

column1: Parasite infestations revealed by tiny chicken backpacks
column2: Blood-feeding livestock mites can be detected with wearable sensor technology nicknamed “Fitbits for chickens.”

column1: Scientists unlock genetic secrets of wine growers’ worst enemy
column2: Following a decade-long effort, scientists have mapped out the genome of an aphid-like pest capable of decimating vineyards. In so doing, they have discovered how it spreads — and potentially how to stop it.

column1: Does urbanization homogenize regional biodiversity in native bees?
column2: First survey of California’s bees in 50 years will look for effects of habitat destruction

column1: Scientists developing new solutions for honeybee colony collapse
column2: The University of California, Riverside, is leading a new effort to stop and reverse a worldwide decline in honeybees, which threatens food security and prices.

column1: Cicada explosion mystifies insect experts
column2: Doug Yanega, senior scientist at UC Riverside’s Entomology Research Museum, discusses one of nature's unsolved mysteries: the 17-year life cycle of cicadas in the Eastern U.S.

column1: Hummingbirds can smell their way out of danger
column2: In less time than it takes to read this sentence, hummingbirds can catch a whiff of potential trouble. That’s the result of new UC Riverside research showing, contrary to popular belief, the tiny birds do have an active sense of smell.

column1: How can workers reap more benefits from retail development projects?
column2: Research from two UCR professors looks closely at the impacts of distribution centers like QVC’s Ontario outpost on working communities

column1: Study shows common insecticide is harmful in any amount
column2: A new UC Riverside study shows that a type of insecticide made for commercial plant nurseries is harmful to a typical bee even when applied well below the label rate.

column1: Rising temperatures overcook bumblebees’ brunch
column2: Bumblebees pollinate many of our favorite foods, but their own diet is being upset by climate change, according to a new UC Riverside study.

column1: Scientists fail to locate once-common CA bumble bees
column2: Several species of California bumble bees have gone missing in the first statewide census of the fuzzy pollinators in 40 years. If they can be found, a recent court ruling could help save them.

column1: Cousin of crop-killing bacteria mutating rapidly
column2: A bacterial species closely related to deadly citrus greening disease is rapidly evolving its ability to infect insect hosts, and possibly plants as well.

column1: When bees get a taste for dead things
column2: Typically, bees don’t eat meat. However, a species of stingless 'vulture' bee in the tropics has evolved the ability to do so, presumably due to intense competition for nectar. UC Riverside scientists find these bees' guts resemble those of hyenas and other carrion feeders.

column1: Genetic discovery could spell mosquitoes’ death knell
column2: A UC Riverside genetic discovery could turn disease-carrying mosquitoes into insect Peter Pans, preventing them from ever maturing or multiplying.

column1: The scent that could save California’s avocados
column2: UC Riverside scientists are on the hunt for a chemical that disrupts “evil” weevils’ mating and could prevent them from destroying California’s supply of avocados.

column1: Bee mite arrival in Hawaii causes pathogen changes in honeybee predators
column2: UC Riverside-led research, done on the Big Island, shows effects of mite introduction have cascaded through entire pathogen communities

column1: Chemical cocktail in skin summons disease-spreading mosquitoes
column2: A UC Riverside-led team discovered the exact chemical combination that causes Zika, dengue and yellow fever-spreading mosquitoes to locate and land on their victims.

column1: Report charts major growth for Inland Empire nonprofits
column2: Still, UC Riverside researchers warn that without action, the sector’s recent gains could be undone by COVID-19

column1: Outpost Concert Series: Music that elevates the senses
column2: Running Nov. 6 through April 2020, the series’ five programs will highlight music composed over the past 40 years.

column1: UCR earns Seal of Excelencia certification
column2: Excelencia in Education, the nation’s premier authority on efforts accelerating Latino student success in higher education, announced today UC Riverside has been certified with the Seal of Excelencia in 2021. The national announcement was made this morning by Excelencia in Education during a press conference at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington, D.C. James Kvaal, the U.S. Department of Education under secretary, delivered remarks. UCR is one of just 10 institutions nationwide to earn Seal of Excelencia certification this year.

column1: Nationwide project seeks to understand how brain exercises produce cognitive benefits
column2: How does memory training lead to cognitive benefits? Aaron Seitz, director of the Brain Game Center for mental fitness and well-being at the University of California, Riverside, has wrestled with this question for several years.

column1: 195 ways to help California’s painted ladies
column2: By documenting hundreds of new nectar plants for painted ladies, scientists have renewed hope these charismatic butterflies may prove resilient to climate change.

column1: Deafness trumps HIV for deaf people living with HIV
column2: UC Riverside-led study participants advocate for collection of more data on deaf individuals

column1: New center to study labor issues in the Inland Empire
column2: Inland Empire Labor and Community Research Center at UC Riverside is one of five UC centers meant to advance timely labor research.

column1: Report paints portrait of Inland Empire’s growing workforce
column2: The region’s job growth exceeds the statewide average, and efforts are underway to ensure more good jobs that allow families to make ends meet

column1: UCR professor selected as Sloan Research Fellow
column2: Sandra Kirtland Turner among 126 outstanding early-career researchers honored across eight fields

column1: $1.5 million gift creates Sean and Stella Harper Endowed Scholarship Fund
column2: Sean Harper is the first person to admit he wasn’t the most disciplined student when he came to UC Riverside as a biomedical sciences student four decades ago. “I was still 17 for my first few weeks at UCR,” Harper said. “I knew that I wanted to study medicine but I wasn’t the most organized or prepared student. I had a lot to learn and my time at Riverside was transformative in that regard.”

column1: Raising the bar through authentic research
column2: Boil the water, add the ingredients, stir.  The instructions given in undergraduate science labs can feel a bit like making ramen noodles. “Lab courses that accompany many large science undergraduate lectures often adopt a cookbook-type approach, where students follow a series of instructions in a stepwise process without really understanding why they’re doing what they’re doing,” said Marsha Ing, an associate professor of educational psychology in the University of California, Riverside’s Graduate School of Education.

column1: Mark Rubin, whose philanthropic efforts span UCR, dies at 84
column2: Mark Rubin, a Riverside-area property developer, Holocaust survivor, and ardent supporter of education and healthcare in the Inland Empire, died Saturday, February 13, 2021. He was 84.

column1: Building the future for UCR's School of Business
column2: Beverly Bailey knows a thing or two about building things.  As a student at Riverside City College, she helped her boyfriend Scott hang patio covers on the weekends. When she turned 20, she bought and ran a small café in Chino, putting her entrepreneurial spirit to the test as she worked some of the longest days of her life. Then she earned her real estate license, making a living helping people build their dream homes.

column1: Benefactor Esther Fincher Hays leaves a lasting legacy at UCR
column2: Esther Fincher Hays, an academic physician, community activist, and philanthropist who supported UC Riverside’s programs in medicine, engineering and music, died June 10, 2021 at her home in Riverside. She was 94 years old. Born in Lexington, Kentucky and raised in Ithaca, NY, Hays attend Cornell University, Cornell Medical School, and completed her internship and residency at New York Hospital. There she met Dr. Daniel M. Hays, whom she married in 1951. In 1954 they moved to Los Angeles, where they raised four children.

column1: UCR faculty member's book shares stories of teachers of color
column2: “What are you … on their side?” The comment was one of many snarky remarks white teachers made about interactions between a Latino colleague and his diverse student population. In the staff lounge at the Sacramento, Calif., public school, the same teachers called the students “monkeys bouncing off the walls” and “losers.” The Latino teacher pushed back. But he reached a point where it was so frustrating to be in the lounge that he stopped going.

column1: Do you act before you think or think before you act?
column2: UC Riverside psychologists’ experiments explain which choice rules daily life

column1: Beyond Brilliant: Katherine Maldonado
column2: Last summer, Katherine Maldonado, a first-generation graduate student at the University of California, Riverside, became one of 133 recipients nationally of a 2019 Ford Foundation Fellowship.  Maldonado, a UCLA graduate, is now working toward her doctorate in sociology, and her $72,000 Ford Foundation award will support her studies over three years. A Watts native and mother of three sons herself, she examines the experiences of formerly gang-involved women who are now mothers.

column1: Will the U.S. economy fall into recession in 2023? Only if the Fed intensifies current tightening policies
column2: The U.S. economy has little chance of falling into a recession this year or next unless the Federal Reserve raises interest rates more than they are currently projecting, according to a new forecast released yesterday at the 13th annual Inland Empire Economic Forecast Conference, hosted by the UC Riverside School of Business.

column1: Student Freedom Initiative adds UCR to its next cohort of member institutions
column2: Today, Student Freedom Initiative announced the next round of Minority Serving Institutions, or MSIs, that will participate in its program.  UC Riverside, ranked No. 1 in the U.S. for social mobility by U.S. News and World Report, was one of the universities selected.

column1: UCR School of Business awarded re-accreditation by distinguished AACSB international
column2: The UCR School of Business is the premier public business research institution in Inland Southern California and provides insights and resources that impact the development of the region

column1: UC Riverside Research in Brief
column2: How does climate change affect California’s mountain lakes? A team of researchers, including UCR’s James O. Sickman, a professor of hydrology, and Kevin Skeen, a research technician, has published a study in Limnology and Oceanography Letters showing that spring snowpack best predicts summer warming in small Sierra Nevada lakes.

column1: Parasitic plants conspire to keep hosts alive
column2: The plant that encourages kissing at Christmas is in fact a parasite, and new research reveals mistletoe has an unusual feeding strategy. When two mistletoes invade the same tree, they increase photosynthesis to get the nutrients they need, essentially sharing the tree and causing it less harm.

column1: Board of trustees lead Beyond Brilliant by example
column2: There’s more to university life than filling out admissions forms, showing up for classes, and studying for tests. Erik Anderson, an Inland Empire business leader and philanthropist, wants all students at the University of California, Riverside to take advantage of the world-class education they are being offered. And he’s pledging $5 million to help make that happen.

column1: UC Riverside launches student-centered Beyond Brilliant
column2: No student should have to choose between buying books or food. Or pass up an internship opportunity because they can’t afford gas. Or drop out of school to ease the financial burden on their family. But these choices are a reality for many students who attend the University of California, Riverside.

column1: Endowed gift will broaden the horizon for UCR students
column2: A $2 million gift from the Pollitt family will fund scholarships that support study abroad opportunities.

column1: Art Riggs remembered for pioneering research on diabetes, arthritis and cancer
column2: UC Riverside alumnus and friend Arthur D. (Art) Riggs, a pioneering researcher and expert in diabetes who helped launch the biotechnology industry, died March 23, 2022. He was 82.

column1: Lifelong UCR advocate Charlie Field dies
column2: Charles “Charlie” Field, an attorney, judge, and community leader who was among UC Riverside’s first graduates, died Oct. 29. He was 85 years old.

column1: Appreciation for library automation had roots in Vietnam War
column2: On hot and steamy days in Saigon, Vietnam, there was only one place for an enlisted man to cool off for a while. “That place was the library,” said UC Riverside alumna Ann Kelsey, who served as a civilian librarian for the U.S. Army from 1969-70. “The libraries were air conditioned because of the books, not the people, though. If they weren’t, the books would mold in two days.”

column1: UC Riverside admits most California freshmen among UCs
column2: UC Riverside has admitted a record number of freshmen for fall 2022 with a total of 37,262 admits — an increase of 2,591 students from the previous year, according to data released August 10 by the University of California.

column1: Late UCR professor honored through endowed award
column2: Tom Morton, a professor emeritus of chemistry at the University of California, Riverside, died March 3, 2020. He is remembered as a global citizen and scientist who embraced foreign languages and cultures, demonstrated a cross-disciplinary passion for scientific research, and who showed concern for the environment.

column1: New Vice Provost & Dean of Graduate Studies named
column2: Lidia Kos has been named UC Riverside’s next vice provost & dean of graduate studies, or VPDGS, effective July 15, 2023.

column1: Join us for UCR’s 2022 Homecoming
column2: UC Riverside alumni are invited back to campus for one of the biggest Homecoming celebrations in the university's history. Set for November 18 and 19, the event will celebrate everything UCR — past, present, and future.

column1: Five new trustees appointed to UCR Foundation board
column2: The UCR Foundation Board of Trustees has welcomed a new chair and five new members, all of whom began their two-year terms July 1.   The 40-member volunteer Board of Trustees oversees UCR’s affiliated foundation, receiving and managing the investment of a $260.2 million endowment as of May 31 that supports the long-term strength of UCR’s research programs, colleges, and scholarship funds. Trustees advocate for UCR and advance its mission by seeking and securing private support for its programs.

column1: Scholarship helps students chart course for science-to-policy careers
column2: When six lifelong friends gathered in 2018 for a reunion in California’s Anza-Borrego State Park, they didn’t sit around the campfire telling spooky stories. Instead, they brainstormed ways they could help students at the University of California, Riverside.

column1: New Vice Provost & Dean of Undergraduate Education named
column2: Louie Rodríguez has been named UC Riverside’s next vice provost and dean of undergraduate education (VPDUE), effective April 1.

column1: University of Maryland scholar is UCR’s next CHASS dean
column2: Daryle Williams is a historian who co-directs the online database Enslaved.org.

column1: Soledad O’Brien to deliver Hays Press-Enterprise Lecture
column2: Award-winning news anchor, entrepreneur, and diversity advocate will share her life stories during the 53rd annual lecture

column1: Vaccine exemption process detailed
column2: This past week, UCR announced an Aug. 16 deadline for UC Riverside employees and students to upload vaccination records for fall 2021. The message was a follow-up to the UC system’s announcement of a SARS-CoV-2 Vaccination Program that would require vaccinations for employees and students to be on campus for fall 2021.

column1: What UC Riverside scientists have to say about vaccines, variants, and antibodies
column2: Immunity generated by vaccination is better than immunity from an actual infection, says an expert

column1: This is the dawning of the age of the vaccine passport
column2: The vaccine passport is coming.

column1: O my, here’s Omicron
column2: UC Riverside experts share their thoughts on the new COVID-19 variant

column1: Student raises funds on Twitter to buy masks for campus
column2: There's the fear of catching COVID-19, and then there's the anxiety that comes with buying the right mask.

column1: Public health expert says influencers should step back
column2: UC Riverside public health expert Richard Carpiano weighs in on ethical matters for vaccine distribution.

column1: Too much hype, too soon?
column2: The news arrived Monday that the world has been awaiting since spring: a vaccine has been developed that shows a high degree of efficacy in late-stage trials: 90%. That puts it in the company of effective vaccines such as for measles, and well beyond what the medical community hoped for in efficacy. Among UCR scientists, as everywhere, the news of the vaccine developed by the drugmakers Pfizer and BioNTech was welcomed.

column1: Experts weigh in on whether COVID-19 is here to stay
column2: COVID-19 is far from beaten. Vaccines may not be the ultimate panacea to haul us out of the pandemic crisis. In the future, will outbreaks of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, arrive in waves every winter? Might COVID-19 never go away? Experts at the University of California, Riverside, weigh in.

column1: Nanofiber filter improves rural water treatment
column2: An electrospun nanofiber uniquely suited to removing nitrogen and phosphorous could help prevent nitrate contamination of drinking water in small, rural communities most at risk

column1: UC Riverside research could eventually lead to advances in pulmonary healthcare
column2: Scientists are just beginning to understand the mechanics of the lung

column1: Crimped or straight? Lung fiber shape influences elasticity
column2: The shape and architecture of collagen and elastin fibers can improve our understanding of lung diseases, including the one associated with vaping

column1: Hope for the infected
column2: Though no proven treatment for COVID-19 currently exists, UC Riverside virologist Juliet Morrison feels there’s a good chance one will emerge. Morrison, an assistant professor in the Department of Microbiology & Plant Pathology, investigates the science behind promising avenues for new antiviral therapies. She explains what those are and weighs in on drugs being tested.

column1: Salton Sea dust triggers lung inflammation
column2: UC Riverside study has health implications for people living around California’s largest lake

column1: Friends remember lifelong UC Riverside advocate Bill DeWolfe
column2: William “Bill” DeWolfe, 84, a prominent Riverside attorney and philanthropist who was one of UC Riverside’s earliest graduates and an ardent advocate of the university for the rest of his life, died April 16, 2020.

column1: Managing earthquakes triggered by oil production
column2: A team of scientists has developed an approach to disposing wastewater that reduces the danger of triggering an earthquake.

column1: ‘She Kills Monsters’ will feature ‘old school theatre magic’
column2: COVID-19 has forced the theater team to be more resourceful while producing a virtual show from home.

column1: UC Riverside freshman builds computers for high school students in need
column2: Computer science student helps ensure Covid-19 pandemic won’t hinder academic success in his community

column1: UC psychologists devise free test for measuring intelligence
column2: Raven’s Advanced Progressive Matrices, or APM, is a widely used standardized test to measure reasoning ability, often administered to undergraduate students. One drawback, however, is that the test, which has been in use for about 80 years, takes 40 to 60 minutes to complete. Another is that the test kit and answer sheets can cost hundreds of dollars, this amount increasing with more people taking the test.

column1: What's driving governors' lockdown decisions?
column2: As debate and protests about lockdowns and opening up flare up across the nation, experts are considering why governors decided to lockdown states in the first place.

column1: Come say ‘barn voyage’ to beloved eatery before its renovation
column2: The Barn will close June 14 for an 18-month renovation

column1: The vibrating universe: Making astronomy accessible to the deaf
column2: UC Riverside astronomers develop educational workshop converting astronomical phenomena into vibrations that can be felt rather than heard

column1: Immigrant Asian American women may be at higher risk for breast cancer
column2: Research highlights differences in risk among Asian American women who immigrated versus their U.S.-born counterparts

column1: Study finds electronic cigarettes damage brain stem cells
column2: A research team at the University of California, Riverside, has found that electronic cigarettes, often targeted to youth and pregnant women, produce a stress response in neural stem cells, which are critical cells in the brain. Present throughout life, stem cells become specialized cells with more specific functions, such as brain cells, blood cells, or bone. Far more sensitive to stress than the specialized cells they become, stem cells provide a model to study exposure to toxicants, such as cigarette smoke.

column1: UCR-led analysis seeks online advertising protocols for data transparency, consumer privacy, and brand safety
column2: Several Internet business experts see a technology that has made cryptocurrencies possible as a panacea to today’s online advertising accountability woes that stem from ad-tech giants hoarding the ad engagement data in their walled gardens.

column1: Carbon monoxide detectors could warn of extraterrestrial life
column2: For some distant worlds, carbon monoxide may actually be compatible with a robust microbial biosphere

column1: Research to focus on small molecule that can help fight breast cancer
column2: UC Riverside and City of Hope awarded Department of Defense grants for the collaborative project

column1: Physicists’ finding could revolutionize information transmission
column2: UC Riverside-led team identifies dark trions as the next carrier of quantum information

column1: Impact of HPV vaccination mandates on social inequalities
column2: Policy has limited impact on vaccine uptake because of individual decision making, study finds

column1: Harmful metals found in vapors from tank-style electronic cigarettes
column2: UC Riverside study analyzed six popular e-cigarette tanks and their atomizers

column1: How associative fear memory is formed in the brain
column2: UC Riverside mouse study provides insights into how pathological fear memory in PTSD could be suppressed

column1: Astronomers discover unusual monster galaxy in the very early universe
column2: XMM-2599 lived fast and died young, says UC Riverside-led international team

column1: Understanding a gene’s role in inflammatory bowel disease
column2: UC Riverside mouse study will identify mechanisms the gene PTPN2 uses to affect gut cells

column1: Study gauges social responsibility in slowing COVID-19 spread
column2: Researchers conducted focus groups of UC Riverside faculty, staff, and students

column1: Policymakers are short shrifting the creative economy
column2: COVID-19 health mandates disproportionally affect arts and culture businesses

column1: Navigating the $1.9 trillion stimulus
column2: March 8, President Biden was set to sign into law the American Rescue Plan, a $1.9 trillion economic stimulus that will provide $1,400 checks to millions of low- and middle-income Americans, new child tax benefits, and extend unemployment payments. It also includes a restaurant rescue fund, money for reopening schools, and funding for state and local governments, among other items. As many among us await stimulus checks, we asked Jana Grittersova, a UCR economist and associate professor of political science, to weigh in on the implications of the stimulus.

column1: Female presidents are held to higher standards than males
column2: An analysis of presidential approval ratings reveals truths about gender biases

column1: California does not need to choose between post-pandemic economic growth and reducing carbon emissions
column2: Surprisingly, environmental leader California has a smaller ‘green economy’ than the average U.S. state and would need to add many thousands of environmentally friendly jobs to catch up. The good news is it’s on track to do just that, according to a new analysis released today by the UCR School of Business Center for Economic Forecasting and Development.

column1: AAPI Data releases mapping tool for Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders
column2: Ahead of census, UCR-based research initiative offers resource to better understand fastest-growing racial groups in U.S.

column2: The SoCal Policy Forum platform is a collaboration between UCR and Southern California News Group

column2: Study pinpoints concerns about race and immigration — not economic ones — as likely determinants of vote switching

column2: Study highlights potential for populist leaders to undermine democracy.

column2: UC Riverside expands its presence in California’s capital

column1: Political scientist’s book takes honest look at sanctuary cities
column2: In his new book, Loren Collingwood traces the history of — and attitudes toward — contemporary U.S. sanctuary policies

column2: Mark Sebarrotin said UCR was his shot at the California dream; now, he wants to help others achieve their dream, too.

column2: Political scientist Kim Yi Dionne explains why responses to COVID-19 reveal a failure to learn from history

column2: In a two-county region at risk of an undercount, grassroots momentum has grown to ensure participation in the 2020 census

column2: Today’s humans share genes with 555-million-year-old oceanic creatures missing heads.

column1: Experts on Diversity and the Oscars
column2: Diversity and the Oscars The 93rd Academy Awards are scheduled for Sunday, April 25, 2021. Experts from the University of California, Riverside are available to discuss various Academy Awards topics, including diversity, acting, gender, culture, and more.  For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu

column1: 1,700-year-old spider monkey remains discovered in Teotihuacán, Mexico
column2: The complete skeletal remains of a spider monkey — seen as an exotic curiosity in pre-Hispanic Mexico — grants researchers new evidence regarding social-political ties between two ancient powerhouses: Teotihuacán and Maya Indigenous rulers.

column1: From UCR’s garden to students’ tables
column2: UCR’s community garden delivers fresh fruit and vegetables to students who remain on campus.

column1: An ancient Maya ambassador’s bones show a life of privilege and hardship
column2: Ajpach’ Waal forged an alliance between two dynasties but died in obscurity

column1: Top-performing soil microbes could be key to sustainable agriculture
column2: UCR research will help agronomists breed plants that attract their own growth-promoting microbes

column1: How giant-faced owls snag voles hidden in snow
column2: Great gray owls’ physical features, especially parts of their wings and face, help them correct for sonic distortions caused by snow, enabling them to find moving food with astonishing accuracy, according to a new UC Riverside study.

column1: Why weren’t New World rabbits domesticated?
column2: Archaeologists find the answer in rabbit social behavior

column2: UCR bioarchaeologist Sara Becker plans to use the cutting-edge technique to document traditional labors of indigenous Andean people

column2: UCR geneticist Norman Ellstrand lent his scientific expertise to a musical romantic comedy centered around genetically modified rice

column1: UCR team creates “quantum composites” for various electrical and optical innovations
column2: UCR team has shown in the laboratory the unique and practical function of newly created materials, which they called quantum composites, that may advance electrical, optical, and computer technologies.

column1: Monuments that matter
column2: Paper urges archaeologists and historians to work closely with people who are grappling with racism in public monuments

column1: Modern activities follow the contours of ancient Teotihuacan
column2: Lidar mapping study reveals vast landscape modifications that still influence construction and farming

column1: High-speed videos capture how kangaroo rat escapes rattlesnake attack
column2: Bipedalism may have been favored in kangaroo rats to avoid ambush predators like vipers and owls, says UC Riverside biologist

column1: Ancestor of all animals identified in Australian fossils
column2: A wormlike creature that lived more than 555 million years ago is the earliest bilaterian

column1: Study finds natural selection favors cheaters
column2: UC Riverside research focused on interaction between nitrogen-fixing bacteria and their hosts

column1: How do worms develop their gut?
column2: The pandemic helped a husband-and-wife team at UC Riverside solve the mystery

column1: Tiny particle, big payoff
column2: UC Riverside scientists have solved a 20-year-old genetics puzzle that could result in ways to protect wheat, barley, and other crops from a devastating infection.  Ayala Rao, professor of plant pathology and microbiology, has been studying Brome Mosaic virus for decades. Unlike some viruses, the genetic material of this virus is divided into three particles that until now were impossible to tell apart.

column1: Some domesticated plants ignore beneficial soil microbes
column2: Domestication yielded bigger crops often at the expense of plant microbiomes

column1: Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering welcomes 17 new faculty
column2: This year, UC Riverside’s Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering (BCOE) welcomed 17 new faculty members, bringing its total faculty cohort to 129. Among the additions are the new engineering dean, a distinguished engineering professor, three provost diversity fellows, a Fulbright Scholar, a National Science Foundation (NSF) CAREER awardee, and two assistant research engineers.

column1: Biologists unravel tangled mystery of plant cell growth
column2: When cells don’t divide into proper copies of themselves, living things fail to grow as they should. For the first time, scientists now understand how a protein called TANGLED1 can lead to accurate cell division in plants.

column1: Bioengineering-led Neuroengineering Symposium brings more than 80 academic experts to share their advancement and build partnerships
column2: UCR’s Department of Bioengineering led the campus’ first Computational Neuroimaging and Neuroengineering Symposium (CNNS) in November. The symposium brought together more than 80 cognitive neuroscientists, computational psychologists, bioengineers and neuroengineers, electrical and computer engineers, and computer scientists to discuss new advances and results in the fast-growing field.

column1: Bioengineering to host an open house of its new Pediatric Rehabilitation Technology Lab showcasing advancements in pediatric assistive devices
column2: The ability to move independently permits us to examine the world around us. Children born with motor impairments face unique challenges to learn about their environment and develop cognitively and socially through locomotion.  Innovative research in pediatric rehabilitative technologies allow children with these disabilities to interact with and explore their world in a way previously thought to be impossible.

column1: CE-CERT Director appointed to U.S Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Committee
column2: Matthew J. Barth, UC Riverside College of Engineering - Center for Environmental Research and Technology Director and Yeager Families Chair, was recently appointed to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency’s Mobile Sources Technical Review Subcommittee (MSTRS) of the Clean Air Act Advisory Committee (CAAAC).

column1: Two ECE faculty on most highly cited list
column2: Two electrical and computer engineering (ECE) faculty at the University of California, Riverside have been named to the 2018 Highly Cited Researchers list compiled by Clarivate Analytics, which was previously part of the Thomson Reuters.

column1: New! Engineering Transfer Student Center to Open
column2: New school. New classes. New study groups. The transition from a community college to a four-year institution can be difficult but the opening of a new transfer student center at UCR’s Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering will help prepare transfer students as they begin the next step in their academic careers. The center, located in Winston Chung Hall, will officially open during a ceremony held on January 8, 2019 from 1 p.m.

column1: Four Engineering Professors Named as Fellows
column2: This year, four UCR Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering professors were named Fellows in recognition to their contributions and extraordinary achievements to advancing science.

column1: UCR mechanical engineering professor receives award to quantify roadside pollutants
column2: Near-road air quality continues to be an important issue for transportation agencies. Invisible plumes of dirty air from cars and trucks on roadways spread to surrounding neighborhoods increasing residents’ risk of cancer, asthma, heart disease, and other illnesses.

column1: UCR wins $10 million to develop AI for sustainable agriculture
column2: The University of California, Riverside, has won a $10 million grant to develop artificial intelligence that will increase the environmental and economic stability of agriculture in the Western U.S.

column1: Integrating acquisition and analysis in AI systems
column2: UCR engineering professors receive $1.2M Navy grant to make artificial intelligent (AI) systems smarter

column1: Commencement 2022 to be in person and on campus
column2: UC Riverside’s class of 2022 will celebrate the milestone of receiving their bachelor's, master's, and doctoral degrees in person and on campus. In early June, the campus will finally welcome graduating Highlanders to the commencement stage, where their friends, families, and fans can cheer them on as they cross the stage in their statement caps, crisp gowns, and commemorative sashes/stoles. Noteworthy details:

column1: Researchers warn of tick-borne disease babesiosis
column2: UC Riverside and Yale University team sequences and mines genome of the pathogen Babesia duncani

column1: For UC Riverside Bioengineering Professor Immune System Research was Personal
column2: Dimitrios Morikis, UC Riverside Professor of Bioengineering, passed away May 27, 2019. Professor Morikis is well known for his work in immunophysics and immunoengineering, where he used physics and engineering approaches to understand molecular mechanisms of immunology, develop disease models, and design new drugs and molecular sensors for autoimmune and inflammatory diseases.

column1: Hot or cold, venomous vipers still quick to strike
column2: Most reptiles move slower when temperatures drop, but venomous rattlesnakes appear to be an exception. The cold affects them, but not as much as scientists expected.

column1: Vaping lung injury symptoms have been reported online for at least seven years
column2: UC Riverside research used internet data mining to monitor health effects reported by electronic cigarette users over time

column1: Salton Sea aerosol exposure triggers unique and mysterious pulmonary response
column2: UC Riverside mouse study suggests inflammation could play key role in progression to asthma

column1: UC Riverside-led research predicted the pandemic economic recession
column2: “The reality of 2020 hits us in the face and I have never been so prescient in my academic research as with this line of work.”

column1: Pandemic gun-buying binge crosses party lines
column2: A fear for health and safety has driven a record number of American gun sales

column1: A Highlander DREAMer's dilemma
column2: Gabriela Martinez is nervous about her trip to Washington D.C. Not because she’s going to be in the same building as the President of the United States. Nah, it isn't that. She’s nervous because this trip to the 2023 State of the Union, or SOTU, is the same week as her econ midterm.

column1: Engineering Commencement Speakers Announced
column2: David Tsai, this year’s engineering keynote speaker for the Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering (BCOE), will follow in his father’s footsteps to inspire tomorrow’s engineers while Crysthal Alvarez, the first engineer in her family, will address her fellow graduates as the student speaker.

column1: Teacher incentive programs can improve student achievement
column2: Programs that combine group and individual rewards can have good results and be cost-effective

column1: Students have innovative, cool ways to nap, relax, and study
column2: Nap pods, hydro massage chairs, and study cubbies on campus.

column1: Back to School: UCR Welcome Week 2022
column2: All UCR Highlanders are invited to celebrate the start of our 2022-23 academic year with a bunch of fun and informative events hosted by various campus partners. This is a great time to discover new departments, reconnect with familiar programs, and add friends to your list of followers and followees.  As thanks to students who are joining the fun, University Communications is hosting a giveaway!

column1: What’s behind the Trump administration’s antitrust challenge to the AT&T-Time Warner merger?
column2: Attorney-led seminar will examine the Department of Justice's civil lawsuit and its implications in advance of the trial's March 20 kickoff

column1: UCR freshmen admissions for fall 2020 up 17%
column2: UCR admissions up 17% for fall 2020, with gains among underrepresented, first-generation, and low-income students.

column1: Demolition makes way for student housing expansion
column2: The first of more than 150 buildings was claimed by a wrecker on Monday, July 22, at a shuttered housing complex that will become the site of a massive student housing expansion at UC Riverside.  The razing of the 50-acre, World War II-era housing complex that came to be known as Canyon Crest Family Student Housing began on July 22 with a small bungalow, with the first blows struck around 10:15 a.m.

column1: Experts on Black Lives Matter
column2: For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu.  Michelle C. Burroughs: director of community engagement and outreach for the Center for Healthy Communities. Burroughs is involved with the CHC’s engagement with the community focusing on the Black Lives Matter movement as well as social inequities. She is also a member of Chancellor Kim A. Wilcox’s Campus Safety Taskforce and the School of Medicine Diversity Committee.

column1: Unfolding Black history at UCR
column2: UCR has more than 4,400 degreed Black alumni, and is nationally recognized for having one of the smallest achievement gaps in the country.

column1: A winding road to studying autism
column2: Yasamin Bolourian pursued a doctorate in special education due to a passion for helping families.

column1: Here are the many ways UCR is helping students right now
column2: A list of available resources during this time of uncertainty.

column1: UCR student housing part of major expansion
column2: On a sunny morning at the north end of UC Riverside, bulldozers and dump trucks are busily grading dirt while construction crews put together a frame foundation for the campus’ newest housing and dining complex.

column1: How COVID-19 is affecting the global supply chain
column2: One of the most visible impacts of the coronavirus pandemic has been the strain on the global supply chain, with consumers noticing certain goods are harder to find at their local store. Danko Turcic, an associate professor of operations and supply chain management at UC Riverside’s School of Business, said the current environment is causing “previously unseen disruptions in both supply and demand.”

column1: Calling all Highlanders
column2: UC Riverside is encouraging its estimated 120,000 graduates to take part in the campus’ first-ever Alumni Roll Call. Starting Feb. 1, all alumni are being asked to fill out an online form that takes about 10 minutes to complete. The Roll Call is UCR’s version of a census, seeking updated contact information and asking questions about what events, activities, career resources, and volunteer opportunities appeal to alumni.

column1: Study: Aggressive lockdowns need to last more than six weeks to contain COVID-19
column2: People around the world are wondering how long COVID-restrictions have to last in order to curtail the pandemic.

column1: UCR offering webinars with campus tour guides
column2: Every spring, hundreds of prospective college students flock to UC Riverside for a tour of the campus to help them decide where to go that fall. With on-campus tours no longer possible, UCR is offering an online alternative. Last month, its team of student tour guides began offering Zoom meetings for high school and transfer students wanting to know more about the campus.

column1: If dogs could talk
column2: New research suggests our relationships with pit bulls shed light on the ways we reproduce social inequality

column1: UCR Citrus Gifts expands online with citrus and honey-infused marmalades, soaps, and more
column2: The fruits of UC Riverside’s research are even easier to enjoy with the Citrus Gifts collection expanding its line of products and making them available online. The collection, featuring marmalades and olive oils from citrus and bee research, have been sold in campus stores for about six years. In June, the campus began selling them online to expand their availability to the wider campus community and alumni. “This idea of creating this very unique UCR gift item is a way to take a piece of UCR home with you,” said Leslie Gerretse, senior manager for Hospitality Services.

column1: Queer lessons for straight couples
column2: Book shows how heterosexuals can learn from LGBT people to have better relationships

column1: Want to save shelter animals? Fight for social justice
column2: Humane communities would endorse animal-friendly affordable housing, living wages, and recognize the importance of human-animal bonds

column1: UCR begins construction of new Student Health and Counseling Center
column2: UC Riverside will begin construction this week on a Student Health and Counseling Center that will bring together health and wellness services at an accessible, modern facility. A groundbreaking ceremony will be held Friday, Feb. 18 for the planned two-story building located on the western portion of Parking Lot 21, south of Linden Street, between Aberdeen Drive and Pentland Way. Construction is anticipated to take over a year with the center opening to students by May 2023.

column1: Coronavirus lab and testing in place for fall quarter
column2: As the fall quarter begins, UC Riverside has a new diagnostic lab operating on campus that will rapidly process samples from students and employees as part of an ongoing coronavirus testing program. The lab, located at the Multidisciplinary Research Building, or MRB, tested its first sample in August and opened in early September.  The result of months of collaboration between several campus groups, the lab allows UCR to conduct its own independent testing of the campus community at a rate of about 600 samples a day. Results are processed within 24 hours.

column1: UCR among top 1% of world universities
column2: UC Riverside retains its place among the top 1% of universities, according to the World University Rankings. The campus ranked No. 242 in the 2021-22 list of the top 2,000 out of 19,788 institutions worldwide. UCR was named No. 82 nationally and in the top 50 public institutions in the US.

column1: Campus sees drop in COVID-19 cases while vaccination rates rise
column2: Since mid-April, UC Riverside has had only a handful of positive COVID-19 cases, continuing a rapid decline that began in January. Campus leaders involved in COVID-19 prevention efforts credit the low positivity rate to proactive efforts including the creation of a homegrown diagnostic lab, regular testing of students, and continuous messaging about the importance of social distancing and wearing face coverings. From September through mid-April, the campus conducted nearly 29,000 tests on campus with a positivity rate of 0.41%.

column1: Classroom technology on the RISE
column2: UC Riverside is getting ready for new modes of instruction this fall as it unveils classrooms equipped with state-of-the-art video and audio technology. The program, called Rooms for Increasing Student Engagement, or RISE, will feature classrooms that allow for both in-person and remote options for the same class. The campus is planning for a return to mostly in-person instruction this fall.

column1: Campus housing has changed - a lot - while you were away
column2: As students show up for move-in day at UC Riverside, they are arriving to a campus that –from a housing perspective – is reinvented from the pre-pandemic campus of two Septembers ago. Two residential communities – Dundee Residence Hall and the North District Apartments – are open for students, significantly alleviating the space crunch UC Riverside has faced since its student population began rocketing in the 2000s. UCR has more than doubled its population of 20 years ago, and is projected to have 35,000 students by 2035.

column1: UCR among top 1.3% of world institutions
column2: UC Riverside ranked in the top 1.3% of universities worldwide in the 2022-23 Center for World University Rankings, released Monday, April 25. The campus ranked No. 249 out of 19,788 institutions. Nationally, UCR landed at No. 81. The rankings are published by the Center for World University Rankings, a consultancy based in the United Arab Emirates. Institutions are evaluated on four key factors: education, employability, faculty, and research.

column1: Non-sworn, unarmed safety responders to join UCR’s Police Department
column2: UC Riverside plans to implement new measures this fall that reflect major changes in how it approaches campus safety. They include a tiered-approach in which the UC Riverside Police Department will add a new category of non-sworn, unarmed safety personnel to respond to calls. Another addition will be behavioral health specialists trained to deescalate situations. UCR is on track to be among the first UC campuses to implement such changes.

column1: Regents approve plans for new School of Business building
column2: The Regents of the University of California have approved construction plans for a new UC Riverside School of Business building that will provide more instructional and administrative space to meet growing enrollment demand. The vote, which took place July 20, allows the campus to move forward with construction this fall. The new building is expected to be completed by fall 2024.

column1: UCR ranked No. 23 among best value colleges in new college guide
column2: UC Riverside is ranked high for financial aid, making an impact, and value in the Princeton Review’s “Best 388 Colleges for 2023.” The lists are based on the Princeton Review’s survey of 160,000 students attending the 388 colleges and universities profiled. They appear in the 2023 edition of the annual college guide, which will be released Aug. 23.

column1: UCR No. 9 among public universities for sustainability
column2: UC Riverside is ranked No. 9 among public universities in the Princeton Review’s Guide to Green Colleges. The campus was No. 27 on the overall list of Top 50 Green Colleges, released Oct. 25. The annual list recognizes institutions for superb sustainability practices, strong foundations in sustainability education, and healthy quality of life for students on campus.

column1: School of Business launches new actuarial science degree program
column2: UC Riverside’s School of Business is now offering a degree in actuarial science, providing a direct path for students seeking careers in finance and insurance. Actuarial science is a discipline that involves assessing financial risks using mathematical and statistical methods. Most who study it go on to work in high-paying positions in finance and insurance.

column1: UCR explores collaboration with China’s top educations and entrepreneurs
column2: This spring, a University of California, Riverside delegation traveled 6,698 miles west to Guangzhou, Guangdong, and Anhui Province in eastern China to strengthen UCR’s relationships with the region’s top educators, researchers, and government officials. Across the Pacific Ocean, Chancellor Kim A.

column2: This spring, a University of California, Riverside delegation traveled 6,698 miles west to Guangzhou, Guangdong, and Anhui Province in eastern China to strengthen UCR’s relationships with the region’s top educators, researchers, and government officials. Across the Pacific Ocean, Chancellor Kim A.

column2: Assembly Select Committee on the California Master Plan for Higher Education deliberates how to best meet the needs of faculty and staff to support future scholars

column2: UCR’s vision of enrollment, infrastructure, and international growth come to fruition in the 2017-2018 academic year

column2: University of California scientists have discovered genetic data that will help food crops like tomatoes and rice survive longer, more intense periods of drought on our warming planet.

column1: Barbara Fried: Meet The Boys in the Boat and Billy Strings
column2: Sam Bankman-Fried (aka, S.B.F.), is a cryptocurrency CEO accused of duping more than a million investors.  John Martin Fischer is a UC Riverside philosophy professor who is a world-leading expert on free will and moral responsibility. Fischer's ruminations on near-death experiences have been consumed by millions in his writings and on YouTube videos. Fischer disagrees with the writings of Barbara Fried, a Stanford professor and S.B.F.’s mother, who maintains that we are driven by accidents of biology and circumstance, and therefore are blameless for our actions.

column2: Recipients to be honored at Chancellor’s Dinner on Oct. 20

column2: Pandemic highlights strain on households with children

column1: Surveys with repetitive questions yield bad data, study finds
column2: “In as few as six or eight questions, people are already answering in such a way that you’re worse off if you’re trying to predict real-world behavior”

column1: Inland Empire business activity growth contrasts with national decline
column2: Business activity in the Inland Empire continued to rise in the latest numbers, standing in stark contrast to the decline in GDP at the national level, according to the new Inland Empire Business Activity Index released today by the UCR School of Business Center for Economic Forecasting and Development. The increase in the region’s business activity in the second quarter of 2022 (the latest data available) does, however, represent a significant decline in growth from recent quarters.

column1: It's more than hot. It's dangerous.
column2: It's the time of year when Inland Southern California becomes a 27,000-square-mile skillet. We asked UC Riverside physicians how to stay safe and hydrated.

column1: UCR experts weigh drought's long-term impacts
column2: Gov. Gavin Newsom declared a drought emergency for the entire state of California this past month. The period from Oct. 1, 2020 to Sept. 30, 2021 was the second-driest year on record in California. Almost 90% of the state is in throes of extreme drought. Reservoir storage is 60% of average. Said one state water official: "It's almost beyond comprehension." We asked UCR experts what the future holds if drought conditions persist. Hoori Ajami, groundwater hydrologist

column1: Is it time to wear a highly efficient medical grade facemask?
column2: UC Riverside experts weigh in

column1: Sending kids back to school: is it too soon?
column2: After more than a year of lockdown, school is back in session. But many people are wondering whether it should be. Here, UC Riverside experts in viruses, medical policy and education share their thoughts about whether in-person learning at this moment in time is an A+ idea, and offer ideas about how to move forward.

column1: Why is it taking so long to approve a COVID-19 vaccine for kids?
column2: UC Riverside vaccine expert David Lo explains

column1: Billionaires in the great beyond
column2: UCR scientists weigh in on the first successful civilian trip to space, and the ethics of being a billion-dollar rocket man.

column1: Should Congress treat insurrectionists as the Romans did?
column2: The political divide that led to the Jan. 6, 2021 insurrection on the Capitol building has been perpetuated in discourse over how to properly address the role  of legislators who may have been involved. On the Jan. 6 anniversary of the insurrection, Michele Salzman, a UC Riverside history professor, published an opinion article in Zocalo urging lawmakers to look to the Roman response to another famous attack on another capital — the fifth century sack of the city of Rome by the Visigoths.

column1: UCR experts: Newsom's CARE courts an 'oxymoron'
column2: Experts on the plight of the unhoused contend the plan would criminalize being poor and mentally ill

column1: Experts on earthquakes
column2: Earthquakes For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu Nicolas Barth, assistant professor of geology

column1: The unintended consequences of using a ventilator
column2: Breakthrough research addresses a long-standing question in pulmonary medicine about whether modern ventilators overstretch lung tissue. They do.

column1: In the space of a day, restrictions go away
column2: The promised return-to-normal set by Gov. Gavin Newsom came with the promised easing of restrictions, and then some. In April, Newsom announced that the familiar color tiers of the pandemic and their mandates would go away on June 15. The heads up gave UCR and the rest of the state a nod that progressive planning for fall is a safe bet.

column1: Should you get a second booster shot for COVID-19?
column2: UC Riverside’s Dr. David Lo, a vaccine expert, shares his thoughts

column1: Experts urge reconsideration of 'standard' for time-keeping
column2: To gauge the impacts of dark mornings in some parts of the country, we spoke with two UC Riverside experts

column1: To mask, or not to mask?
column2: To gauge whether scientists agree with popular sentiment around mask wearing, we check in here with three UC Riverside virologists and epidemiologists.

column1: Free speech, meet Elon Musk's Twitter
column2: This week, billionaire Elon Musk struck a deal to buy Twitter for $44 billion. His statements before and since have led many to believe he intends to ease or eliminate content moderation. “Free speech is the bedrock of a functioning democracy, and Twitter is the digital town square where matters vital to the future of humanity are debated,” he said. Here, UCR professor of political science and public policy Kevin Esterling weighs in on Musk's pending acquisition. Esterling is director of the Laboratory for Technology, Communication and Democracy.

column1: Is that a persistent cold, bad allergies, … or long COVID?
column2: Dr. Martin Schlusselberg of the UCR School of Medicine explains

column1: Monkeypox explained
column2: UC Riverside experts discuss disease symptoms, vaccines, and anxiety management

column1: Unusual team finds gigantic planet hidden in plain sight
column2: A UC Riverside astronomer and a group of eagle-eyed citizen scientists have discovered a giant gas planet hidden from view by typical stargazing tools.

column1: Geckos might lose their tails, but not their dinner
column2: A new UC Riverside study finds geckos are fierce hunters whether or not their tails are attached to their bodies.

column1: How mountain streams signal climate change
column2: A new tool designed by UC Riverside researchers can better assess an overlooked indicator of global warming: the variety of bugs, worms, and snails living in high mountain streams.

column1: Antibiotics wreak havoc on athletic performance
column2: By killing essential gut bacteria, antibiotics ravage athletes’ motivation and endurance. The UC Riverside-led mouse study suggests the microbiome is a big factor separating athletes from couch potatoes.

column1: Mass customization can make fashion more sustainable if customers are willing to wait for it
column2: High fees for disposal and recycling can boost the sustainable effect under some circumstances

column1: AI programs consume large volumes of scarce water
column2: UCR study the first time estimates the huge water footprint from running artificial intelligence queries that rely on the cloud computations done in racks of servers that must be kept cool in warehouse-sized data processing centers.

column1: Sniffing your way to the gym
column2: Exercise motivation could be linked to certain smells, UC Riverside mouse study finds

column1: New research bites holes into theories about Megalodons
column2: A new study leaves large tooth marks in previous conclusions about the body shape of the Megalodon, one of the largest sharks that ever lived.

column1: Better predicting how plants and animals will weather climate extremes
column2: A team of scientists led by UC Riverside has devised a more accurate way to predict the effects of climate change on plants and animals — and whether some will survive at all.

column2: Project will develop energy-efficient, energy-elastic, and real-time-aware graphic-processing units

column2: Researchers are building a tool that searches real-time text, photo, and video from many sources to help responders allocate resources

column1: Making ‘soft’ robots work harder
column2: A new robot developed at UC Riverside can navigate uneven surfaces with silicone legs

column2: Just 25 industry-standard fast charging cycles can ruin a car’s batteries

column2: Amit Roy-Chowdhury leads project that will develop robust context-aware machine vision for computers

column1: Keeping the peace when mom and grandma disagree on feeding the kids
column2: Nutrition education programs for children should incorporate all family members who act as caregivers

column1: Sociologist’s family history inspires her first book
column2: Victoria Reyes’ research explores a place that figures heavily into her heritage: the Philippines’ Subic Bay

column1: Youth who understand mental illness more likely to ask for help later
column2: Research suggests destigmatizing mental illness in schools could increase the likelihood of treatment-seeking for youth who need it

column2: Targeted violation reports are more likely to encourage vertical integration and reward “good” firms

column2: Researchers are creating an autonomous mobile robot to sample leaves and measure their water potential

column2: Simple process transforms PET plastic into a nanomaterial for energy storage

column2: The breakthrough combines excellent electromagnetic shielding with ease of manufacture and electrical isolation

column1: UCR Engineering Welcomes 12 New Faculty
column2: UC Riverside’s Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering (BCOE) welcomed 12 new faculty members this year. Among the additions are the director of neurotechnology at California Institute of Technology’s T&C Chen Brain-Machine Interface Center, an EECS Rising Stars participant, a KIChE President Young Investigator Award recipient, and a NSF review panel member.

column1: Quickly optimizing deep neural networks for different devices
column2: New technique makes apps perform better across devices while keeping costs about the same

column2: UC Riverside engineers are developing methods to keep self-driving cars and autonomous drones from being hacked

column1: ARL-West and UCR engineering partnership a win-win for the future warfighters and students alike
column2: Today’s soldiers face a battlefield unlike any before them. With the rapid advancement of high performance technology, warfighters can quickly be left vulnerable if they lack the latest capabilities.

column2: The California labor market is recovering but rate of job growth has slowed

column1: ‘The Cost of Free Shipping’ lifts curtain on Amazon

column2: Regional employment recovered more than 54,000 jobs

column1: Grant enables first nationwide effort to save native bees
column2: Though regional studies have tracked the decline of native bees, there hasn’t been a coordinated nationwide effort to monitor these pollinators — until now. UC Riverside entomologist Hollis Woodard and bee researchers at 11 other institutions are now gathering data that will help governments and land managers justify new protective regulations.

column2: Region is outperforming along multiple measures

column1: Latino census data points to college-graduation disparity
column2: Sept. 25, the Center for Social Innovation released a report based on census data that asserts only 11% of Latinos in the Inland Empire have a bachelor’s degree or higher, compared with 35% overall in California and 33% nationally. Latinos comprise 51 percent of the 4.65 million people who live in the Inland Empire.

column2: External application could reduce agricultural reliance on fungicides

column2: Synthetic strigolactones could also improve nutrient uptake in crops

column2: Primary candidates Xavier Becerra, Steven Bailey, Eric Early, and Dave Jones will convene at UCR's Culver Center on May 15

column1: Demographic dilemma: slowing population growth, not pandemic, at the root of U.S. worker shortage
column2: Supply chain struggles have been widely blamed for the inability to meet consumer and business demand throughout the pandemic.

column2: UC Riverside study focused on how HIV mutates to escape the immune system
