column1: Frequently Asked Questions
column2: Find the Answer We’ve anticipated many of your questions and tried to answer them. If you are unable to find the answer here, don’t hesitate to contact us.

column1: Satisfactory Academic Progress (SAP)
column2: Like all schools that offer federal financial aid, UCR Financial Aid uses Satisfactory Academic Progress (SAP) standards to measure acceptable progress toward degree completion.

column1: Project Management Certificate
column2: Complete the 18-unit Project Management certificate within 9-12 months.You'll learn: Foundational project management approachesProposals to post-project analysisMethods to assess scheduling, risk management, budgetary limitations, workloads, and quality assuranceThe process of project procurementVendor contractingRelated costs

column1: Health Insurance
column2: All UCR University Extension students, regardless of visa status or program, must purchase the UC Extension Health Insurance.

column1: Online Learning Systems
column2: Learn about all the online learning systems available to you as a student, including e-learn, canvas, zoom, and YuJa.

column1: Coding Bootcamp
column2: Complete the 5-module Coding Bootcamp certificate within 24 weeks.You'll learn: Full-stack web developmentHow to build a website from scratch or by utilizing a front-end frameworkHow to create full-stack, single-page web applications with RESTful routes and AJAX methodsMethods for generating dynamic content and how to implement user-authentication schemes by incorporating different types of databases - MySQL and MongoDBHow to develop apps Basics of troubleshooting and enhancing legacy codeHow to create RESTful API's properly utilizing JSON as a data formatThe entire development cycle of complex projects in both independent and collaborative settings

column1: Cybersecurity Bootcamp
column2: Complete the 6-module Cybersecurity Bootcamp certificate within 24 weeks.You'll learn: How to identify suspicious patterns of user behavior to identify bots, intruders, and other malicious actorsMethods to analyze malware to identify its origin and purpose, and determine methods for uninstalling itHow to perform Python programming along with Bash and scriptingBest practices for conducting vulnerability assessments using tools like Metasploit to profile an application for vulnerabilities, and then exploit those vulnerabilities

column1: How to Stay Eligible
column2: Six Ways to Stay Eligible for Financial Aid: You must do all seven to maintain eligibility!

column1: Human Resources Management Certificate
column2: Complete the 15-unit Human Resources Management certificate within 9-12 months.You'll learn: HiringRecruitmentCompensationSupervision and retention of staffEmployee benefit administrationInsurance and risk managementHuman resources lawLabor relationsWorkers compensation

column1: Applied Cybersecurity Certificate
column2: Complete the 6-unit Applied Cybersecurity certificate within 5 months.You'll learn: Essential concepts and terminology in cybersecurityAssessment of vulnerabilityInstallation of network componentsUtilization of security tools for assessing riskMethods to troubleshoot network security issuesInstallation of databases securityUse of SQL Server Identifying assets at risk to applying appropriate technologies to protect them

column1: Microsoft Outlook Course
column2: Outlook is the leading application used to manage e-mail, schedule meetings and appointments, keep track of contact information, organize folders and files, and collaborate with co-workers. Participants develop skills in using Outlook to send, receive and manage e-mail; insert, edit and manage attachments; schedule meetings; assign and track tasks; track and share contact numbers and addresses; log activities; create custom forms and reports; filter information and share files. From this course participants can prepare for the Microsoft Outlook certification exam.

column1: Content and Methods for Teaching Advanced Placement Human Geography (APSI) Course
column2:
Curriculum content and instructional strategies for teaching AP Human Geography. This course introduces participants to the systematic study of patterns and processes that have shaped human understanding, use, and alteration of Earth's surface. Participants employ spatial concepts and landscape analysis to examine socioeconomic organization and its environmental consequences. They also learn about the methods and tools geographers use in their research and applications. The curriculum reflects the goals of the National Geography Standards.

Note: This course is offered as part of the Advanced Placement Summer Institute for high school Advanced Placement teachers. Participants in this course will be high school teachers who are assigned to teach or who are interested in teaching AP Human Geography.

column1: World History: Twentieth Century Course
column2: Over five weeks, we will trace the history of the long 20th century across our interconnected world. Throughout the course, we will assess global patterns and trends, including decolonization, total war, and the Great Acceleration, and focus in on illustrative case studies in the Congo, Hawai’i, Japan, and more. Our survey of the 20th-century world will be guided by three key themes: the global movement of people and ideas, technological and environmental crisis, and power struggles between revolution and empire. Apart from the historical content, the course will also teach students how to think and read like a historian.

column1: Finder
column2: Explore online or in-person certificates, teaching credentials, courses, or programs to prepare you to upskill, advance, or shift careers.

column1: Finder
column2: Explore online or in-person certificates, teaching credentials, courses, or programs to prepare you to upskill, advance, or shift careers.

column1: Writing Red: Native American Literature Course
column2: Acquaints students with a range of Native American literature. Discusses mass-mediated images of Native Americans and how "Indian-ness" is constructed, contested, and embodied in poetry, film, autobiography, fiction, and photography.

column1: The Origins Course
column2: Explores the most fundamental questions in cosmology, physics, and chemical sciences through their origins. Topics include: the origin of the Universe, origin of matter, first generation of stars and galaxies, origin of chemical elements, chemistry of life, and astrobiology.

column1: Introduction to the Study of Race and Ethnicity Course
column2: This course will introduce foundational theories and concepts in Ethic Studies, and examine how social institutions have historically shaped race relations and social processes producing racial, class, and gender inequalities and stratifications. Surveys racial ethnic groups and gives particular attention to the historical presence and contributions of African Americans, Asian Pacific Islanders, Chicanas/os, Latinas/os, and Native Americans in the United States. Students will utilize interdisciplinary perspectives from the social sciences and humanities and analyze concepts, research methods, and theories pertaining to the study of culture, economics, history, politics, and society. Students will examine the historical development of diverse cultures, and the role those cultures play in shaping core institutions and practices of individuals and societies. Students will discuss principles, methods, value systems, and ethics of social issues confronting local and global communities.

column1: Science Fiction: Major Themes & Motifs Course
column2: An introduction to science fiction from the nineteenth century to the present, examining the influence of other literary forms (utopian, folklore, medieval, etc.), as well as scientific, historical, social, political, and religious trends on the genre.

column1: Shakespeare Course
column2: This course, intended primarily for non-English majors, is designed to provide an understanding of drama as a form of literary art and to encourage a familiarity with Shakespeare's most important works. Plays from each dramatic genre (comedy, history and tragedy) will be included.

column1: Introduction to Microeconomics Course
column2: Principles of microeconomics with emphasis on methodology of economic analysis, supply and demand theory, market theory, resource allocation, and the provision of public goods. In the study of economics, we assume homo economics rationally pursues profit and growth that, at times, disregards both negative and positive impacts on the rest of society. Promoting social responsibility, we’ll explore economic principles to align private and social preferences to maintain a habitable and sustainable world for present and future generations. We’ll also consider how incentives can increase social awareness, and inspire collective action to improve general welfare.

column1: Introduction to Macroeconomics Course
column2: An introduction to the study of the economic system from a macro, or aggregate, perspective. Includes analysis of business cycles, economic growth, unemployment, inflation, and the impact of government policies on the level of economic activity.

column1: Introduction to Gay and Lesbian Literature Course
column2: Examines central texts by gay and lesbian authors from the nineteenth century to the present. The primary focus is on exploring the ways in which sexual identity affects the writing of literature.

column1: Finder
column2: Explore online or in-person certificates, teaching credentials, courses, or programs to prepare you to upskill, advance, or shift careers.

column1: Introduction to Critical Thinking Course
column2: A practical examination of reasoning and argument, topically illustrated.

column1: Introduction to College Mathematics for Business and the Social Sciences Course
column2: Covers functions and their graphs including linear and polynomial functions, zeroes, and inverse functions as well as exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric functions and their inverses. Also includes counting including elementary probability. Involves applications to business and social sciences.

column1: Finder
column2: Explore online or in-person certificates, teaching credentials, courses, or programs to prepare you to upskill, advance, or shift careers.

column1: Introduction to Business Course
column2: Provides an overview of the field of business administration. Explores business goals and strategies, functional areas of business and their integration in policy and decision making, social responsibility, computers in business, and business trends and challenges including the international dimension.

column1: Introduction to Asian American Literature Course
column2: An introduction to the history, social background, culture, and literature of Asian America.

column1: Introduction to Applied Data Science: A multi-disciplinary approach Course
column2: Introduces students from different disciplines (physical, biological, engineering, finance, economy, humanities) to data science techniques and applications. Provides background knowledge in data science, and prepares for a career in this field. Provides basic knowledge to continue on to more advanced topics in data science and apply it to practical problems.

column1: Introduction to Archaeology Course
column2: This course offers a general introduction to the aims and methods of archaeology, in both the field and laboratory.By the end of this course, the student should be able to situate basic knowledge of archaeology within an anthropological framework, and have a good comprehension of the methods that archaeologists use to reconstruct the past. World prehistory as revealed by these methods will be briefly surveyed.

column1: Human Evolution Course
column2: Explores the evolutionary history of humans as biocultural beings adapting to changing environments. Examines fossils, genetics, and archaeological data.

column1: History 17A: The United States to 1877 Course
column2: This course covers the key developments in the history of United States to 1877. While the course gives a general survey of United States History to 1877, it will rely on key concepts and institutions that were developed. Students cover American society, politics, and culture. Focus is on the unique historical conditions that framed and formed America’s foundation, and how those conditions affected the emergence of a new, powerful, and industrial United States. Students also explore various challenges we, as a people, have faced, and discuss the political and geographic realities average Americans encountered as they attempted to deal with expanding democracy, and confronted America’s differing and changing political viewpoints.

column1: First-Year Calculus Course
column2: Introduction to the differential calculus of functions of one variable.

column1: First Year Calculus Course
column2: Introduction to the integral calculus of functions of one variable.

column1: Financial Accounting and Reporting Course
column2: A study of the concepts and techniques for measurement and communication of financial information. Includes interpretation of financial statements.

column1: Ethics and the Meaning of Life Course
column2: Approaches one of the basic questions of value: how should one live? Covers classical and contemporary discussions of issues such as the human good, human virtue, the role of pleasure and happiness, egoism and altruism, duty, the relativity and objectivity of value, the meaning of life, death, autonomy, integrity, and conscience.

column1: Energy and Environment Course
column2: Covers energy conservation, energy sources, market dynamics, and climate change. Addresses cultural, political, and social trends and their impact on the ecosystem. Discusses renewable and nonrenewable energy sources.

column1: Electronics, Smart Phones, and Mobile Internet Course
column2: Introduces basic concepts and understanding of electronic products, wireless communications, industrial control, and robotics that are important for citizens and leaders in the information age. Highlights including smartphones, mobile Internet, robots etc., will be used as examples.

column1: Cultural Anthropology Course
column2: Explores the basic contributions of anthropology to the understanding of human behavior and culture and the explanation of similarities and differences among human societies. Addresses the relevance of materials drawn from tribal and peasant culture to problems of the modern world. Stresses the application of anthropological methods to research problems.

column1: Contemporary Moral Issues Course
column2: Philosophical analysis of contemporary moral issues, such as: abortion, discrimination, sexual morality, punishment, the obligation to obey the law, suicide, euthanasia, war, privacy.

column1: Chicana & Chicano Literature Course
column2: An introduction to Chicana and Chicano literature. Explores teatro, poetry, short stories, novels, essays, and other genres particular to Chicana and Chicano literary production. Periods of study include turn-of-the-century to the present.

column1: Calculus for Life Sciences I Course
column2: Introduction to the differential calculus of functions of one variable for students majoring in Life Sciences.

column1: Calculus for Life Sciences II Course
column2: Introduction to the integral calculus of functions of one variable. For Life Sciences majors.

column1: Calculus for Business Course
column2: Explores relations and functions (e.g., linear, polynomial, logarithmic, and exponential). Addresses differential calculus of functions of one and two variables as well as integration (indefinite and definite) with applications to business and economic problems.

column1: American Indian Literature Course
column2: An introduction to the defining themes of American Indian literature. Through traditional stories, autobiography, poetry, and fiction, the class explores the relationships between humans and nature; the individual and the community; and Indian and American identities.

column1: African American Autobiography Course
column2: An introduction to African American literature, focusing on how black literature in the United States has been shaped by self-narrated responses to terror and oppression. Examines autobiographies by Frederick Douglass, Harriet Jacobs, Langston Hughes, Ida Wells-Barnett, and Malcolm X.

column1: STEAM Discovery Camp Course
column2: Fun, interactive, collaborative, and challenging STEAM experiences for 3rd to 5th graders.

column1: Law School Admission Test (LSAT) Preparation Course
column2: LSAT Preparation will provide students with the skills needed to take the LSAT exam. This course will cover typical question types on the LSAT exam, and will help students prepare using previous LSAT exams.

column1: Graduate Recorded Examinations (GRE) Test Preparation Course
column2: GRE Preparation will provide students the skills and tools needed to maximize their potential on the GRE test. This comprehensive program covers each of the three main sections of the GRE General Test, including Analytical Writing, Verbal Reasoning, and Quantitative Reasoning.

column1: Graduate Management Admission Test (GMAT) Preparation Course
column2: GMAT Preparation will provide students 24 hours of targeted instruction to help them fully prepare for the GMAT. This will be a comprehensive course which includes a review of the mathematical and verbal concepts tested on the GMAT, and prepares students for questions typically seen on the test, such as Quantitative, Verbal, Integrated Reasoning, and Analytical Writing.

column1: Exploring the Global Workplace Course
column2: Students will learn how to achieve introductory-level abilities in career-preparation skills including resume writing, informational interviewing, work-culture and communication, and traditional interviewing techniques. The objective is for students to become prepared to successfully participate in their placed internships and utilize the learned skills beyond their internships to prepare for opportunities for joining the workforce.

column1: Evil Course
column2: An introduction to the nature of evil, its motivation, and its origins. Utilizes a variety of sources to examine these themes, including classical philosophical texts and contemporary films.

column1: Enacting Change Across Cultures: Thinking Local/Thinking Global Course
column2: This course prepares students to self-reflect on their privilege and experiences to be informed and active change agents, within their communities and globally. Students will use the knowledge gained in prior courses and virtual internships to recognize and approach social issues on an individual and social level to enact change.

column1: Supervised Training, Part II Course
column2: The student will complete a reflective report in a hospitality business that allows the student to apply classroom knowledge and guided experience to onsite employment, and networking to career goals. This advanced internship program will prepare the student to confidently choose or not choose a career path in the hospitality industry using personal and professional employment knowledge and competencies. As a part of the learning experience, this class requires students to take up to two 2-hour courses offered by Disney’s DORMS program. Class can be found on the hyper link here: https://dorms.disney.com/course-details?courseId=183

column1: Problem-Solving Toolkit with R and Python Course
column2: This course prepares students to utilize GIS knowledge and data analysis skills to address spatial analysis problems, identify patterns and trends, and solve real-world problems. Students will use R and Python to analyze spatial datasets, conduct data modelling, and generate insights from the results. At the end of the class, students will be able to transform data into visualization, and generate their portfolio website that displays the past spatial relevant projects with R Markdown.

column1: Multidisciplinary Applications of Geospatial Data Course
column2: This is a one-quarter course that focuses on the use cases of geospatial data analysis. GIS technology is ubiquitous; however, not all students have access to the professional ArcGIS software. This course provides an alternative way of solving problems using web-mapping technologies. Web-mapping has unlocked the power of GIS and put online maps and geospatial intelligence in the offices/homes of millions, and the hands of billions. This technology can be applied to multiple fields, including urban planning, transportation, data visualization, and business analysis. This course will encompass typical case-to-case studies, and exercises.

column1: Fundamentals of Spatial Data Modeling and Analytics Course
column2: This course introduces the fundamental concepts and techniques used in geospatial intelligence, including remote sensing, centralizing sources stored using different data types, data processing, interactive spatial maps, and modeling. It is designed to build a core theoretical foundation in spatial analysis, and introduce methods for analyzing quantitative spatial data. The course will also explore the role of spatial data analysis across a variety of disciplines, including business, urban planning, environmental conservation, and disaster prevention. The focus is on understanding the theories and context of spatial analysis so that you are equipped to find and apply the best analytical tool for your problem, and to correctly and appropriately interpret and present your results.

column1: Environmental Logistics Course
column2: The purpose of this course is to help students understand the environmental effects of transport and logistics. Students will learn how to develop appropriate strategies for the management of reverse logistics and green logistics within the transport process.

column1: Data Analytics Technologies Course
column2: This module covers the basic concepts of statistics needed to understand the critical concepts of data mining, machine learning, and predictive analytics used in the visualization of analysis of data, particularly Big Data. Big Data is the term used for a collection of structured and unstructured data sets so large and complex that it is difficult to process using the commonly available relational database management systems and statistical software packages. Data mining is the process of discovering useful patterns and trends in large data sets. Predictive analytics is the process of extracting information from large data sets in order to make predictions and estimates about future outcomes. Students will gain an understanding of data preparation, the process models used in analytics, the algorithms and their requirements, the implementation of these algorithms using current technologies, and their applicability to different types of scenarios. They will also gain advanced practical skills in the design, implementation, and evaluation of analytical solutions to problems involving Big Data.

column1: Cloud Computing and Web Services Course
column2: This module provides analytical and practical coverage of cloud computing and web services. It focuses on the technology, frameworks, and associated standards: cloud models, cloud platforms, and scalability. It also provides coverage of current web service technology and data transport representations, and integrated cloud and web service application development. Current examples from industry technology are used throughout.

column1: Big Data Landscape Course
column2: This class covers the process of managing Big Data throughout its lifecycle--from requirements, through retirement. The lifecycle crosses different application systems, databases, and storage media. Students will gain an understanding of the full Big Data value chains. Students will be able to analyze the challenges and opportunities associated with the different stages which Big Data passes through.

column1: ITA Pronunciation Improvement Course
column2: In this course, students will learn about and practice the segmental and suprasegmental elements of English. Segmental elements of English include consonant and vowel sounds, and suprasegmentals include stress, rhythm, focus words and intonation. Students will apply their knowledge to various speaking contexts, with a focus on producing highly comprehensible speech, and on identifying and correcting instances of mispronunciation. At the end of the course, students will make an academic presentation to peers.

column1: Travel the Seven Natural Wonders of the World Course
column2: "Seven Natural Wonders" is an organization created with the mission of protecting and promoting the natural wonders of the world. The project was launched in 2008. The campaign was distinguished by avoiding the influence of marketing, advertising, and social media. The winning wonders were determined by experts from around the world who leveraged statistical and traditional significance, uniqueness, and pure splendor. The list of the natural wonders includes: Aurora Borealis (also known as the northern lights); Harbor of Rio de Janeiro; Grand Canyon; Great Barrier Reef--Mount Everest; Victoria Falls; and Parícutin, Mexico. Each of the Seven Natural Wonders will be explored using drone video footage, original discovery comments, scientific explanations, expert descriptions, tourist comments, and more.

column1: Technology in World History Course
column2: This is a brief overview of the history of technology in the world. The course illustrates a panoramic view of the most important developments in technology that gave rise to our modern industrialized civilization. The aim is to provide a grand picture of the history of technology--from the early civilizations to the present--that every educated citizen needs to know.

column1: Science in World History Course
column2: This is a brief overview of the history of science in the world. The course illustrates a panoramic view of the most important developments in science that gave rise to our modern industrialized civilization. The aim is to provide a grand picture of the history of science–-from the early civilizations to the present--that every educated citizen needs to know.

column1: Painting Celtic Knots Course
column2: Interwoven knot work, aka Celtic Knots, began in 4th Century Italy, and appear in manuscripts throughout Europe and the British Isles. One knot that we’ll be painting even has feathers! Celtic Knots are visual symbols that God is woven into every aspect of our lives. Painting them is an exercise in meditation. You will be introduced to six Knots, one per week, along with step-by-step painting instructions, and a little history about each Knot. No previous experience required. Note: A $25 materials fee includes 6 hand-drawn and printed reproduction patterns on imported archival paper, backing board, a palette containing pigments of historically accurate colors, and a round-pointed brush. Everything you need to complete 6 projects will be mailed to you upon class registration.

column1: Musical Theatre Translated into Film: Part 2 Course
column2: We will continue our examination of six more successful American Musical Theatre Plays that have been adapted into films and in the case of one, vice versa. We’ll look at their origins and development, as well as their historical and cultural contexts. Musical theatre is typically thought of as escapist entertainment but, like all art, it reflects our evolution, history, culture, and morals. Often, dark or enlightening themes pervade these plays and their film adaptations. We’ll watch each film on our own, do some reading, and come together to discuss the history, themes, and underpinnings of 42nd Street, Showboat, Guys and Dolls, Oklahoma, West Side Story and Sweeney Todd. We’ll look at escapism during the depression, more escapism with gambling, sexuality, tolerance, racism, immigration, true crime, and class warfare. Plus, we’ll sing and tap our toes just a little. You will stream films and optional supplementary documentaries in your own time, and read articles.

column1: Xeriscape Design for the Home Gardener Course
column2: Basic concepts of good design such as form, function, balance and symmetry are illustrated. Particular attention is paid to common design errors that can lead to future maintenance problems and a less than satisfactory landscape. Emphasis is placed on selection of plant material suitable for inland Southern California to create a beautiful garden with minimal homeowner maintenance.  Participants analyze several garden designs for Xeriscape principles.

column1: Plant Propagation Workshop Course
column2: Learn all about how to make more of your favorite plants.  Topics include starting from seeds, making cuttings, division, air layering, grafting and budding. Proper preparation of materials, choosing the right containers, the best tools, media choices, hardening off and rooting hormones are also covered. Students are required to have a hand pruner.

column1: Staging Your Home to Sell Course
column2: Most people do not base their decision of purchasing a home solely on location and price. They usually bond emotionally with the home the very first time they see it. By creating a good first impression, sellers can dramatically increase a home's value to prospective buyers. Through lecture and examples, learn how to improve your home's appeal from the curb to the backyard and everything in between.

column1: Patio Design: Planning Ideas Course
column2: A one-day workshop designed to give you step-by-step instructions to plan the perfect patio--quickly and easily.  Learn simple design tricks, techniques and ideas to help you plot your patio onto paper. Discuss location, building materials, furniture and other features to suit your lifestyle.

column1: How to Grow Plants Indoors Successfully Course
column2: In one lecture and one lab, students are shown the do's and don'ts of growing plants indoors.  Students learn watering and fertilizing techniques and how to select plant materials suitable for growing in a low-light environment (including certain orchids and blooming African violets).  The lab session covers soils, plant cutting and the construction of a rooting bag full of cuttings to take home.

column1: Introduction to Aquaponics and Hydroponics Course
column2: The word "hydroponic" comes from Latin and means "working water."  Simply put, it is the art of growing plants without soil.  Adding a fish pond to the system makes it "aquaponics." When most people think of hydroponics, they think of plants grown with their roots suspended directly into water with no growing medium; however, this is just one type of hydroponic gardening. The major benefit of hydroponic and aquaponic gardening systems is that the nutrients are directly available to the plants, when and where they are needed. With conventional soil-based gardening, plants are expected to find available nutrients in the soil--nutrients that are often not present, having been depleted by excessive plantings. Join us to learn about the most common methods and variations of hydroponic gardening, discuss the pros and cons of each, and take home an abundance of great, general information about both hydroponics and aquaponics.

column1: Growing Vegetables in Containers Course
column2: Dream of growing your own fresh vegetables but don't think you have enough space? Container gardening is an easy way to grow your favorite edible crops--and convserve valuable water resources! Learn the essentials to get started. Topics include types and size of containers; soil and crop selection; optimum spacing for maximum crop yield; plant care; water and fertilization schedule; and diagnosing plant problems.

column1: Growing Plumerias, The Flowers of Love Course
column2: Plumerias (often called frangipani) are the most celebrated of all flowering trees growing in the tropical and subtropical world today.  They have broad appeal for flower types and shapes, brilliant colors and fragrances and can be used for lei, floated centerpieces and background foliage in the garden.  Plumerias are members of the oleander family and grow extremely well in the heat and sun of the Inland Empire and desert areas. Plumerias can be a special part of the garden as potted plants and/or planted in the ground in frost-free areas. This workshop discusses propagation, grafting, pruning, cultural practices, soil mixtures, fertilization, watering and pest control. A Saturday morning field trip provides a look at a plumeria garden.

column1: Growing Blueberries, Raspberries & Blackberries for Home Gardens Course
column2: The newest commercial berry crop to California is blueberries, but you too can grow them. Not only are they good to eat but also, with glossy green leaves in the summer and red foliage in the fall, they can be an exceptionally handsome bush in pots or the home garden. This course explores how to produce and care for blueberries, raspberries and blackberries in a home garden. Discussion includes the special cultural requirements of blueberries, such as acidic, well-drained organic soils and some chilling, and shading raspberries in southern California to extend their production throughout the hot summers. A Saturday morning field trip provides a look at a blueberry variety planting and a raspberry planting. Tasting is included in the tour.

column1: Green Design for Your Home Course
column2: From bamboo flooring to recycled glass hardware, there is wide assortment of green home products and furnishings available on the market today. For homeowners and designers, this course explores available green materials and implementing them in home projects and provides information and sources for obtaining them. Discussion includes the principles of sustainability, cost effectiveness and the long-term benefits of green design. Students gain exposure to many different materials and detailed information on retail and online sources.

column1: Growing and Propagating Cacti and Succulents Course
column2: Growing and propagating cacti can be a prickly job, but it's rewarding for anyone who wants to take a stab at it.  This practical course covers propagation of cacti and related plants;  handling cacti safely; collecting, cleaning and storing seed;  requirements for seed germination;  taking offshoots and cuttings;  and cacti culture including indoor and outdoor growing tips, soil mixes, watering and fertilizer.

column1: Great Roses for the Home Garden Course
column2: Through lecture and demonstration this workshop explores tried and true methods for producing spectacular roses.  Participants are introduced to purchasing plants, preparing the soil, mulching, planting, fertilizing, watering and pruning for total care of roses.  Activities for the dormant season, controlling pests without using pesticides and displaying the results of your efforts to the best advantage are also discussed.

column1: Grafting and Budding Fruit Trees Course
column2: Techniques for grafting and budding a variety of fruit trees in the field and in the greenhouse.  Practical, easy-to-apply grafting methods and materials are discussed and demonstrated.  Topics include tools, graft aftercare and horticulture.  Students receive individualized instruction on crops of special interest to them.  During the Saturday morning field trip, students visit a commercial nursery and a commercial avocado grove.

column1: Edible Landscapes: Combining Form and Function Course
column2: Edible landscapes are designed to produce food, as well beauty, by growing vegetables along with fruit and nut trees, berry bushes, fruiting vines, herbs, and edible flowers. Offers an overview of planning, design, planting, maintenance, fertilization, vegetables, seasonal considerations, fruit trees, food safety, harvest and storage. Includes a visit to a garden that employs edible landscape design.

column1: Contemplative Crafting with Succulents and Other Plants Course
column2: This is an exploratory class in beginning succulent and other plant arrangements. You will be introduced to the positive effects of crafting in a relaxing, ambient atmosphere, with the intent and mindfulness to create and prepare a minimum of 5 plant arrangements. These will include, but not be limited to, a terrarium and other plant arrangements for the garden and home, as well as gifts for family, friends, special occasions and celebrations. Using visual aids, lectures, guided practice, in-class drawings, and demonstrations, the class will integrate and expand your awareness and creativity, as you learn to identify, harvest, grow and display native plants. Class fee includes materials and supplies.

column1: Citrus Trees in the Garden Course
column2: Covers the selection, planting and care of citrus trees in the home garden. Participants tour the UC Riverside Citrus Variety Collection, one of the most important and diverse collections of citrus trees in the world, and will have the opportunity to inspect and sample many varieties of citrus. The course presents information on selection of trees, site assessment, planting, feeding, irrigation, and disease and insect control for common and exotic species of citrus trees.

column1: Attracting Beneficial Insects to Your Garden Course
column2: Put the welcome mat out for all kinds of "good" bugs to come and stay in your garden!  Learn to identify the most common beneficial insects, what flowers and plants attract them, and how to maintain a year-round insectary of them. Includes a visit to a local demonstration garden.

column1: ABCs of Vegetable Gardening Course
column2: Did you have problems growing tomato plants last year?  Do pests damage your vegetables before they are harvested?  This course gives you the information you need to grow vegetables successfully in your garden. Learn how to identify the best locations in your garden, select appropriate plants for growing in this area, care for vegetable plants, and combat common plant pests.   The course includes tips on how to harvest and store fresh vegetables.   A lecture and tour of a backyard vegetable garden takes place on Saturday morning.

column1: Advanced Sketching for Designers Course
column2: You will learn to communicate your ideas through quick sketching techniques using a variety of media, including pencil, pen and markers. Emphasis is on developing visual communication skills for graphic design and packaging, product and interior design and advertising. Cover 3D form development and observational sketching on specific products or objects.

column1: UCR Iyengar Yoga Institute Weekend Seminar and Workshop Course
column2: This weekend workshop is designed to integrate the theory and practice of yoga. Yoga practitioners will deepen their understanding of Patanjali's yoga sutras and their essential connections to yoga practice. Those wishing to receive advance practice and training will benefit from attending this workshop.

column1: T'ai Chi Ch'uan: Beginning Yang Style Course
column2: T'ai Chi Ch'uan (Taijiquan) is a Chinese martial art and system of low-intensity exercise sometimes referred to as moving meditation. Total relaxation, breathing and proper movement are used to bring the mind and body into harmony.  This class introduces the first Yang-style form, foundation exercises, stretching, basic techniques, Ch'i Kung (Qigong) and traditional exercises.  The emphasis for this class is learning basic techniques, the form and relaxation training.  Stress reduction techniques and Chinese Yoga (ch'i kung) floor exercises are also covered.

column1: Yoga Continuing Practice Course
column2: Designed to expand and deepen your practice of yoga postures.   You will build from the basic poses taught in Iyengar Yoga I and II to complicated asanas.  The focus will be to examine and further your practice through the subjective experience of various yoga poses.

column1: Yoga Workshop:  Inverted Poses Course
column2: This workshop reviews the practice and many benefits of inverted yoga poses. The student will learn appropriate preparatory poses, as well as the sequence for practicing inversions.

column1: Introduction to Pilates: Theory & Practice of Mat Pilates Course
column2: Students will learn the history and theory of Pilates (contrology), based upon the teachings of Joseph Pilates. Pilates exercises will be instructed and performed in a fun, positive, safe, and effective manner increasing strength, flexibility, and mindfulness in one's practice.

column1: Beginning Mindfulness Training and Practice Course
column2: What does it mean to live fully present in our moment-by-moment experience? This course introduces the basics of mindfulness, with an emphasis on starting or deepening your own meditation practice in a busy world. You will cover the latest research on the benefits of mindfulness on our well-being, and includes sitting, walking, and eating meditations; interactive discussions; and writing reflections. Practical exercises are designed to gently nourish kindness, self-compassion, and forgiveness as antidotes to self-critical thoughts and life patterns. The class welcomes students of all ages and backgrounds, and is especially valuable to those in the helping and teaching professions. Weekly “homework” assignments will encourage you to cultivate awareness, and sustain a personal meditation practice once the class ends.

column1: R'STEM Makershops Course
column2: A series of workshops based on the Makerspace ideology. Eager learners will learn introductory STEM concepts with a focus on engineering and design. Participants will build STEM-related projects using a variety of materials. Workshop topics will vary and rotate throughout the year.

column1: Beginning Iyengar Yoga Course
column2: A beginning practice class in Iyengar yoga. The course offers instruction in basic yoga postures/poses (asanas) according to the Iyengar method, and includes: classical Sanskrit terms and meaning for each pose; variations and adaptations of poses; and the benefits of each group of poses. This course is designed for the general yoga practitioner interested in developing their knowledge, beginning a yoga practice, and understanding the basic concepts of yoga. Upon completion of this course, students will be able to perform basic yoga poses; understand basic Yoga concepts and Sanskrit names and translation of poses; understand the physical and mental health benefits of each group of poses; and begin an independent yoga practice. This beginning course will also help prepare students who wish to take Iyengar Yoga I (AST X401).

column1: The Construction of Native Americans in Film: Wiping The War Paint Off the Lens Course
column2: This course explores the "visible" and "invisible" imaging and social construction of Native American women and men in modern day film and cinematography.  Through class discussions, writings, and film, we will examine and probe how discourses on race, class, gender, and nation inform popular culture and how they position Native Americans within various communities. We will explore the histories, politics, social identities and representation of Native Americans by examining documentaries, Hollywood productions, and independent films made by Native Americans and non-Native Americans.

column1: The Business of Photography Course
column2: Designed to help photographers assign a profit to their art, this course will help students define their ideal client, learn how to assign a price to their art, and develop effective responses to successful and unsuccessful sales. Students will work through the process of developing a winning marketing and business plan, and will be advised on implementation techniques.

column1: Travel Photography Course
column2: For those with photography experience, this course introduces the essentials of good travel photography, which captures the scenery, the people and the culture of any destination.  Students explore how to make travel plans when photography is a goal, how to plan a day "on location," and how to make the most of available time in order to get quality photos.  An emphasis will be on photographing people and techniques that illustrate a culture.  Participants practice what they have learned by planning and participating in a photographic travel/field trip to a destination of their own choosing.

column1: Saturday Morning on Location: UCR Botanic Gardens Course
column2: Spend a Saturday morning leisurely exploring the UCR Botanic Gardens and using close-up photography to capture its beautifully planned community. You will learn about close focus controlling, image sharpness, exposure adjustments, and related camera features for better detail and color. Throughout the morning, instructor will answer questions and give one-on-one assistance.  All experience levels are welcome.

column1: Saturday Morning on Location: Hsi Lai Temple Course
column2: Join us to photograph a cultural treasure in the San Gabriel Valley: Hsi Lai Temple. The temple's Ming and Ching dynasty architecture is the beautiful highlight of this 15 acre site that includes gardens and statuary. We start the morning with a creative exercise, then your instructor discusses lenses and using flash to balance sunlight and shadows. There is plenty of time for your photography and to get one-on-one assistance. All experience levels welcome.

column1: Saturday Morning on Location: Big Morongo Canyon Preserve Course
column2: Spend a Saturday morning exploring and photographing the trees, wetlands and landscape of Big Morongo Canyon Preserve. You will walk along two trails, often on boardwalks, that wind through the diverse nature beauty of Big Morongo. Discussions include light, lenses and photographic technique and one-on-one assistance from instructor.  All experience levels welcome.

column1: Portrait Photography Course
column2: Learn how great portraits can be taken using your camera and simple lighting techniques.  Focused discussions about subject matter, composition and lighting (including flash) help you experiment with a variety of portraiture methods and include topics such as photographing children, shooting a picture story and capturing candid and environmental portraits.  Photo assignments will be done using your camera (digital or 35 mm) inside and outside the classroom to practice the various techniques.

column1: Photography Projects: Silhouette, Still Life, Portrait and Night Scenes Course
column2: Learn why, when and how to override your camera's auto-exposure modes to achieve consistent repeatable results instead of letting the camera make the choices.  You will explore the subtleties of lighting and how they affect your images by completing four projects: Silhouette Project, Still Life Project, Portrait Project and Light/Night Scenic Project.  This course requires little experience with photography.

column1: Photographing the Mojave National Preserve Course
column2: Away from the interstate highway traffic is a landscape of subtle beauty and fascinating variety: California's eastern Mojave Desert.  With its panoramic views, sand dunes, cinder cones, historic buildings and Joshua trees, the eastern Mojave is less visited than more famous desert places, making it largely a desert wilderness.  The result is a quiet landscape excellent for photographic discovery.  The workshop is based at the Desert Studies Center southwest of Baker, California.  The Center, also known as Zzyzx, is a former health spa located at Soda Springs on the western edge of Soda Dry Lake.  Dedicated to research and education, Zzyzx has a complex of interesting buildings along with palms, ponds, springs and fine views of the lake bed and desert ranges. The workshop combines classroom instruction with early morning and late afternoon photographic field sessions and one-on-one assistance. Instruction includes: field techniques, approaches to photographing the desert, natural light, exposure, existing light photography and a review of student photographs.  Field session locations include the Zzyzx-Soda Springs area, Lava Beds, Kelso Depot and Kelso Dunes.  A follow-up session at UC Riverside Extension is scheduled to review photographs made at the workshop.  All camera formats are welcome.

column1: Photographing Joshua Tree National Park Course
column2: This workshop is designed for people who want to devote a block of time to photography as they explore parts of Joshua Tree National Park.  The photographic possibilities range from Joshua Tree forests, to cactus flats, to massive rock formations, to remnants of early mining activity. Through the day, the desert sun keenly reveals the special qualities of this nearby national park.  Autumn is an excellent season for photography in Joshua Tree: temperatures are mild, weather changes can produce dramatic skies, numerous boulder outcroppings are accented with dashes of yellow from wildflowers.  A special "photographers only" visit to historic Keys Ranch is also planned.  This 1910 homestead contains a fascinating assortment of wooden buildings, machinery and ranch equipment.  The workshop format consists of early morning and late afternoon field sessions, along with individualized assistance and a review of previous photographs.  Participants will learn how to get better results from equipment they already own.  All camera formats are welcome.

column1: Photographing Death Valley Course
column2: This workshop is designed for people who want to devote time to photography as they explore the largest national park of the 48 contiguous states. At more than 3.3 million acres, Death Valley National Park is a place of surprising variety: sand dunes, salt flats, colorful canyons, date palms, historic mining sites, a saline creek. Visible from Badwater, near the lowest point (-282 ft.) in the Western Hemisphere, is an unobstructed view across the valley floor to 11,049 ft. Telescope Peak in the Panamint Range. It is a landscape that leaves a lasting impression. Photographic field sessions are planned for times of day when the light best reveals the shapes, colors and textures of Death Valley. Class discussions cover exposure, filters, natural light and camera use, with emphasis on ways to effectively photograph the desert. The instructor is available for one-on-one assistance at these field sessions. Participants also receive feedback on photographs they bring to the workshop. All camera formats are welcome.

column1: Photo Editing: Basics Course
column2: This intensive, one-day seminar is an ideal "first class" for people new to digital photo editing or those who would like a refresher course in basic editing tools and techniques. Our focus is on gaining useful knowledge and learning practical skills about image importing, making corrective and creative changes, processing raw and jpeg files, saving images, and final output for the web, email or an inkjet print. Learn to avoid common photo editing mistakes. Demonstrations are made using Adobe Photoshop CS software, but you may bring a laptop computer with any software you already have. An inkjet printing demonstration is included.

column1: Panorama Photography Course
column2: This online course is designed to facilitate the learning of intermediate panorama photography. The course will involve the development of stitched photographs, shot with and without a tripod. Students will be required to shoot and stitch one panorama photograph per week (after the first 2 weeks of class). Each student will provide helpful critiques and comment on the work of their peers. The course will have it's own Flickr account where students may log in, post their assignments and write critiques. Course lessons will be posted in screencast format.

column1: Night Photography Course
column2: Learn how to make exciting pictures at night using a 35 mm film or digital camera. Discussion and demonstration of the tools and techniques for low-light level photography. Includes instruction on the proper use of flash for night photography and how to use alternate sources of light for more exciting photographs. Students will produce outdoor night photographs and have them processed at a lab of their choice for evaluation by the instructor and fellow students.

column1: Landscape Photography Workshop Course
column2: Many of the most memorable photographs ever made have, in some manner, dealt with the land around us. The names of some landscape photographers have literally become household words. How is it that some people can create profound statements from little more than dirt and rock, while others seem to be at a loss when it comes to interpreting the places we see? In this workshop, students will explore the work of contemporary landscape photographers and take a look back to some of the early masters in an attempt to understand why this genre speaks so strongly to us. During the first meeting, we will discuss technical and aesthetic considerations in landscape photography in an effort to bring more power and meaning to our own images. Topics will include; film and filters, lighting, lenses, composition and artistic intent. The next day, participants will put this information to use during a one-day photographic field trip.  All skill levels are welcome and any camera format may be used.

column1: Introduction to Photography Hosting and Publishing Course
column2: Information on a variety of photography topics to assist you in creating an online venue for your photographs.  Details the best and most affordable ways to manipulate, manage, share and publish new and existing images. Topics include photo resolution, cropping, saturation, portfolios, hosting, file types (including audio files) and sizes. You will also make your own photo blog on Google's blogging platform, Blogger, and learn to post on YouTube.

column1: Getting Started in Digital Photography Course
column2: This intensive one-day seminar is an ideal "jump start" for people new to digital photography or those who simply need a refresher course in photography. In a step-by-step manner, basic digital photography is presented in a way that promotes learning and understanding. Answering your questions is an important part of the seminar. Throughout the day, you will learn tips and techniques useful in making better digital photographs. Seminar topics include camera features and settings, accurate focusing, viewfinder information, menu options, lenses, sharpness, exposure, ISO, white balance and flash. A troubleshooting session is planned to review "problem" photographs. Bring your digital camera (with adjustments for shutter and aperture), owner's manual and 10 "problem" photographs to class.

column1: Introduction to Close-Up Photography Course
column2: Taking photographs of small subjects at close range allows the photographer to explore a fascinating and beautiful world of design, color and shape. This course introduces both the technical and creative aspects of producing good quality close-up photographs. Students learn how to focus accurately, adjust camera settings for exposure and controlling image sharpness, and use viewpoint and natural light in composition. Discussion includes the pros and cons of close-up equipment and getting the most from existing equipment.

column1: Exploring Photography as a Fine Art Course
column2: You will be exposed to the important genres in fine art photography that have emerged during the medium's history. Additionally, you will examine your own preferences as photographers, with an eye to seeing where image-making fits among the spectrum of fine-art categories. Camera techniques common to each genre will also be emphasized, and you will assemble a foundational portfolio of your own work.

column1: DSLR Photography: Moving up to DSLR Cameras Course
column2: An online course designed to provide you with a working knowledge of modern DSLR cameras.  You will learn how to get the most out of your camera's features, and understand how to use your DSLR camera more creatively. You will also explore different ways of moving photographs from the camera to a home computer.

column1: Digital Storytelling Course
column2: In this class, students combine narrated essays with photographs and/or videos snippets to create a three-to-five minute personal digital story. Students will use Microsoft Movie Maker, a free software application from Microsoft, to create their digital stories.  Includes lectures, story viewing, story circles and hands-on lab work. Students write a personal essay, narrate and record their essay, arrange photographs  and/or video, and compile these to create a compelling digital story. Students should collect or create images to include with their story and bring them to class.

column1: Documentary Photography Course
column2: Learn the art of visual storytelling -- whether for a single editorial image, for feature stories or books or for creating a personal record of things observed. In this class, you explore ways to execute photos through a range of styles and subjects and create a story line from concept development to picture editing and sequencing. You learn to take better images with strong, sensitive and effective visual qualities by producing several themed projects that can work as a portfolio.

column1: Digital Photography: The Creative Advantage Course
column2: Explore the creative opportunities available to digital photographers using current Adobe CS software applications.  Designed for the more experienced photographer, assignments will include night photography; lighting on location and shooting for impact; and advanced creative and corrective techniques in Adobe Photoshop.  In-class demonstrations and practice will lay a foundation for projects executed with your own digital camera.

column1: Defining Your Photographic Vision Course
column2: Designed to help photographers identify and define their personal photographic vision. By evaluating previous work and images produced during the course, writing assignments and creative exercises, students will identify the themes and ideas that revolve around their photography, and how to apply their vision as a business or fine art sales. Through a process of discussion and various editing assignments, students will create a portfolio collection of images that best represent their personal vision. Images will be shown in a month-long exhibit in a gallery.

column1: Digital Photography: The Basics Course
column2: Learn how to effectively use your digital camera. This short course for beginners introduces the basic concepts of digital image capture, image formats, file manipulation, storage media and output. Students use their own digital cameras to produce images for photographic assignments. Instruction also covers a light review of photographic history, basic photographic concepts, and the fundamentals of Adobe Photoshop software.

column1: Digital Photography: Beyond the Basics Course
column2: This class is for those already familiar with their digital cameras and with camera settings such as aperture, shutter speed and exposure modes. The special features and extended capabilities of the digital camera are explored, along with methods of manipulating images using Adobe Photoshop. Control of contrast, color, sharpness and black-and-white image conversions are discussed, along with other creative options available to digital photographers. Students use their own cameras to produce images for assignments in a real studio, and employ lab computers to learn and apply manipulation techniques.

column1: Composition and Concepts for Better Photography Course
column2: Study of basic composition in photography with emphasis on practical applications of generally accepted guidelines.  Demonstrations, discussions and photo analysis concentrate on the question of why certain compositions are more interesting or successful than others. Covers the use of contrast, balance, line, shadow, texture and the Rule of Thirds.

column1: Beginning HDR Photography Course
column2: This online course introduces the process of combining three or more images of different exposures and combining them using software such as Photoshop CS 5 or Photomatix.   Topics covered include shooting images at different exposures with and without a tripod, adjusting the cymera setting known as AEB (Auto Exposure Bracketing); and HDR photo sets (landscape, street or indoor ) by adjusting the Exposure Compensation or Shutter Speed settings. You will follow step-by-step instructions for using the software to create different kinds of HDR photographs, from natural looking ones to those that appear surreal or painterly.

column1: Built-In Camera Flash Workshop Course
column2: In this hands-on workshop, you will explore basic and more advanced uses of built-in camera flashes to get better photographs of people and indoor and outdoor scenes. Learn when to use flash and how to adjust your camera's exposure and menu settings to help balance flash illumination with overall exposure. Bring your digital camera (with built-in flash and adjustments for shutter and aperture), owner's manual and ten"problem" photographs to class.

column1: Available Light Photography Workshop Course
column2: This workshop explores how to take photographs under lower levels of light to preserve the look of the scene or subject. Learn focusing techniques, exposure adjustments, camera steadiness, ISO sensitivity, and white balance useful for buildings, urban scenes, portraits, still life, indoor scenes, and landscapes. Course combines classroom instruction with on-campus available light photography sessions. Bring camera and six photographs to class.

column1: Visual Diary: The Process of Developing a Story Through the Visual Arts Course
column2: This course will explore the intersection of visual art and journalism. Art/writing students will engage in exercises to immerse themselves in a story/experience with the end result being a finished story accompanied with a visual component (which could also be a personal journal). The purpose of these exercises is to use visual and writing techniques to explore and absorb a place and/or experience. Keeping personal journals will also be explored.

column1: Watercolor Sketching Course
column2: Introduces you to the skills needed to create watercolor sketches from observation using various techniques such as line and wash, tone and basic color theory. You will progress through a sequence of sketchbook exercises, while gaining a firm understanding of using watercolor as an on location sketch medium. Designed for those with prior watercolor experience, but can also work for beginners.

column1: Watercolor Workshop Course
column2: A watercolor workshop for beginning and intermediate levels. Class discussions cover materials, techniques, composition, color, selection of subject matter, and the problems of painting in the field. The instructor will demonstrate watercolor painting from sketch to completion, so students can learn from the commentary on and analysis of a work in progress. Individual student projects will be based on one's own ability. Landscapes and still lifes are emphasized.

column1: Still Life Illustration in Colored Pencil Course
column2: Achieve vivid color, detailed texture, and other colored pencil techniques that will help your illustrations stand out in this hands-on workshop.  The colored pencil workshop series teaches you how to draw skillful and creative pieces from specific topics in Prismacolor combined with other media to capture the likeness of special subjects and/or textures. Still Life Illustrations in Colored Pencil will guide you in creating a realistic drawing with a focus on organic and created textures in one composition. Using photo references, you will explore techniques on developing surface color using transparent layering and burnishing for an extraordinarily realistic drawing on paper. Those who have taken Introduction to Prismacolor Techniques, or have other Prismacolor (or colored pencil) experience, are welcome.

column1: Simple Script with Flowers Course
column2: This simple script has a myriad of uses. You will explore different ways of writing, starting with a monoline pen (even a simple ball point will work), and moving on to a dip pen, a favorite tool of calligraphers. To complement your writing, you'll learn some simple watercolor flowers. This is a fun script for use on envelopes, greeting cards, journal pages and small art pieces. This class is a great way to begin mastering lettering with a dip pen.

column1: Quick Sketching for Travel Course
column2: How do you capture a picture when photography isn't allowed? This quick sketching workshop will open the doors to interesting adventures. Although the focus of this class is on travel sketching, techniques learned can also be used to highlight events and family activities. Participants will learn the basics of parallel, angular and cylindrical perspective and the use of fine and wide-line drawing instruments to sketch animals, people and architecture. Working from slides, photographs and on-site locations, participants will be introduced to the fundamentals of quick sketching.

column1: Pencil Techniques in Face Drawing Course
column2: An introduction to special techniques using graphite pencil in portrait drawing.  You explore fundamental structuring of the facial anatomy as you learn how to express detail and definition of form and textures found on the human face and head using:pencils, stumps, kneaded erasers.  Photo or image references will be used for all of the analysis, practice activity, and final drawings.  Fundamental drawing skills are prerequisite.

column1: Painting Outdoors - Plein Air Course
column2: Through a combination of lecture and painting demonstrations, you'll learn the history of Plein Air and the concepts and techniques that apply specifically to painting landscapes in the open air.  Your artistic interpretation should evolve as you gain a deeper understanding of color theory, mixing paints and using the principles of light and dark, contrast and perspective. Classes are held on location, and you'll create original paintings, each with its own palette and mood reflecting your art sense and capturing the atmospheric conditions, light changes and sheer beauty of painting outdoors.

column1: Introduction to Prisma Color Techniques Course
column2: An introduction to the special processes and techniques using Prisma Color wax pencils. Includes studies and activities on transparent layering and opaque layering (burnishing) techniques for expressive and realistic illustrations. You will also cover color theories and application process using the color pencils. Drawing experience is recommended.

column1: Introduction to Pen and Ink Drawing Course
column2: An introduction to the special processes and techniques in pen and ink drawing. Include studies and activities on contour, hatch, cross hatch, and stippling to create expressive gesture sketch or realistically developed drawings. You will begin evaluating line types and their uses in drawing, which involve massing (shading) and form development. Drawing experience is recommended.

column1: Introduction to Contemporary Painting Course
column2: This class will provide hands on instruction for basic contemporary painting practices by examining the components of 2D image-making from a contemporary arts culture perspective. Using a variety of media, including acrylic and oil painting, students will  develop strong fundamentals in painting. Course includes demonstrations and projects designed to expose students to common methods, materials and techniques.

column1: Introduction to Color and Paint Course
column2: The power of color in an artwork cannot be underestimated. Be it subdued, bright or absent, it is a key component in creating the mood or feeling of a painting. The ability to understand and mix colors so that your painting has unity and expresses the emotions you'd like to portray are key to creating powerful artwork. You learn basic color theory and how to mix colors in completion of your finished painting.

column1: Intermediate Drawing Course
column2: This course continues the study and refinement of skills and concepts acquired in Basic Drawing I. Course work includes an exploration of a broader range of subject, media, and the expressive possibilities of drawing.

column1: Illustrating Glass and Chrome in Colored Pencil Course
column2: Glass and Chrome can be some of the most difficult materials to illustrate. This course will show you how to create realistic drawings with a focus on transparent glass and high shine chrome objects. Using photo references, you will explore techniques on developing surface colors using transparent layering and burnishing for an extraordinarily realistic drawing on paper. The colored pencil workshop series teaches you how to draw detailed and creative pieces from various topics in Prismacolor combined with other media to capture the likeness of special subjects and/or textures. Those who have taken Introduction to Prismacolor Techniques, or have other Prismacolor (or colored pencil) experience, are welcome.

column1: How to Draw Seascapes and Beaches in Colored Pencil Course
column2: Discover how to draw beautiful ocean related landscapes with colored pencils. The colored pencil workshop series teaches you how to draw detailed and creative pieces from specific topics in Prismacolor combined with other media to capture the likeness of special subjects and/or textures. The course will guide you in creating a realistic illustration using the subject matter of sky, water, and created textures. Using photo references, you will explore techniques on developing surface colors using transparent layering and burnishing for an extraordinarily realistic drawing on paper. Those who have taken Introduction to Prismacolor Techniques, or have other Prismacolor (or colored pencil) experience, are welcome.

column1: How to Draw Your Pet in Colored Pencil Course
column2: Learn how to draw your pet, or any animal, in this one-on-one workshop course. The colored pencil workshop series teaches you how to draw detailed and creative pieces from specific topics in Prismacolor combined with other media to capture the likeness of special subjects and/or textures. How to Draw Your Pet in Colored Pencil will guide you in creating a realistic drawing with a focus on fur, eyes, and the unique character of your pet or animal. Using photo reference, we will explore techniques on developing layers of color for an extraordinarily realistic drawing on paper. Those who have taken Introduction to Prismacolor Techniques, or have other Prismacolor (or colored pencil) experience, are welcome.

column1: Fast Sketching Course
column2: This course emphasizes drawing and sketching through demonstration, discussion, hands-on drawing, and rapid visualization. Students will progress through a sequence of projects and exercises that apply sketching practices of observation, expression, and accuracy. A variety of sketching techniques will be introduced to study, and put into practice. This course could apply and supplement various disciplines that include commercial and fine arts.

column1: Fast Sketching Course
column2: This course emphasizes drawing and sketching through demonstration, discussion, hands-on drawing and rapid visualization. Students will progress through a sequence of projects and exercises that apply sketching practices of observation, expression and accuracy. A variety of sketching techniques will be introduced to study and put into practice. This course could apply and supplement various disciplines that include commercial and fine arts.

column1: Drawing the Elderly Face in Colored Pencil Course
column2: Learn how to delicately illustrate elderly faces with colored pencils. The colored pencil workshop series teaches you how to draw detailed and creative pieces from specific topics in Prismacolor combined with other media to capture the likeness of special subjects and/or textures.  Drawing the Elderly Face in Colored Pencil will guide you in creating a realistic drawing with a focus on wrinkled skin textures and grey hair. Using photo references, you will explore techniques on developing surface colors using transparent layering and burnishing for an extraordinarily realistic drawing on paper. Those who have taken Introduction to Prismacolor Techniques, or have other Prismacolor (or colored pencil) experience, are welcome.

column1: Drawing a Baby's Face in Colored Pencil Course
column2: Learn the techniques to delicately draw a baby's face with colored pencils. The colored pencil workshop series teaches you how to draw detailed and creative pieces from specific topics in Prismacolor, combined with other media, to capture the likeness of special subjects and/or textures.  The course will guide you in creating a realistic drawing, with a focus on delicate transitions of color and textures of a baby's face. Using photo references, you will explore techniques on developing surface colors using transparent layering and burnishing for an extraordinarily realistic drawing on paper. Those who have taken Introduction to Prismacolor Techniques, or have other Prismacolor (or colored pencil) experience, are welcome.

column1: Copperplate Lowercase Writing Course
column2: Modern variations of Copperplate script are all the rage, used by cutting-edge graphic artists and calligraphers. You will start with traditional lower case calligraphy, writing with something as simple as a pencil, to learn the basic shapes and strokes, progressing to the dip pen. Some people prefer to use only lower case in their projects, and this is a great start. You will learn the shapes and strokes for lowercase Copperplate script, applying pressure-and-release, with a dip pen, for elegant writing.

column1: Copperplate Capitals Writing Course
column2: Learn the strokes and shapes of copperplate capital letters using pencil, pen, and a dip pen. Produce shapes and styles; create, polish and define the curves of each letter; add definition by creating thick and thin lines.

column1: Beginning Painting Using Acrylics Course
column2: Introduces the medium of acrylic painting, including building and preparing a canvas, color mixing and harmonies, manipulation of paint and brush handling.  Basic painting concepts will be studied as well as various techniques and approaches used when painting by direct observation.  Subjects to be painted include still lifes, portraits, and landscapes.

column1: Basic Drawing I Course
column2: A beginning course in drawing designed for both beginners and more experienced students who need to refresh their skills.  The class will explore the media of pencil, conte, charcoal, pen and ink, and brush and wash.  Lectures will include the history of drawing and the variety of techniques available.  Drawing in studio from still life as well as outdoors will be the basis for learning the fundamentals of composition, pictorial space relationships and draftsmanship.  Students will also learn line, shape, volume, perspective and light logic.

column1: Advanced Watercolor Techniques Course
column2: This course is for those who already have established a level of comfort with the watercolor medium and who seek a new level of challenge and encouragement.  Each session students explore a different texture challenge and various technique solutions that render textured surfaces such as weathered wood, glass, metal and stone.

column1: Advanced Fast Sketching Course
column2: Advanced Fast Sketching goes beyond the basics learned in Fast Sketching, and dives into complex subject sketching. Sketches will consist of costumed figures, clothed figures, crowd and interior scenes, landscapes, drapery on figures, unusual lighting effects, and more.

column1: Advanced Fast Sketching Course
column2: Advanced Fast Sketching goes beyond the basics learned in Fast Sketching, and dives into complex subject sketching. Sketches will consist of costumed figures, clothed figures, crowd and interior scenes, landscapes, drapery on figures, unusual lighting effects, and more.

column1: Advanced Drawing Techniques Course
column2: In this class students explore the use of various drawing media, including pencil, charcoal, ink and ink wash, color pencil and scratchboard.  Projects focus on developing and improving basic skills of the artist.  Among various topics the class explores drawing styles of the masters, creating realistic texture, the importance of dramatic composition and use of color.

column1: Abstract Painting Course
column2: This course explores the various means of generating abstract imagery, conceptual approaches to non-representational painting, and different methods of paint application.  Attention is given to the development of both technique and individual expressiveness.  Studio assignments are supplemented with class discussions and slide lectures on the history of abstract painting.  Figurative painters are encouraged to attend this class as a means of enhancing their paint handling skills.  Students can work with water-based paints, acrylics, pastels or colored pencils.

column1: Writing Your Memoir with Emily Rapp Course
column2: Turning your life story into a compelling book isn’t merely recounting your adventures; you must also find an essential truth, some moment that exceeded the bounds of your previous life. We’ll take you down the path from memory to action, finding the story you not only wish to tell, but the story you must tell. Utilizing in-class readings, writing exercises and the critical examination of published work, we’ll move you ever closer to the book you’ve been trying to write. Students will also workshop up to 25 pages of their creative work in class

column1: Writing Your Life's Story Course
column2: Writing your own life story can be very rewarding, beginning with the satisfaction of telling it your way. And who knows the important events that shaped your life better than you do? What you write can entertain or inspire others and enrich your family's heritage. Through a step-by-step approach, this workshop covers the life "history" writing process from the original idea to completing a manuscript. Among the topics are giving oneself permission to write, deciding what to tell and what to withhold, finding the story beneath the surface, organizing material, researching details, revising and self-editing, and getting published.

column1: Writing Today's Mystery Course
column2: What do editors and agents look for in a publishable mystery novel, what must be in a manuscript regardless of literary quality? Discover concrete answers in the context of reviewing the essential building blocks of good craft: an effective opening; the art and craft of characterization; dialogue; point of view; description; plot dynamics; the nature and necessity of conflict, and how these elements must interact to apply to the mystery novel, with special emphasis on the fine points that lift manuscripts to a publishable level. This hands-on, nuts and bolts class includes an instructor-led peer workshop where you receive feedback, direction, and detailed checklists of what agents want and editors seek. You leave with a toolkit to apply directly to your fiction, present and future.

column1: Writing the Short Story Course
column2: A short story has its own unique structure. Using as few words as possible, the short story must satisfy a reader's expectations.
