This class, designed to explore the personality of the short story, examines topics such as: creating characters and images, plotting for maximum impact, what to tell and what to leave out, writing effective beginnings, developing atmosphere and tone, and smartly styled description. Includes looking at how overall length influences the type of story being told and how to use words in as precise a manner as possible.

column1: Writing the Opinion and Personal Essay Course
column2: Commentator and author Andy Rooney has made a living off of his opinions and author/radio personality Sandra Tsing Loh has done the same--turning what would normally be seen as mundane daily experiences into moments of witty and poignant epiphany and carving out successful careers as first-person essayists. This course helps passionate writers who have a story to tell or an opinion to share explore the many avenues of expression--from the serious and professional to the whimsical and alternative. Through writing assignments, in-class readings and discussions, students learn how to translate their personal experiences and monologues into entertaining and enlightening nonfiction prose. The class also explores how to choose a market and media for a specific piece, with detailed guidelines on how to get new, exciting material into the market place.

column1: Writing the Memoir Course
column2: Everyone has a fascinating memoir to write.  Whether your stories are for family, friends or yourself, the few simple exercises in this course help you capture those moments in vivid description.  Class discussion focuses on the structure of the memoir from beginning to end and the significance of memory, imagination and reflection.

column1: Writing the Screenplay with Mickey Birnbaum Course
column2: In this intensive screenwriting seminar, students will have the first 25 pages of their screenplays workshopped by top Hollywood screenwriter Mickey Birnbaum, while also learning the principals of the craft and examining the current marketplace for both TV and film. Students will be immersed in the full "writer's room" experience, breaking each other's stories in a professional and creative atmosphere.

column1: Writing for Television Course
column2: Screenwriting is only half of the entertainment writing equation.  In the work-a-day world of writing for the screen, television writers enjoy longer employment, greater variety of subject matter, and the opportunity to become part of the production staff as staff writers, story editors, producers and showrunners.  This class explores writing for the half-hour comedy and one-hour dramatic formats, including elements of production.  Students write an outline or beatsheet for a television pilot (your own idea for a series) or write a story/script for an ongoing television series.  Guests are invited from the industry to talk about production and writing.

column1: Writing Fantasy Fiction Course
column2: Introduction to the various forms and functions of fantasy stories, exploring how the element of "magic" affects characterization, plot and writing style.  Fantasy fiction techniques covered include developing consistent, believable characters and stories based on "impossible" premises, and constructing compelling fantasy worlds and situations. Each student writes at least one short story or a chapter of a novel. Information about manuscript format, submission procedures, agents, editors and publishers is presented.

column1: Writing a Novel Course
column2: A study of the craft of writing a novel, including proven techniques for keeping editors and readers interested.  Novel writing topics include inventing memorable characters, intricacies of good plotting, choosing an appropriate setting and atmosphere, developing an ear for the right dialogue, creating beginnings that hold the reader's attention and developing cliffhanger endings.  Among the publication issues discussed are conducting research, finding a particular audience, selecting an agent and/or publisher and preparing manuscripts for submission.

column1: Writing Children's Books Course
column2: This course helps writers hone their writing skills in the children's book field through exploring great ways to choose ideas, develop a plot and theme, revise rough drafts for a specific age group and finally put it all together to create a great new work. The first day includes in-class exercises, discussions on favorite books, books in the market and writing, lots of it.  In the second meeting, participants do cold readings of their work and receive constructive peer critiques, which is a great way for an author to hear how others hear his or her work and then revise it, OR NOT!  Among various group discussion topics the second day are marketing, contracts and selling a book to an editor,  a bookstore or a group looking for a speaker.

column1: Workshopping Your Children's Book Course
column2: Learn the tools for creating memorable characters, plot arcs, and satisfying resolutions; what the publishing industry is looking for at this time; and how to pick a publisher for your particular writing style.  Includes hand-outs on formatting children's books, professional writing organizations, and tips on finding a reputable publisher or agent.

column1: Travel Journal Writing Course
column2: Bring the sights, smells and good memories of your visit or trip back to life by keeping a good personal travel journal.  Through lecture, discussion and in-class exercises, learn how to balance specific description and insightful reflection with the "less is more" concept to enrich your travel journal entries and your experiences.

column1: Travel and Food Writing 101 Course
column2: From Anthony Bourdain to Elizabeth Gilbert to Frances Mayes, some of the most compelling writing of the last 20 years has merged two of our biggest passions: travel and food. In this intensive seminar, you will learn the skills to chronicle your favorite trips and your favorite meals for an international audience. So whether you are hiking Kilimanjaro or exploring the local diner, globetrotting writer Maggie Downs will teach you how to bring your travel story to life, how to make your local cuisine read like Zagat-rated faire, and how to tie the two together into an irresistible package. You will also get the skinny on how to get your articles published in the best magazines, newspapers, websites, and blogs around the country, and the world. You will have the opportunity to turn in 25 pages of creative work after the course.

column1: Turn Your Travels into Literary Adventures! Course
column2: New and mid-level writers will enhance their ability to turn their personal travel experiences into thought-provoking, entertaining and enlightening creative nonfiction literature or instructional material. Students gain experience through writing assignments, discussions and feedback sessions, and will learn how to select the proper market and media for their piece should they desire to publish, blog or podcast.

column1: The Art and Craft of Blogging Course
column2: Every person has something to say, a story to tell, and an experience to share. With the use of the internet, people are able to express themselves, and learn about the world through pictures, comments, videos, etc. that are shared from others. This introductory course explores format, style, topic, theme, development of voice and identity, and how to connect with and build an audience. Using a blogging and social media platform, you will build a blog reflecting your desired online presence via a thematic orientation.

column1: Scriptwriting: From Graphic Novels to Screenplays Course
column2: This course focuses on the two most popular scriptwriting styles: graphic novel (or comic book) writing and screenwriting for television and films. You will explore scriptwriting styles such as teleplays, stage plays, radio plays, comic books, commercials, and lyrics. You will examine and concentrate on basic story structure common to most scripts, while improving your writing techniques by surveying and discussing effective examples using storyboards and comics to illustrate the process of script to finished product. Mastery and understanding of how excellent scripts are created adds a multitude of tools to a writer's toolbox.

column1: Taking Your Writing to the Next Level Course
column2: Is writing fun - or a struggle? Do you sweat sentences into perfection or play with them like a puzzle? Do you think you're a good writer or not good enough? How can you tell? This course shows how to make your writing more lively by developing the skills that turn amateurs into pros. You'll learn how to plant hooks in sentences that make readers want more, eliminate clichés and word clumps, spot gaps, and discover your style. Writing is rewriting, and you'll practice being your own editor so that you'll know when it's "good enough." Bring a writing sample to class for constructive feedback.

column1: The ABC's of Getting Your Children's Book Published Course
column2: Learn the do's and don'ts of sending to an editor; which professional groups to join; how to find legal support; setting up your cover letter; and when to follow up with the editor.

column1: Screenwriting Workshop I Course
column2: You will  focus on fundamental screenwriting concepts through exercises and assignments, lecture, and film viewing.  Engage in discussions emphasizing topics such as story structure, theme, plot, characterization and dialogue; and examine successful scripts.   Individual writing goals will be set for you and outline what you should accomplish during the 10-week course.  Personalized feedback is given throughout.

column1: Screenwriting Today -- The Craft and Business Course
column2: Students get an overview of what is involved in the process of taking their idea for a movie and turning it into a tangible, compelling screenplay that could be shot into a major motion picture. Topics include screenwriting mechanics, basic story structure, and storytelling elements that are evident in successful, popular films.

column1: Research for Writers Course
column2: For writers of fiction and nonfiction, doing research is a necessary, but often challenging, part of their creative process.  Researching a topic doesn't have to be boring or frustrating.  Learn techniques for doing research efficiently and professionally so that editors, agents and supervisors see an impressive project from you, the writer.  Topics include how to find almost any fact fast, how to find and interview experts, what to do when your fact-finding hits a dead end, and alternative research methods.  Effective tips for all levels of information gathering, sample searches and individual guidance will help students discover the fun of fact-finding.

column1: Plein Air Creative Writing Course
column2: "Plein Air," French for "open air," was a popular art movement in the early nineteenth century. Between portable easels and the invention of pre-mixed oil paints, artists, for the first time, could easily work outside. So they did, capturing the light, air and beauty of the natural world to create a new way of seeing and a new art movement. Taking a cue from the Plein Air artists of both Europe and the U.S., this creative writing class finds inspiration in Riverside-area parks and gardens. Immersed in the natural world, writers will observe the landscape, focus their senses and capture the experience with deft prose pen strokes that can later be edited. The challenge, just as for the Plein Air painters, is to quickly capture a moment in time in an ever-changing world. Writers will share their work aloud in story circles and are invited to edit their workshop material to share or submit for critique. You will meet for classes at local parks for this outdoors-inspired workshop, which includes moderate hikes or walks (3 miles or less).

column1: Novel Workshop with Stephen Jay Schwartz Course
column2: In this intensive two-day seminar, you’ll learn the hallmarks of successful first novels, and have the first 25 pages of your own book workshopped in class.  We'll also examine the intersection of character and setting, the mechanics of plot, the art of dialogue, the dynamics of timing and pace, and, finally, the path to publication. We'll look at your first chapter with an eye towards where it needs to go to capture a publisher's attention, but also with the aim of giving you the tools to effectively write your entire novel.

column1: Memoir Into Fiction -- Writing the Autobiographical Novel or Story Course
column2: What do Ernest Hemingway, Jonathan Franzen and Pam Houston have in common? Each of these writers has written fiction by drawing from his or her personal experiences. This course is designed for writers whose personal stories inform their work but who are unsure how to transform them into fiction. Whether you are reluctant to tell your story in memoir for personal, or ethical reasons, or are uncertain how to create fiction out of true events, this course helps you make informed choices on how to proceed both from a technical standpoint as well as an emotional one. In addition, you learn how to create characters and develop plot lines that steer comfortably clear of true events and real people while, at the same time, evoking the truth and essence of your own real-life experiences. This class helps you learn the craft and technique of writing autobiographical fiction, as well as unravel the significance of your own stories and discern your levels of risk in the telling of them.

column1: Memoir and Personal Essay Writing Course
column2: A ten-week, self-paced online course designed to  help you learn the basics of memoir and personal essay writing. You will draw on readings and exercises from "The Situation and the Story" by Vivian Gornick, "Writing Down the Bones: Freeing the Writer Within" by Natalie Goldberg and two additional memoirs, including "The Liar's Club"by Mary Karr and "The Things They Carried" by Tim O'Brien. Your work will include weekly writing assignments of approximately two pages, critiques of other students' work, forum discussions and two-page annotations of the assigned memoirs.

column1: Marketing for Writers Course
column2: This course offers a quick way to review and improve your work, either fiction or nonfiction, covering those areas editors and publishers focus on most: viewpoint, quotes/dialogue, narrative voice, pace, and descriptive elements. The course will also focus on the actual marketing, showing writers how to approach the market through query letters, outline/synopsis, and book proposals. Writers conferences and self-publishing will also be discussed.

column1: Learn to Write Literary Nonfiction Course
column2: New and mid-level writers will enhance their ability to turn the fabric of their daily lives and histories into thought-provoking, entertaining and enlightening essays, biography, memoir and creative nonfiction literature. Students gain experience through writing assignments, discussions and feedback sessions, and will learn how to select the proper market and media for their piece should they desire to publish, blog or podcast.

column1: Introduction to Screenwriting Course
column2: Screenplay writing is a rigorous craft and, at its best, a fine art. This lecture and discussion course involves practical analysis of film and television screenplays, emphasizing on story structure, scenes, dialogue, and characterization. Successful scripts or portions thereof are used as examples; regular writing assignments are tailored to master the basics of screenwriting. Course goal is to complete an outline or treatment, and to begin writing a screenplay. Students learn the basics of screenwriting, emphasizing topics such as story structure, theme, plot, characterization and dialog. Successful scripts are used as examples. The goal of the course is to have students write a step outline and complete the first act (approximately 30 pages).

column1: Introduction to Story Analysis Course
column2: Story analysis is not film criticism, but a way of understanding and interpreting a screenplay and assessing its artistic and commercial potential as the basis for a movie.  It's unquestionably the single most important skill that anyone can have in applying for a position at a motion picture studio or production company, from entry-level jobs to the executive suite.  Knowing how to read and analyze a script is crucial for actors, writers, directors, producers, cinematographers and many more of the people who collaborate to get a movie up on the screen successfully.  What's more, story analysis is the gateway skill to the broader, more in-depth discipline of story development.  This course offers an introduction to the art and discipline of reading a motion picture screenplay, summarizing its narrative content, and evaluating its dramatic, cinematic, and commercial potential for a movie. You learn how to read and understand a motion picture story on paper, as it unfolds in a printed screenplay before that story is ever captured on film; how to describe the central idea or concept of that story; how to write a clear, engaging synopsis of the story, covering all of the story's major plot points; and how to formulate and write comments on the script as a whole that make a convincing case for or against the project's viability as a motion picture release.  An overview will be given of all aspects of conventional narrative filmmaking by way of in-class film screenings, readings of screenplays for existing movies and discussions of class materials. A class project will apply this knowledge to the writing a story analysis for two movies, including one voted on by the class.

column1: Introduction to the Graphic Novel Course
column2: Almost every sort of story can be told as a graphic novel, which is often described as the comic book's grown-up offspring.  From the daily strip in the paper to the most acclaimed graphic novels, this literary form can be a rich, diverse storytelling medium.  In a workshop environment, learn the basics of graphic novel creation through in-class readings, story revision, plot layout, pacing of action, and development of dialogue and narrative sequences.  Students create a mock book of their story that includes hand-drawn scenes or cuttings from other sources such as magazines.

column1: Introduction to Getting Published Course
column2: Forget the horror stories you've heard about how agents and editors only sign experienced writers and won't read your query letter unless you've got a track record. Not true. You can break the fear barrier and develop a personal game plan for getting published. This one-day crash course helps you play the publishing game like a pro and brings you up to speed with the self-publishing revolution, as we examine the pros and cons of independent publishing vs. mainstream. Enter the world of working writers: Learn how agents and editors think and how to handle writer's block and fear of rejection. You'll also learn how to write a powerful query letter, the elements of a book proposal, common mistakes new writers make, and whether "indie," academic, or mainstream publishing is best for you. You'll leave knowing the secrets and shortcuts to getting published and, most important, believing you can and will get published.

column1: Idea Into Action: Creating Dynamic Characters and Dialog Course
column2: The essence of drama is that humans, unlike any other animals, are incapable of escaping the consequences of their actions. In fiction, as in real life, characters are faced with important decisions and it is in those small moments of emotion that a character is defined, a voice is created, and a plot unfolds. This course explores the fundamentals of creating dynamic characters and realistic dialog that both drives the central conflict of your story and turns mere idea into action. Through targeted readings of both contemporary and classic works, in-class writing, assigned writing and exploration of key craft issues and techniques (as well as in-depth analysis of student work), each student will develop their own particular voice; have their work read by others; and will have a firm grasp of how characters think, what creates their logic, and how their personalities manifest themselves in dialog.

column1: Introduction to Creative Nonfiction Course
column2: Students in this course learn to use fiction techniques, such as dramatic scene, image, voice, story movement and point of view, for writing creative nonfiction.  Students enhance their writing skills through the critical reading and writing of creative nonfiction.  The course -- consisting of instruction, discussion and critique sessions -- offers students an opportunity to write creatively in several nonfiction formats including literary journalism, memoirs and essays.  Students develop dramatic, true stories using scenes, dialogue, detail and research of their chosen subjects. Weekly critique sessions refine and polish the works for either publication or personal satisfaction.

column1: Idea into Action: A Fiction Writer's Toolbox Course
column2: In this intensive seminar, award-winning writer Mary Yukari Waters will guide you over the craft hurdles which often trip up writers - from clunky dialog to ineffective description to narrative incoherence, and all points in between - and then shows you how to fix those very problems, so your story can shine through. Using in-class exercises, readings, lectures, and group discussions, this two-day seminar will help you see your problems before they happen and guide you through the first draft of your story toward success.  Writers in this seminar should come to the class with an idea, and be prepared to leave with a better one.  You will have the opportunity to turn in 25 pages of creative work after the course.

column1: History, Presence, and Writing from Famous Local Desert Authors Course
column2: Explore the many influences which have shaped the writings of authors such as Ray Bradbury, George Englund, Cloris Leachman and Mary Sheldon.  You will study their journeys as writers living in the Coachella Valley.  Through discussions, readings, and film clips, you will learn about the art of their writings, what inspired them, and the impact of their work on the community.

column1: Grant Writing for Artists and Arts Managers Course
column2: In this overview, students learn the critical parts that make up a successful grant proposal. With a focus on the importance of nomenclature, impact and artistic quality, the course examines a range of topics, including the use of the funds, how and when to collaborate, getting support letters, creating a budget and following up once the grant is funded. Sample projects and draft proposals are done in class as a group activity. The course should benefit development professionals (both nonprofits and arts nonprofits), volunteers for arts organizations and artists.

column1: Getting Started:  Building the Character, Conflict and Setting Course
column2: Learn techniques and exercises for creating in-depth characters, attention-grabbing conflict, and detailed settings in your stories.  Study popular techniques for pulling the reader in and practice them through dialogue exercises; poetry and in-depth character study;  and group collaboration and critique.  Explore various genres to determine how the mood of the story affects its characters, conflict and setting.

column1: Freeing Your Creativity Course
column2: This ten-week, self-paced online course shows you how to re-ignite your creative and artistic spirits. Readings from Julia Cameron's "The Artist's Way" and Michael Gelb's "How to Think Like Leonardo da Vinci" will help you identify and overcome creative blocks, all while engaging in whole-brain thinking. Students also create collages to envision and pursue creative dreams. Online discussions and short writing assignments about students' experiences included.

column1: Finding Your Poet Voice Course
column2: Take your poetry from your notebook to the pages of top magazines in this intensive workshop with internationally-acclaimed poet Anthony McCann. This weekend-long course will introduce a variety of methods to seek out, deepen and maintain poetic inspiration, while also paying special attention to crafting that inspiration into rich, strong, affecting language on the page. You will be provided with a wide range of sample reading in contemporary and modern poetry, as well as a wild range of poetry exercises and pre-writing activities to stimulate new work of your own. We will not just theorize about how to write poems, we will be writing poems. Lots of poems.  You can expect to have drafts of at least four new poems by the end of the weekend, along with notes and exercises to help you build many more poems in the days, weeks, and months following the course. The class is designed for students of multiple levels; writers who are very new to poetry will feel just as welcome and engaged as writers who have been working in poetry for some time.

column1: Fiction Workshop Course
column2: This workshop gives writers guidance on works in progress. Each week students bring in pages from short stories or novel chapters. The works are read and critiqued for structure, style, basic writing techniques and rewriting. Critiquing is done in a constructive, supportive and encouraging manner. Emphasis is on the process of rewriting and how progress, from first drafts to finished product, is accomplished. Individual writing goals are set for each student to determine what they should accomplish during the course.

column1: Fiction of Place Course
column2: This course will explore the variety of forms and techniques used in writing fiction of place. Special attention will be placed on writers who depict their hometown or home region as they capture the specificity of that place, including its history; what makes it unique and how that difference affects their understanding of the world. In the first session, the class will develop its own definition of place, in all areas (for example, its importance to people, impact on a person's understanding of how to interact with the world, etc.) before exploring this definition as a means to evaluate and analyze assigned diverse novel excerpts and short stories.

column1: Feature Film Writing: Women on the American Movie Screen Course
column2: Experience a fast-moving, highly entertaining look at the history of women in American movies.  You will study them not from a perspective of film history or appreciation, but as a tool for writing movies about women - as protagonists, supporting characters, heroes or villains.  Designed for aspiring and experienced screenwriters, moviegoers, movie lovers, and anyone who has a strong personal or professional interest in the movies. Film screenings include; A Bill of Divorcement or Alice Adams, Funny Face, An Unmarried Woman, The Devil Wears Prada, and either The Help or Black Swan.

column1: Dialogue Workshop: Creating Memorable Voices Course
column2: This workshop is designed for students of fiction, nonfiction and screenwriting, to refine their skills of writing creative, memorable dialogue. Reading and writing assignments will illuminate techniques of dialogue writing not often studied on their own.

column1: Creative Writing for Young Adults Course
column2: You will  study and practice the basic elements of creative writing, including character development, setting, dialogue, and plot.  You will also explore and analyze the genres of Young Adult Literature, Poetry, and Children's Literature in order to help you shape and define your own writing style.  As a final project, you will be asked to submit a short piece of writing for publication in the course newsletter.

column1: Creative Nonfiction Workshop Course
column2: Designed for students who understand the fundamentals of creative nonfiction, this class provides guidance on works in progress.  Each week students bring in pages from a creative nonfiction project, such as book chapters or a magazine article, which will be critiqued for structure, writing technique and style.  Critiquing is done in a constructive, supportive and encouraging manner, and student work is used to illustrate advanced techniques.  Emphasis is on the process of rewriting and how progress, from first drafts to finished product, is accomplished.  Individual writing goals are set for each student on what should be accomplished during the 10-week course.

column1: Creating Realistic Characters Course
column2: Great stories have one thing in common: memorable and realistic characters. This workshop focuses solely on character development in fiction, using physical description, attitude, thought, dialogue, and inner change/realization. Weekly writing exercises help students bring their characters to life.

column1: Content Writing and Promotion for Social Media Course
column2: Geared to anyone who has an interest in writing content online from articles to websites and blogs. Learn the ropes of Internet hit-producing content, search engine optimization, HTML, keyword selection, file-naming, photo selection, caption/sidebar writing and more.  You complete writing assignments with the goal of Internet publication and obtaining quality sample work to submit to possible employers.

column1: Children's Book Illustration Course
column2: In this class, you'll learn the process of writing and illustrating a children's book. Cover story ideation, refining the story, using drawing/storyboards to write and pace your story, character design, staging, environment stylization, roughs to final, from type placement to creating a dummy, and shopping the book to publishers. In-class activities include creating a storyboard, character design, and designing a book dummy. You will have one-on-one instructor assistance in an artistic environment. All experience levels are welcome.

column1: Beginning Fiction Techniques Course
column2: This class covers basic writing techniques and how to use them for novels and short stories.  Lecture topics include the who, what, when, where, why and how of writing; dramatic hooks that grab the reader; character revelation through basic traits, actions and speech; and plot dynamics.  Dialogue, conflict, narration, viewpoint and style will also be covered.  Students will have weekly assignments, both in and out of class.

column1: Alternative Publishing and Self-Publishing Course
column2: Learn the facts about the publishing opportunities available including small presses and the Internet for any kind of work such as poems, novels, nonfiction, short stories or essays. This class shows you how to weigh your options when deciding to be published or self-published, to post your work on the Internet for others to see and critique or to create a POD formatted book. Writing assignments, lectures and discussions cover what it means to be a self-publisher, the publication process, the differences in publishing houses and their expectations and the challenges of publishing different mediums. Students receive information and website links regarding how to market and sell your work once it has been published.

column1: Building a Play: An Introduction to Writing for the Stage Course
column2: An elective in the study and practice of playwriting, this course covers the principles of story-telling and how dialogue can advance plot. Learn the basics of building a play's foundation, and how to construct character, beats of action, dialogue, and stage direction that will manifest in the draft of a 10-minute play to be work-shopped in class. You will also learn about the art of "pitching" a play to and working with a theatre company, as well as various other aspects of a playwright's career.

column1: Window Treatments -- Draperies, Shades, Blinds and Shutters Course
column2: A basic study of various aspects of window coverings--designing, measuring, materials, pricing and sources. Step-by-step formulas for hard and soft treatments are explored. Problem-solving exercises are used to learn the principles of measurement and calculation.

column1: Video Game Design, Development and Production Workshop Course
column2: Ideal for those who have completed UCR Extension’s Video Game Design and Content Creation Summer Academy, this program further enhances the artistic skills and technical techniques required for many aspects of video game creation and development. You will learn both the intermediate and advanced principles of video game ready code and art including modeling, texturing, and animation through the use of Autodesk Maya, Adobe Photoshop, and the Unity 3D Game Engine. Geared for those interested in developing a specialization pertaining to the creation, refinement, and optimization of existing video game assets and code elements, you will gain experience in working in teams leading to creating a functioning video game.

column1: Textile Design: History, Design and Construction of Fibers and Fabrics Course
column2: Study of textile history, design and technology.  Topics cover the classification and properties of fibers, types of weaves, dyeing and printing processes, and specific problems in the uses of natural and synthetic fibers.  Emphasis is on the proper selection of textiles for use in residential and commercial interiors.

column1: The Arts and Crafts Movement in Southern California: Architecture, Interiors, and Decorative Design Course
column2: Highlighting architecture, furniture, painting, textile design, metal work, and fashion, students will take part in an illustrated lecture and field trip to Pasadena to explore the arts and crafts movement that flourished in Southern California during the early 1900s. The architecture and furnishings of brothers Charles and Henry Greene, and furniture designs by Gustav Stickley, will also be highlighted during a walking tour that will include a visit to the Gamble House.

column1: Sustainable Interior Design Course
column2: Teaches designers and consumers the fundamental principles and benefits of sustainable interior design. Designed to equip you with a systematic strategy for assessing the degree of sustainability and cost effectiveness of green design products. A thorough exploration of eco-friendly materials, energy saving appliances, and their sources will be covered. You will come away with an in-depth understanding of sustainability and detailed knowledge about green products which will enable you to create beautiful home environments that are healthier for our earth and those that inhabit the space.

column1: Space Planning Course
column2: This course introduces students to the methodology used by interior designers to plan and creatively organize residential and commercial space. Emphasis is on understanding and creating design solutions that incorporate given parameters, such as building codes, architectural limitations, and client considerations. Students plan and develop several layouts applying these principles.

column1: Residential Interior Design Course
column2: Study of residential interior design projects from conceptualization to installation.  Covers analysis of client needs, space utilization, color and texture coordination and selection and design of furnishings. Student projects include designing and presenting a residential space.

column1: Refining Your Images in Photoshop Course
column2: Successful fine-art photos begin with a great camera capture, but many software techniques can help to clarify an image's visual message. This class explores the ways that photographers use Adobe software to enhance a digital photograph's brightness, contrast, color and especially its overall impact.

column1: Publishing with InDesign Course
column2: This course is designed to expand your existing InDesign layout skills, and to apply them directly in production within the expanding industry of Epub publishing. With the ever-increasing popularity of the Epub, it is essential that the professional designer is knowledgeable and skillful enough to create this essential interface. Students will learn how to design layouts that can be exported into Epub fixed and/or liquid layouts.

column1: Professional Resources for Interior Designers Course
column2: Gain a better understanding of how local design showrooms and vendors work with designers. Learn about the wealth of products that are available to local designers without traveling to Los Angeles or Orange County Design Centers. Includes tours of local Interior Design showrooms and workrooms.

column1: Perspective Drawing Course
column2: Learn how to draw both one-point and two-point perspective drawings of interiors. Also, learn how to replicate objects you see on to paper. These are essential skills for designers to be able to communicate ideas to clients.

column1: Patio Design Course
column2: Step-by-step instructions to plan the perfect patio, quickly and easily. Learn simple design tricks and techniques to take your design ideas from conception to execution. A review and application of design concepts will include choosing the right location, building materials, furniture and other features that will suit your lifestyle needs.

column1: Materials and Resources for Interior Design Course
column2: A basic problem-solving course on locating and selecting interior components. Main topics include elements of wearability and content of materials and furnishings, and main resource centers for designers.

column1: Kitchen and Bath Design Course
column2: Learn how to coordinate, plan, and implement designs for kitchen and bath areas.  Includes an overview of electrical components, plumbing, and furnishing materials.  You will discuss, in detail:  cabinetry, wood, construction, appliances, countertops and tiles.

column1: Introduction to Interior Design Course
column2: A practical introduction to the basic principles of interior design and an overview of the requirements for a comfortable, functioning and aesthetically pleasing environment. Main topics are design principles and elements, beginning space planning, lighting, color and surface treatments.

column1: Introduction to Logo Design and Brand Development Course
column2: An introductory course designed to help you develop creative skills in concept development for logo design and general branding. You will work from thumbnails in a sketchbook to converting concepts into digital renditions using Adobe Creative Suite, primarily Adobe Illustrator. In addition, ongoing discussions about logo use and branding issues will be the norm. Most areas of branding will be discussed, including: for products, institutions, non-profit organizations etc

column1: Introduction to Game Programming Course
column2: Students will learn the basic features of Unity through hands-on experiences with scripting in C#. This course will cover the Unity Engine and editor, building basic scenes, creating gameplay with scripts, accessing pre-defined components from scripts, debugging in Unity and MonoDevelop. Unity basics include interface, workspace customization, asset workflow, and creating scenes.  Scripting basics include debugging in Unity and MonoDevelop, as well as accessing scripts and components, and instantiation.

column1: Introduction to Game Design Course
column2: Students will learn game design fundamentals through an introduction to Unity. In-depth presentations will cover the Unity Engine and Interface, building basic scenes, and creating gameplay using pre-defined components. Unity basics include interface, workspace customization, asset workflow, and creating scenes.  Building scene basics includes game objects, prefabs, lights, and cameras. Creating gameplay explores rigid bodies, colliders, meshes, and GUI. Scripting will not be covered in this course

column1: Introduction to Furniture Design Course
column2: Today, many designers are creating and selling custom furnishings of their own. An introduction to the world of furniture design. You will receive personal tours of A-list furniture showrooms in the West Hollywood Design District, and learn about furniture manufacturing and current trends in the industry. Additionally, you receive an introductory lesson on how to draw and prepare production-ready furniture working drawings for custom case goods and upholstery.

column1: Introduction to Digital Arts and Graphic Design Course
column2: This five-week workshop is designed for individuals who want to create visual and innovative communication solutions using graphic elements. Workshop topics and hands-on activities focus on fundamental design production processes; the role of the professional visual communicator; design unification of diverse elements; color theory; typography; and a comprehensive introduction to the primary Adobe design software programs including Illustrator, InDesign, Photoshop, and Acrobat. Delivered in a hybrid format combining in-class and online learning modules, students will learn how basic design concepts and software interface to create an effective and efficient design environment. Production will include graphic collaterals focused on the web and print media. A capstone project displaying a comprehensive layout and design project is required upon completion.

column1: Introduction to Color Rendering Techniques Course
column2: This course covers marker illustration techniques which can be applied to architectural perspective drawings, floor plans, and elevations. Through the use of markers, colored pencils and pastels, students will create visually pleasing drawings which will can be used to convey a design concept, sell an interior design project, or for the purpose of artistic illustration.

column1: Interior Design: Selling at the Retail Level Course
column2: Many students who study interior design begin their careers at the retail level in order to gain practical experience in the field. This course provides aspiring interior designers an overview of selling interior design products at the retail level. Learn how to build relationships and long-term partnerships with clients, how to quickly assess a client's needs, how to clearly communicate with customers based on their personality type, how to proactively follow up, and ultimately how to ask for referrals. at a retail furniture showroom where students are given a design assignment to complete on-site to gain practical experience.

column1: Introduction to Art for Games Course
column2: Students will learn the basic principles of how to create a video game-ready art asset. This process will cover the basics of the modeling, texturing and animation processes using Autodesk Maya and Adobe Photoshop, with implementation into the Unity Game engine.

column1: Interior Design Internship Course
column2: Student Interns will work closely with the Interior Design Program Internship Coordinator to apply classroom lessons to on-the-job assignments to develop proficiency in completing various design tasks through the placement at an internship site. Students can expect to benefit from real-life exposure to site-based resource libraries, trade relations, catalogs, showrooms, working drawings, and more. Interns must attend all scheduled class meetings and scheduled work hours at an approved internship site for a minimum of 90 hours, participate in online forums, submit weekly journals, and complete a final paper. All internship sites have been approved by the Department of Interior Design and Interior Design Program Internship Coordinator to ensure that all activities, tasks, and responsibilities are appropriate for this course. The Interior Design Program Internship Coordinator is an Academic Senate-approved Interior Design instructor for UCR Extension.

column1: Information Session: Introduction to Digital Arts and Graphic Design Course
column2:
Attend a FREE Information Session to learn about UCR Extension’s new Introduction to Digital Arts and Graphic Design Hybrid workshop. If you are looking to start or continue a career in the creative art field, this workshop is for you! The Information Session will cover:
  • What is Digital Arts and Graphic Design?
  • Who is this program for?
  • What do we teach?
  • Course format, dates, location and cost

column1: Intensive Training Workshops in Computer Animation: Studies in Adobe Flash Course
column2: Adobe Flash is the acclaimed professional software for integrating motion, sound, and interactivity for entertainment production applications including web, professional-quality animated cartoons for broadcast and Computer Video Games.  In this sequential 5-part workshop series, you will develop skills and gain valuable insights into Flash's unique animation capabilities. Hands-on activities include vector character drawing, setting characters in motion using a variety of Flash attributes and techniques, designing coordinated scenery and background wallpaper, and synchronizing sound, music and spoken dialogue. The program also addresses important aspects of storyboarding, character interpretation and analyzing storylines.

column1: History of Architectural Interiors I Course
column2: Survey historical interiors from antiquity through the 17th century including ancient Egypt, Greece and Rome; the Middle Ages; the Renaissance; and Europe. Examine the decorative arts and the historical and social events of the period.

column1: History of Architectural Interiors and Furniture II Course
column2: Survey of historical interiors from the 17th century to the present, including English, American and contemporary periods, with focus on styles. Participants will study architecture and interior design and their relation to the decorative arts.

column1: Environmental and Human Factors in Design Course
column2: This class introduces the student to environmental factors in design and to the psychology of human behavior as it pertains to space planning, privacy and mental health at both the individual and group levels. Understanding and analyzing the relationship between environment and design will be emphasized.

column1: Entertainment Design Information Session Course
column2: Attend a free information session to learn about UCR Extensions Specialized workshop in Entertainment Design. Having an artist's imagination is helpful but getting the skills and competencies to start or advance your creative career is indispensable. Come and learn about the creative workshops in digital graphics, animation, and learn about the new media that can take you to the next step in your creative development.

column1: Drawing with Illustrator Course
column2: Adobe Illustrator CS5 is the industry-standard professional vector drawing program. Learn step-by-step production processes for creating original industry-compatible illustrations. Explore Illustrator's precision drawing and transformation tools for creating and editing Bézier curves, color, gradients, gradient mesh, patterns, transparency, type, layers, and more. Interface your illustrative work with Photoshop and rasterize for further creative enhancement with the entire Creative suite, Dreamweaver or InDesign.

column1: Drafting II Course
column2: This course expands upon topics covered in Drafting I. Topics pertinent to architectural drawing are introduced, including electrical plans, section elevations, detail drawings and document presentation. Students put these lessons into practice as they design their own residential or commercial spaces. Upon completion students will have created a full set of design construction documents for their professional portfolios.

column1: Digital Media: Introduction to Graphic Design Course
column2: A comprehensive, online overview of the Digital Media industry, allowing students to make informed decisions about their compatibility and interest in this field of study. Instruction will explore the production sequence from Concept to Output, including:  utilizing contemporary processes of computer and file management, file formats, image resolution, color modes, Adobe Creative Suite software usage and page layout as it relates to digital media and visual communication.

column1: Drafting I Course
column2: An introduction to basic architectural drawing techniques and skills. Students learn how to use drafting tools such as parallel rulers, architectural scales, triangles and drafting boards. Emphasis is on practice and development of proper drafting technique and skill. Topics include lettering, space and furniture plans, elevations, legends and perspective drawing. Students complete a set of drawings to add to their portfolios.

column1: Designing With Light Course
column2: This course covers lighting systems in both residential and commercial spaces, with emphasis on residential lighting. Topics include focal lighting, light sources, fixture schedules, switching patterns and the required drawings used by designers. Instruction includes lectures, research and student projects.

column1: Design and Create Interactive PDFs and E-Pubs Using Adobe InDesign Course
column2: Creating ePublications, as well as interactive documents with hyperlinks and embedded video, is fun and useful given today's explosion of hand-helds, I-pads, tablets and remote presentation. Learn how to design interactive documents and ePubs using Adobe InDesign CS6 and add interactivity to PDF files.

column1: Computer Animation: Studies in Adobe Flash Information Session Course
column2: Attend a informational session to learn about UCR Extension's Computer Animation: Studies in Adobe Flash.  If you are looking to break into this creative field to develop skills and gain valuable insights into Flash's unique animation capabilities, this in-depth program is for you.  Program offers approximately 40 hours of professional level instruction and features small class sizes.

column1: Commercial Interior Design Course
column2: In this class participants design a small professional/commercial space. Topics incorporate the design process and business practices from the beginning programming phase, design implementation, to the product specifications. Design process skills are emphasized, as well as the creative aspect of design.

column1: CAD for Interior Design, Part II Course
column2: This course focuses on residential room layout, composition, planning, and architecture design, including ADA considerations. The course content is designed to enhance Computer-Aided Design drafting skills geared for Interior Designers.

column1: Color Theory and Its Application Course
column2: This course covers all aspects of Color Theory in order to show students how to create harmonious color schemes in art and design. Lectures and lab exercise offer in-depth exploration of color interaction, color characteristics, and color mixing. Additional lessons in color psychology and symbolism help students make informed decisions regarding color placement. Whether taking the course for personal enrichment or to build upon professional design skills, all students will come away from the course with a more sensitive and discriminating eye for color.

column1: Business Practices for Interior Designers Course
column2: Survey of business principles and practices for interior design professionals. Topics include customer relations, cost estimating and buying concepts, the psychology of sales, government standards, designers' fees, writing contracts and sources of supplies and information.

column1: Building Codes Course
column2: This class introduces various building codes that the professional designer must comply with for all building types. Building codes affect almost every aspect of design, including the size of a structure, the location of windows, exits and the types of finishes that may be installed. The primary focus will be on the uniform building code and barrier free (handicap) design. Students will learn the various codes and their applicability to different building types.

column1: Advanced Digital Illustration with Adobe Illustrator Course
column2: Adobe Illustrator is a powerful tool for creating distinctive artwork. Through class demonstrations and "hands on" exercises, you will learn the advanced features of this vector-based drawing software, and techniques for creating beautiful and compelling illustration--essential to both digital designers and fine artists. You focus on how to best achieve effective visual communication through increasingly challenging design for print, web and motion graphics. Optimum performance in creating successful logo design, illustration, gradient mesh effects, transparency and opacity, masking, vector animation for shockwave export, and the use of filters will be explored. The creative process will be analyzed in a very understandable step-by-step technique.

column1: Advanced Design Collaterals Course
column2: This course is specifically designed for advanced users of the Adobe Creative Suite who also know the principles of design and visual communication. Students will improve their digital media skills through the production of a series of print collaterals utilizing the complete Creative Suite in a variety of challenging ways. Upon completion, students will have developed several refined layout projects suitable for inclusion into their professional portfolios.

column1: Adobe Lightroom Essentials Course
column2: Lightroom by Adobe is a powerful new photographic workflow application designed to help amateur or professional photographers expand their creative potential. This online course is about using this revolutionary new tool and how to make use of its full potential, particularly in dealing the sheer volume of images that result from shooting digitally. Explore browsing, organizing, and adjusting images in Lightroom in order to improve photo management, processing, and presentation.  Simplifying this process allows photographers of all ability levels to focus on what is most important: the photo!

column1: 2-D Design Course
column2: This course introduces you to the art elements of line, shape, space, value, texture, color,  and form and to the principles of 2-D design. You will explore design concepts through visual analysis, problem-solving projects, and presentation.

column1: Spanish Reading and Writing Skills for Bilingual Interpreters Course
column2: This course assists Spanish language speakers, who are at a high-intermediate proficiency level, in developing their reading comprehension, written and oral abilities. Instruction includes an emphasis on writing Spanish using appropriate vocabulary, syntax, stylistic patterns and grammar tenses. In-class activities include discussion of writing assignments and vocabulary development. The course should also benefit individuals who are pursuing interpreting and translation professions and want to strengthen their writing and translation skills.

column1: The U.S. Court System: An Overview for Legal Interpreters Course
column2: A general survey of criminal and civil courts and the various jurisdictions in which they operate. Explores basic legal concepts such as constitutional rights and search and seizure. Includes statutes and codes that court interpreters often encounter and discussion of related systems such as the probation departments and law enforcement agencies.

column1: Simultaneous Interpretation for Interpreters and Translators Course
column2: Students enrolled in this course will learn the basics about simultaneous interpretation. During every class meeting student will rehearse on parallel skills that simultaneous interpreters need. These parallel skills include, speaking, listening, and organizing memory. Students will be given opportunities in class to rationally interpret parts of audios, discuss the difficulties, and provide suggestions. This course also focuses on simultaneous translation during the jury selection process.

column1: Simultaneous Interpretation Course
column2: Students enrolled in this course will learn the basics about simultaneous interpretation. During every class meeting student will rehearse on parallel skills that simultaneous interpreters need. These parallel skills include, speaking, listening, and organizing memory. Students will be given opportunities in class to rationally interpret parts of audios, discuss the difficulties, and provide suggestions. This course also focuses on simultaneous translation during the jury selection process.

column1: Sight Translation for Translators and Interpreters Course
column2: Sight interpretation and translation concepts will be used to assess the ability to comprehend written text in one language and the ability to produce an oral or signed rendition in another language. Sight translation will be implemented as a pedagogical tool to enhance students acquisition of translation and interpretation skills. Students will develop advanced sight translating skills through practice. Emphasis in this course will be placed on the general rules that recommend strict limits on the length and complexity of the documents that interpreters must sight translate. Students in this course will learn about the abilities to; translate a text in the allotted time, deal with unfamiliar words, self-correct, and how to avoid verbal literal translations.

column1: Simultaneous Interpretation Course
column2: Emphasizes simultaneous interpretation, a technique used in judicial proceedings. Shadowing, decalage and other memory retention techniques will be covered to help the student acquire the flow, register, target language grammar and vocabulary necessary for a professional level of interpreting. Lab work will be stressed.

column1: Sight Translation:  English to Spanish Course
column2: This course emphasizes the acquisition of appropriate Spanish to English vocabulary and translation skills used in criminal and civil court matters. Sight translation is stressed. Materials are drawn from areas that include constitutional rights, jury instructions, penal and vehicle codes, arraignments, pleas and waivers, workers' compensation, depositions and other civil proceedings. Students are required to learn glossaries.

column1: Sight Translation for Interpreters and Translators Course
column2: Sight interpretation and translation concepts will be used to assess the ability to comprehend written text in one language and the ability to produce an oral or signed rendition in another language. Sight translation will be implemented as a pedagogical tool to enhance students acquisition of translation and interpretation skills. Students will develop advanced sight translating skills through practice. Emphasis in this course will be placed on the general rules that recommend strict limits on the length and complexity of the documents that interpreters must sight translate. Students in this course will learn about the abilities to; translate a text in the allotted time, deal with unfamiliar words, self-correct, and how to avoid verbal literal translations.

column1: Professional Interpreting: Protocol and Ethics Course
column2: Focuses on ethical principles and standards in the interpreting profession. Complete and accurate interpretation, impartiality, confidentiality, dress code, preparedness, conflicts of interest and the interpreters' code of professional ethics will be covered. Methods of instruction include discussion, role playing, text readings and courtroom observations.

column1: Professional Certificate in Interpretation and Translation - English/Spanish: Information Session Course
column2: An overview of the Professional Interpretation and Translation Certificate Program offered through UCR Extension. Learn about the field of professional interpretation and translation including career paths and specializations, education levels, job requirements, skill sets, and responsibilities. If you are looking to break into the field of interpretation and translation, this program is for you. Program offers approximately 200 hours of professional level instruction.

column1: Qualifying Admission Exam for the Professional Certificate in  Interpretation and Translation: English/Spanish Course
column2: Applicants for the Professional Certificate in Interpretation and Translation English-Spanish program must successfully pass the Qualifying Admission Exam for the Professional Certificate in Interpretation and Translation: English-Spanish prior to enrolling in either certificate program. Admission to the program will be based on an assessment of your language skills in English and Spanish. The exam will test your knowledge of vocabulary, reading, comprehension, spelling and grammar, as well as the ability to complete college-level coursework. Please visit our website for a list of materials you should submit on or before your exam. Note: Graduates of the Professional Certificate in Interpretation and Translation English-Spanish program, and/or experienced professionals working in the Interpretation and Translation field for more than two years, may be given special permission from the department to be exempt from taking the admissions exam.

column1: Note-Taking: Skill Builder for Interpreters Course
column2: This workshop provides an introduction and step-by-step guide to the skill of note-taking across language combinations which forms an essential part of consecutive interpreting. Developing a system for note-taking skill takes time, practice and a general understanding of the underlying structure of language itself. You will be guided through a range of note-taking strategies, such as the use of symbols, abbreviations, and layout on the note-taking pad and how to establish a framework for developing a personal note-taking system.

column1: Medical Terminology Course
column2: The Medical Terminology English-Spanish course will teach students how to understand common medical terms and meanings by breaking down the words in prefix, root word and suffix.  Students will learn the most common medical terms, the various body systems, diagnostic and therapeutic procedures. Students will learn how to manage an interpreting session and interpret accurately without omitting, adding or changing the meaning of the conveyed message in order to increase the quality of patient care.

column1: Medical Terminology Course
column2: The Medical Terminology English-Spanish course will teach students how to understand common medical terms and meanings by breaking down the words in prefix, root word and suffix. Students will learn the most common medical terms, the various body systems, diagnostic and therapeutic procedures. Students will learn how to manage an interpreting session and interpret accurately without omitting, adding or changing the meaning of the conveyed message in order to increase the quality of patient care.

column1: Medical Interpretation Course
column2: The Medical Interpreting Course will introduce the bilingual and bicultural individual to a description of the Limited English Proficient (LEP) Population. It will focus on the distribution in the U.S., including barriers, challenges, and benefits of providing language services to this group. Federal mandates to provide Language Access Services will be studied in detailed. The course will also cover the modes and roles of interpretation, how to manage a session, medical interpreting code of ethics, cultural competency and introduction to medical terminology.

column1: Introduction to Legal Interpretation and Sight Translation Course
column2: This course is designed to introduce students to the legal setting. Students will gain basic understanding of legal terminology, ethics, and procedures. This course will cover the topics of interpreter qualifications and professional responsibilities. Learning material and class exercises simulate real life experiences and current events.

column1: Introduction to Medical Interpretation Course
column2: This introductory course is intended for individuals with fluent language skills in Spanish and English within the health care field who are utilized as interpreters as part of their jobs and/or are seeking to attain certification or employment as interpreters. Lessons will include interpretation theory and technique, as well as medical terminology and vocabulary in Spanish and English. Participants will develop skills to sight translate and interpret basic health related documents and discussions and apply professional ethics and standards of practice to common health care interpreting situations.

column1: Medical Interpretation Course
column2: The Medical Interpreting Course will introduce the bilingual and bicultural individual to a description of the Limited English Proficient (LEP) Population. It will focus on the distribution in the U.S., including barriers, challenges, and benefits of providing language services to this group. Federal mandates to provide Language Access Services will be studied in detailed.  The course will also cover the modes and roles of interpretation, how to manage a session, medical interpreting code of ethics, cultural competency and introduction to medical terminology.

column1: Medical Document Translation Workshop: English and Spanish Course
column2: This workshop is for individuals who are fluent in Spanish and English and who wish to improve their skills in written translation for the health care professions. Lessons include introductory translation theory and technique, common errors in English and Spanish, computer-assisted research skills, text analysis, reviewing, proofreading and editing. Participants work individually and in groups to prepare translations of typical health-related documents in both languages.

column1: Introduction to Legal Interpretation Course
column2: This course provides the tools necessary to begin the journey into the rewarding and in-demand profession of Legal Interpretation. Students learn essential study techniques, as well as the three basic skills of court interpreting: sight translation, consecutive and simultaneous interpretation. Class discussions cover important legal concepts surrounding the U.S. court system, including the role of the interpreter, ethics, professional profile, job market, pay scales, professional organizations, the private sector and preparation to take the state certification exam.

column1: Introduction to Legal Interpretation and Sight Translation Course
column2: This course is designed to introduce students to the legal setting. Students will gain basic understanding of legal terminology, ethics, and procedures. This course will cover the topics of interpreter qualifications and professional responsibilities. Learning material and class exercises simulate real life experiences and current events.

column1: Introduction to Legal Interpretation Course
column2: This course provides the tools necessary to begin the journey into the rewarding and in-demand profession of Legal Interpretation. Students learn essential study techniques, as well as the three basic skills of court interpreting: sight translation, consecutive, and simultaneous interpretation. Class discussions cover important legal concepts surrounding the U.S. court system, including the role of the interpreter, ethics, professional profile, job market, pay scales, professional organizations, the private sector, and preparation to take the state certification exam.

column1: Intermediate Spanish Grammar for Interpreters and Translators Course
column2: Intended for bilingual students preparing to develop language skills for use in professions that require bilingual fluency, such as court interpreting and professional translation. A study of the rules of Spanish grammar. Topics include Greek and Latin prefixes as they pertain to Spanish words, parts of speech, sentence and paragraph structure, and translation units.

column1: Intermediate Principles and Methodologies of Translation Course
column2: You develop intermediate language proficiency by further applying the theories and methods of translation and the practical elements of the five core translation competencies. (1) The personal competencies, technical (2) tools, and (3) reading competency continues to be covered, but emphasis is placed on (4) bilingual writing, including diverse register and styles; bilingual writing mechanics; and dealing with language interference. Also, you begin to (5) translate moderately difficult texts with accuracy and completeness.

column1: Ethics and Legal Court Proceedings Course
column2: In this class, students will become familiar with ethical standards for interpreters. They will also become acquainted with criminal court, civil, juvenile, family, small claims, and other court procedures. Students will understand how the court system works and what role the interpreter has in the court system. The Professional Standards and Ethics for California Court Interpreters, established by the Judicial Council of California, will be used as a guide outlining the specific rules. Proper behavior, moral standards, and ethical practices an interpreter must follow when working in any field of interpretation.

column1: Ethics and Legal Court Proceedings Course
column2: In this class, student will become familiar with ethical standards for interpreters. They will also become acquainted with criminal court, civil, juvenile, family, small claims, and other court procedures. Students will understand how the court system works and what role the interpreter has in the court system.  The Professional Standards and Ethics for California Court Interpreters, established by the Judicial Council of California, will be used as a guide outlining the specific rules. Proper behavior, moral standards, and ethical practices an interpreter must follow when working in any field of interpretation.

column1: Fundamental Principles and Methodologies of Translation Course
column2: An introduction to the theories and methods of translation, and to the practical elements of five core translation competencies with real-world bilingual examples: (1) personal competencies and (2) basic tools for the translation task. Emphasis is placed on (3) reading comprehension and analyses in both languages. You will read a wide variety of bilingual topics, and analyze the source and target readers. Also, you are introduced to writing (4) and translating (5) short texts.

column1: English, Reading, and Writing Skills for Bilingual Interpreters and Translators Course
column2: Enhance  your English language proficiency for use in professions requiring bilingual skills such as court interpreting and professional translation. Instruction covers appropriate vocabulary, grammar tenses, and stylistic patterns necessary for error-free communication.  In-class activities include discussions on writing and oral assignments, vocabulary development, spelling, word usage, and punctuation

column1: Court Interpretation- Exam Preparation Course
column2: This class is designed to help the student prepare to pass the State Court Interpreter Exam. Students will review all 3 modes of interpretation, sharpen their interpreting, sight translation skills and expand their knowledge of the legal glossary. This class will include intense practices in the lab in order to build up speed, memorization, note taking, and mind agility skills. This class is also offered to any student who has completed a certificate program at another institution and is interested in taking a refresher course or receive deeper learning in preparation to take the State Court Interpreter Exam.

column1: Court Interpretation - Exam Preparation Course
column2: This class is designed to help the student prepare to pass the State Court Interpreter Exam.?Students will review all 3 modes of interpretation, sharpen?their interpreting, sight translation?skills and expand their knowledge of the legal glossary.?This class will include intense practices in the lab in order to build up speed, memorization, note taking, and mind agility skills.?This class will be offered to any student who have completed a certificate program at another institution and is interested in taking?a refresher course or receive deeper learning in preparation?to take the?State Court Interpreter Exam.

column1: Consecutive Translation for Interpreters and Translators Course
column2: In this course students will learn to convert the words into the target language after the speakers delivers one or two sentences. Consecutive interpretation will be implemented as a pedagogical tool to enhance students acquisition of translation and interpretation skills. Students will develop advanced consecutive interpretation skills through practice. Emphasis in this course will be placed on cultural knowledge, understanding of the nuances of the language, sharp memory, excellent speaking, and keen hearing skills. Emphasis will be placed on visual contact with the speaker and note-taking.

column1: Consecutive Translation for Translators and Interpreters Course
column2: In this course students will learn to convert the words into the target language after the speakers delivers one or two sentences. Consecutive interpretation will be implemented as a pedagogical tool to enhance students acquisition of translation and interpretation skills. Students will develop advanced consecutive interpretation skills through practice. Emphasis in this course will be placed on cultural knowledge, understanding of the nuances of the language, sharp memory, excellent speaking, and keen hearing skills. Emphasize will be placed on visual contact with the speaker and note-taking.

column1: Consecutive Interpretation Course
column2: Emphasizes consecutive interpretation as practiced in courts and adjudicatory hearings.  Tapes, court transcripts and other legal documents will be used to teach the technique, and note-taking skills will be developed employing principally an adaptation of the Rozan Method.  Materials include specialized glossaries.

column1: Comparative Analysis of the Structures of English and Spanish Languages Course
column2: An examination of key grammar and punctuation elements of both language structures including the standard and non-standard forms of a language, and the importance of sentence structure, verbs, punctuation, reading, and writing, editing and proofreading. Emphasis is on in-class reading; comprehension and writing exercises and discussions; syntax and semantics; and vocabulary development with examples from both languages.

column1: Comparative Analysis of the Structures of English and Spanish Languages Course
column2: An examination of key grammar and syntax elements of both language structures, including the standard and non-standard forms of a language, and the importance of sentence structure, verbs, punctuation, reading, and writing, editing, and proofreading. Emphasis is on in-class reading; comprehension and writing exercises and discussions; syntax and semantics; and vocabulary development with examples from both languages.

column1: Community Interpretation and Translation in Education Course
column2: In this course, students will learn how to create their own tools for the field of Community Interpretation in the Educational Field. Students will navigate through the different interpreting sessions using the modes and rules of interpretation. Students will acquire the educational vocabulary needed to interpret in IEP meetings. Students will understand the importance of outreach and how to maintain a strong communication with the LEP populations. Students will explore different ways to create a website and acquire resources for the LEP population.

column1: Community Interpretation and Translation in Education Course
column2: In this course, students will learn how to create their own tools for the field of Community Interpretation in the Educational Field. Students will navigate through the different interpreting sessions using the modes and rules of interpretation. Students will acquire the educational vocabulary needed to interpret in IEP meetings. Students will understand the importance of outreach and how to maintain a strong communication with the LEP populations. Students will explore different ways to create a website and acquire resources for the LEP population.

column1: Community Interpretation Course
column2: In this course, students will learn how to navigate across cultural interpretation in the educational field. The purpose is to prepare students to operate through all types of interpretation and translation while applying the modes and roles of interpretation in the community setting. Students will research and understand the different cultural and linguistic barriers between both languages. Emphasis on this course will be placed in the different roles of a community interpreter in the educational and social fields.

column1: Community Interpretation Course
column2: In this course, students will learn how to navigate across cultural interpretation in the educational field. The purpose is to prepare students to operate through all types of interpretation and translation while applying the modes and roles of interpretation in the community setting. Students will research and understand the different cultural and linguistic barriers between both languages. Emphasis on this course will be placed in the different roles of a community interpreter in the educational and social fields.

column1: California Court Interpreter Written Exam Preparation Course
column2: This course provides a language literacy overview of Spanish and English grammatical structures, legal terminology, and general Spanish and English vocabulary in preparation for the written exam. The exam preparation should benefit individuals who possess a certificate or expertise in professional interpretation and translation, or need improvement in written Spanish skills (including reading ability). Course activities include practice exams, a review of test-taking techniques and in-class reading analysis. Attention is given to the sight translation portion of the oral exam.

column1: Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) for Interpreters and Translators Course
column2: Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) (arbitration, settlement conferences, mediation and negotiation) has become institutionalized in law and business worldwide, using English as the "lingua franca" for ADR sessions and trainings. ADR sessions can be confusing to non-native speakers in terms of language, culture and law; however, these confidential "behind closed doors" sessions can have profound and lasting consequences-- particularly in child custody, civil harassment, elder abuse, foreclosure, eviction, personal injury, business and collections cases. Learn to understand the specialized concepts, terminology and culture of ADR, and how to provide this added value to courts, mediators, attorneys, litigants or mediation trainers. In order to provide non-native speakers with equal access to fair ADR processes, interpreters who understand key ADR concepts and who can properly communicate its legal, linguistic and cultural nuances are in high demand. Instruction includes role-play and feedback.

column1: Advanced Principles and Methodologies of Translation Course
column2: In this bilingual course, (1) personal competencies such as self-assessment and professional ethics; (2) computer-assisted translation tools; and competencies for advanced bilingual (3) reading and (4) writing are expected.
