Emphasis is placed on producing a corpus of professional (5) translations. Concepts include language functions, the translation process, and translation theory for dealing with texts. Application of translation methods and procedures to solve difficult translation problems is covered.

column1: California Court Interpreter Oral Exam Preparation Course
column2: Preparation for the oral portion of the Spanish-English California State Court Interpreter Exam. Workshop activities include an overview of consecutive, simultaneous and sight translation, and exercises and mock tests simulating the actual oral exam. Designed for individuals who have completed a professional interpretation and translation certificate program or possess expertise in interpretation and translation techniques.

column1: A Survey of Latin-American Literature and Culture Course
column2: Explore the rich and diverse voices and communities represented in literature, language, and culture of Spanish-speaking countries. Through a selection of Spanish texts, writers, music, and movies, you will look at cultural comparisons between the practices and perspectives of people from different Spanish-speaking regions and countries. Discuss the history and modernization of Spanish literature and culture via examination of Spanish art, language, politics, and social movements. Focus is on understanding the cross-cultural communication challenges and barriers. You will complete an assignment, selecting a topic of interest, reflecting your comprehension of the history and modernization Spanish literature and culture.

column1: A Practical Approach to Spanish Grammar for Interpreters and Translators Course
column2: This course is intended primarily for native Spanish speakers with little or no formal education in the language and for bilingual students. Students develop language skills for use in professions requiring bilingual skills such as court interpreting and professional translation. This comprehensive program consists of the study and review of parts of speech, orthography, sentence structure and verbs.

column1: A Practical Approach to English Grammar for Bilingual Interpreters and Translators Course
column2: Instruction includes an emphasis on the fundamentals of English grammar for use in professions requiring bilingual skills such as court interpreting and professional translation.  In-class activities build fluency in both spoken and written language through the study and review of parts of speech, orthography, sentence structure and verbs.

column1: Practical French for Travelers Course
column2: A general approach to the French language for travelers to France, Belgium and other countries where French is spoken.  Emphasis on pronunciation and practical vocabulary.  Practice dialogues for asking directions, ordering food, going to the post office or bank, ordering a hotel room, shopping and other situations the tourist is likely to encounter.

column1: Practical Chinese for Travelers Course
column2: A general approach to the Chinese language for travelers to China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore,  and other countries in the world. Emphasis will be on pronunciation and practical vocabulary. Practice dialogues for asking directions, ordering food, going to the post office or bank, reserving a hotel room, shopping and other situations you may encounter as a tourist.

column1: Passport to Japan: Conversational Japanese Course
column2: An introductory course for those who expect to travel to Japan or have business or social contact with Japanese visitors. Also a useful introduction to the structure and pronunciation of the Japanese language for English teachers who may have Japanese-speaking students. Emphasis is on the spoken standard language with as little English used in the classroom as possible. The goal of the course is the acquisition of conversational skills, and translation is discouraged.

column1: Passport to Italy: Conversational Italian (Beginning) Course
column2: The course begins a sequence of two courses, Conversational Italian, Parts A and B. Covers beginning conversation, emphasizing oral skills and comprehension of spoken and written Italian. The purpose of this course is to provide students with a sound basis for communicating effectively and accurately in Italian. “Real-life” activities will expose students to day-to-day contexts likely to be encountered in Italy, thus reinforcing grammatical structures learned in class and increasing functional skills. Students will also be introduced to contemporary Italian life and culture.

column1: Passport to France: Beginning Conversational  French Course
column2: This course will emphasize basic oral language acquisition by stressing active participation of students through talking, listening and interacting. Organized around themes that present language usage in common tasks and activities, the course will provide an opportunity for students to develop basic speaking and comprehension skills that will be generally useful for those interested in learning French and for those planning to travel to France or host Francophone people.

column1: Parlez-vous fran�§ais?  A Workshop in French for Young Learners Course
column2: Intended to provide a French-speaking environment for children between the age of 3 and 6, with focus on the four language learning skills: reading, listening, speaking and writing. Hands-on and interactive activities will be used to enhance learning and participation.

column1: Medical Terminology and Conversational Spanish, Part A Course
column2: Study Spanish medical terminology and conversational skills used in health care and medical environments. Lessons focus on basic anatomy and physiology terminology, related colloquialisms, and commonly encountered health conditions and cross-cultural issues. Spanish grammatical structures are also explored to provide a foundation for enhancing conversational skills. Benefits individuals in medical professions, clinics, educational settings, and other professional settings where bilingual skills are used to assist Spanish speakers with health-related issues.

column1: Medical Terminology and Conversational Spanish Part B Course
column2: Continuation of Medical Terminology and Conversational Spanish Part A. Your lessons focus on: intermediate to advanced anatomy and physiology terminology, related colloquialisms, and commonly encountered health conditions and cross-cultural issues. You will develop and practice techniques to enhance your language proficiency, interpretation skills, medical terminology and grammar. Benefits individuals in medical professions, clinics, educational settings, and other professional settings where bilingual skills are used to assist Spanish speakers with health-related issues.

column1: Let's Talk: English Conversation Group Course
column2: This class is designed for English language learners enrolled in part-time ESL Programs at the UCR Extension Center. Students in these programs can get extra practice with English conversation by attending this course. Each week, students will practice conversation about relevant topics such as current events, daily activities, personal goals and challenges, popular culture, holidays and traditions, and more. Students will practice authentic conversation with peers, native speakers, and the instructor during dynamic and strategic activities that are designed to maximize student talk time.

column1: Let's Talk: English Conversation Group Course
column2: This class is designed for English language learners enrolled in part-time ESL Programs at the UCR Extension Center. Students in these programs can get extra practice with English conversation by attending this course. Each week, students will practice conversation about relevant topics such as current events, daily activities, personal goals and challenges, popular culture, holidays and traditions, and more. Students will practice authentic conversation with peers, native speakers, and the instructor during dynamic and strategic activities that are designed to maximize student talk time.

column1: Legal Terminology and Conversational Spanish Course
column2: The study of Spanish grammatical structures, and interactive practice scenarios provides a solid foundation for enhancing conversational skills needed in the legal field. Lessons focus on basic legal terminology, related vocabulary, colloquialism, and commonly encountered cross-cultural issues. A critical study to compare and contrast the differences between English and Spanish Legal Terminology benefits paralegals, attorneys, law enforcement, staff at Legal Aid Clinics, and those working in professional settings where bilingual skills are used to communicate with Spanish-speakers with legal issues.

column1: Introduction to Italian Conversation and Grammar Course
column2: Ciao!  Come learn to speak and understand la bella lingua in a relaxed, fun atmosphere.  Emphasis will be placed on comprehension, pronunciation, dialogue, and common idiomatic expressions in Italian.  Grammar will be studied both explicitly and in context.  This class is perfect for those soon-to-be traveling in Italy, those wanting to learn more about their Italian roots, or for students who wish to learn a second language.

column1: Introduction to Hindi Conversation and Grammar Course
column2: By virtue of increasing interest in Yoga and also for India's contributions to modern technology and related businesses, India has risen to one of the top destinations for people from other countries. Since Hindi is the spoken language in most of India, this course provides an opportunity to learn correct vocabulary and grammar usage whether you are traveling to India for business or pleasure. Students will be able to communicate with people easily and gain a better understanding of the culture.

column1: Information Session: English as a Second Language Program Course
column2: In this information session, prospective students for the Specialized Study Program in English as a Second Language will learn about the program and classes.  They will also have the opportunity to take a free placement test of their English language level, and receive assistance filling out the application to the program, and registering for ESL courses.

column1: Introduction to Hebrew Conversation and Grammar Course
column2: An introduction for those who want to learn conversational Hebrew to prepare for travel to Israel, or for personal enrichment. Emphasis is on pronunciation, building a useful vocabulary, practice in basic conversation, and reading and writing skills in modern Hebrew.

column1: Intermediate Conversational French Course
column2: A course on communicative skills emphasizing oral language acquisition and comprehension of French spoken at regular speed. Special attention will be given to diverse linguistic registers (ranging from formal to colloquial), pronunciation and rhythm, and the development of freer and more confident speech. Relevant points of grammar will be included. Audio tapes, videos and visual materials revolving around themes and cultural contexts will be used to encourage discussion.

column1: ESL Low Intermediate Course
column2: This is a lower intermediate level English class in which students will build upon the listening, speaking, reading, writing, and grammar skills introduced in ESL Low and High Beginning. In this class, students will refine these skills so that they can participate in routine and sometimes challenging conversations about social, school, and work topics.  Students may practice skills such as giving personal information, making polite requests, discussing housing, explaining recipes and food, making complaints, describing holidays, and more.  Students will also learn different strategies to improve their reading comprehension, develop their grammar skills, understand simple conversations, and write at the paragraph level.

column1: ESL Low Beginning Course
column2: This is a lower beginning level English class in which students will develop basic reading, writing, speaking, listening, and grammar skills. Students will practice English skills and language to complete everyday tasks. They will practice skills like giving introductions and greetings, asking for and giving personal information, describing places, and shopping. Course topics may include jobs, school, family, entertainment, exercise, and free-time activities.  Students will read basic texts, work on projects, and give short presentations.

column1: ESL Low Advanced Course
column2: This is a lower advanced level English class in which students will build upon the listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills introduced in ESL Low and High Intermediate. Students will explore complex topics such as relationships, careers, current events, culture, travel, and personal and global problems. They will learn and apply new strategies for reading and vocabulary comprehension with authentic texts, use advanced grammar structures in speaking and writing, and write multi-paragraph texts with complex sentences. They will also practice conversational skills such as telling anecdotal stores, interrupting, and turn-taking. Ultimately, students will complete an interview-based research project in which they explore a topic of interest through conversation and writing.

column1: ESL ITA Preparation: Pronunciation Improvement Course
column2: In this course, students will learn about and practice the "segmental" and "suprasegmental" elements of English.  Segmental elements of English include consonant and vowel sounds, and suprasegmentals include stress, rhythm, focus words and intonation.  You will apply your knowledge to various speaking contexts, with a focus on producing highly comprehensible speech, and on identifying and correcting instances of mispronunciation. At the end of the course, you will make an academic presentation to peers, and will be prepared to take the SPEAK test, an institutional speaking assessment taken by many international students at UCR.

column1: ESL ITA Preparation: Oral Skills Development Course
column2: In this course, students will develop their oral skills for the purposes of taking the SPEAK test, an institutional speaking assessment taken by many international students at UCR, and for delivering instruction in English.  Specifically, students will develop their language competencies  in spoken English – functional, sociolinguistic, discourse, linguistic - for the purposes of performing language functions necessary for daily activates and academic life.  Additionally, students will develop test-taking strategies for the SPEAK test.  At the end of the course, students will make an academic presentation to peers and will be prepared to take the SPEAK test.

column1: ESL High Intermediate Course
column2: This is a high intermediate level English class in which students will continue to develop their reading, writing, speaking, listening, and grammar skills. Students will learn strategies to improve communication skills around daily events and worldwide issues. Course topics may include life events, job skills and preferences, landmarks and places, entertainment, non-verbal communication, laws and customs, and problems. Students will learn strategies to increase their control with more difficult grammatical structures, understand more complicated, authentic texts, and write paragraphs on a variety of topics.

column1: ESL High Beginning Course
column2: This is a high beginning level English class in which students will develop basic reading, writing, speaking, listening, and grammar skills. Students will practice daily tasks such as describing appearances, discussing the past, talking about health, ordering in restaurants, and making future plans. Course topics will reflect everyday life and may include clothing styles, people, activities, countries, hometowns, and food. Students will learn strategies for reading brief texts, and write sentence-level notes or messages. Students will also develop their communicative skills by working together in groups on projects and delivering presentations.

column1: ESL High Advanced Course
column2: This is a high advanced level English class in which students will improve their reading, writing, speaking, and listening skills. Students will practice speaking and writing about a variety of complex and abstract topics, such as self-improvement, historical events, personal milestones, success in business, pet peeves, the media and entertainment industry, and legal issues. Students will develop skills and strategies for reading lengthy or difficult texts, writing multi-paragraph texts with revision, and participating in persuasive conversations such as interviews.

column1: Conversational Spanish, Part D Course
column2: Continuation of Conversational Spanish, Parts A, B and C. Designed to further develop grammar, vocabulary and conversational skills in Spanish. This course includes discussion of Spanish culture and daily life.

column1: Conversational Spanish, Part C Course
column2: Conversational Spanish Part C builds on to a solid foundation with advanced grammar principles, vocabulary, and conversational skills in an interactive environment to practice your speaking and listening skills and build self-confidence. Understanding Spanish culture is included. Course is taught primarily in Spanish.

column1: Conversational Spanish, Part B Course
column2: Conversational Spanish Part B focuses on listening, speaking, and comprehension using an integrated approach through hands-on activities. With the goal of strengthening grammar, vocabulary, and conversational skills, this course will enhance the use of modern Spanish for practical communication. Both personal and professional uses of the language are presented alongside information about Spanish culture. Course is taught primarily in Spanish.

column1: Conversational Mandarin Chinese, Part B Course
column2: Spoken Chinese at the intermediate level.  Emphasis is on thinking and speaking in Chinese without English translation.  Sentence structure, vocabulary and idioms covered require a beginning knowledge of Chinese conversation.  Includes information about Chinese history and culture.

column1: Conversational Spanish, Part A Course
column2: The conversational Spanish series emphasizes oral skills and comprehension of the spoken language. Through various interactive, group activities, beginning-level grammar necessary for a basic understanding of the Spanish language is covered. Personal and professional uses of the language are presented as is information on Spanish culture. Course is taught primarily in Spanish.

column1: Conversational Mandarin Chinese, Part A Course
column2: This introductory course in spoken Chinese is taught with little or no English translation so that students soon begin thinking and speaking in Chinese. Emphasis is on learning the most useful sentence structures and vocabulary. The goal of the course is to prepare students for Chinese conversation and to lay a proper foundation for the continued study of the Chinese language and culture.

column1: Conversational Italian, Part B Course
column2: A continuation of Conversational Italian, this course emphasizes the conversational skills of listening comprehension and speech.  Emphasis on in-class practice of skills.  The course includes cultural information and vocabulary appropriate for travel in Italy.

column1: Conversational Italian, Part A Course
column2: This course begins a sequence of two courses: Conversational Italian, Parts A and B, and covers beginning conversation emphasizing oral skills and comprehension of spoken and written Italian. The purpose of this course is to provide students with a sound basis for communicating effectively and accurately in Italian. “Real-life” activities will expose students to day-to-day contexts likely to be encountered in Italy, thus reinforcing grammatical structures learned in class and increasing functional skills. Students will also be introduced to contemporary Italian life and culture.

column1: Conversational Brazilian Portuguese Course
column2: Whether you are traveling  to Brazil for business or pleasure, this course will introduce you to the  Portuguese Language and Brazilian culture and emphasize correct grammar usage and vocabulary.

column1: Conversational Arabic Course
column2: Practice in conversational Arabic. Emphasis on pronunciation, idioms and building a useful vocabulary. Since the basics of reading and writing modern Arabic will be covered, a background in Arabic is not necessary.

column1: Beginning Conversational Japanese Course
column2: An introductory course for those who expect to travel to Japan or have business or social contact with Japanese visitors.  Also a useful introduction to the structure and pronunciation of the Japanese language for English teachers who may have Japanese-speaking students.  Emphasis is on the spoken standard language with as little English used in the classroom as possible.  The goal of the course is the acquisition of conversational skills, and translation is discouraged.

column1: Workshop on Southern California Indian Basketry Course
column2: This one-day workshop introduces participants to the materials and techniques used in Southern California Indian basketry.  Participants gain an appreciation for the art of basket weaving and have the opportunity to complete a round reed creek-side basket.

column1: Traditional Native American Storytelling Course
column2: Native American storytelling reflects the rich cultural and religious heritage of many generations. Storytelling leads to the understanding of how the past has influenced the present. This course examines the foundation of traditional Native American storytelling through analysis of comparative traditional forms with emphasis on its importance to religious and social values. Participants gain a historical, cultural and traditional overview of storytelling and are introduced to Native American storytellers.

column1: Native Plants: Preserving the Harvest Course
column2: Native plants are taking their rightful place in health and nutrition. Explore the many ways indigenous peoples of Southern California use and save native plants for health and nutrition. You will have a hands-on experience in gathering, preparing and preserving various native plants such as yucca, cactus, elderberry, stinging nettle, mesquite, acorn, and more. You will receive a native plant cookbook, as well.

column1: The Art and Science of Flintknapping Course
column2: Before tools were made from metal, tools were made of stone through the ancient art of flintknapping (manufacturing tools by breaking rocks in a systematic manner). Today, archaeologists, historic reconstructionists, teachers and hobbyists keep the old techniques alive. This weekend learning experience at the Desert Studies Center includes a combination of lectures and planned field activities such as the heat treatment of silicious rocks, basic percussion biface reduction, basic pressure flaking (including notching), the use of an atlatl, and the use of a single stave and self bow. Students have the opportunity to haft what they manufacture (arrow point, dart point, or knife). The raw material and basic tools needed for making stone tools are provided. Detailed information on what to bring will be sent upon enrollment.

column1: Native Plants of California: Medicinal Uses Course
column2: This workshop explores the many ways that indigenous peoples of Southern California adapted to their local environment and to the plants with which they share it. Focus is on the medicinal uses of native plants and the preparation of healing salves, teas, soaps and lip balm. Includes a field trip to Mockingbird Canyon.

column1: Native American Uses of Southern California Plants: A Botanic Walk Course
column2: This one-day workshop explores how indigenous peoples of Southern California used local plants in their daily lives. Participants will take a botanic walk around Mockingbird Canyon identifying and learning about the variety of plants used by local tribes to create useful products such as soap, brushes and cordage. Participants will have the opportunity to create projects which include a yucca utilitarian brush and cordage.

column1: Native American Uses of Southern California Plants Course
column2: This workshop explores many ways that indigenous peoples of Southern California used local plants in their daily lives.  Emphasis is on how local tribes processed and used seeds and made soap, brushes and cordage. This workshop provides the opportunity to work with a variety of plants and materials to learn how to create useful products.  These activities include processing yucca root and soaproot (amole) into soap products; using traditional techniques to make broom and brushes from pine needles, soaproot fibers, yucca and wild teasel; and creating a seed beater fan to learn how various seeds were collected and processed.

column1: Native American Culture Course
column2: This two-day course begins with a review of how the rich and diverse cultures of Native Americans Indians were affected by the loss of their lands, removal and forced assimilation through the boarding school experience including the Sherman Indian Boarding School in Riverside.  You explore how tribal communities are reclaiming their languages, stories, songs and ancestral lands, and cultural revitalization efforts such as the Salt Song Trail Project of the Chemehuevi and other Southern Paiute peoples, and the purchase of 2,500 acres of land at the Old Woman Mountains in the eastern Mojave desert region.  You discuss the role of cultural cartography and cultural preservation in the protection of those lands, and have the opportunity to look at traditional indigenous farming and foods as currently practiced by Matthew Leivas, Sr. of the Chemehuevi Tribe.  The workshop includes: recorded music, live songs performed at the Oasis of Mara and the award-winning film (Best Documentary Short/2005 American Indian Film Festival) The Salt Song Trail.

column1: Methods for Teaching Elementary Students About Native Americans Course
column2: Methods for teaching elementary teachers ways to incorporate information about Native Americans into social studies, history, literature and writing lessons. Topics include content standards that address Native Americans, selecting non-biased reading materials and how to avoid stereotyping in the schools. Hands-on projects and crafts that are appropriate when teaching about specific tribes are linked to classroom activities and curriculum. Participants are able to take home projects and a useful bibliography that is relevant to the grade level taught.

column1: Native American Basketry:  Coiled Juncus Course
column2: The Indian tribes of California produced baskets of great diversity and beauty. The exquisite baskets of the Cahuilla are among the highest forms of the basket-making art, and in recent years the Cahuilla have experienced a revival in the tradition. Participants in this workshop learn to identify plants that are used in basket-making and create a coiled basket in class using yucca, sumac, juncus and deer grass.

column1: Indian Boarding Schools: Past and Present Course
column2: This course examines the role of off-reservation boarding schools as a tool to assimilate American Indian children into the dominant culture. Topics include the history of boarding schools, federal education policy toward Native Americans and the experiences of American Indians who attended off-reservation boarding schools.  The focus is specifically on the Sherman Indian High School boarding school.  Participants will tour the Sherman campus and museum and visit the off-site Sherman Indian School cemetery.

column1: Introduction to Indian Law and Government Course
column2: This course provides participants a historical overview of early tribal governments and their evolving relationship with the federal government. The primary focus is contemporary tribal self-governance and application of federal/state laws to tribal entities, including tribally owned enterprises. The focus is on the Southern California region and includes presentations from tribal attorneys and members of tribal government.

column1: Trust Administration and Procedure Course
column2: Breaks down the anatomy of a trust instrument, introduces trust terminology, and covers the California laws governing trust administration and procedures. Explore different types of revocable and irrevocable trusts, the purposes they serve, and how to administer and manage private and court-supervised trusts. Learn how to identify and avoid conflicts of interest, and what to do should you find yourself in a conflict. Ethical considerations are discussed.

column1: Trusts and Trust Administration for the Professional Fiduciary Course
column2: <font color="#000000">An in-depth examination of a wide variety of trusts, from single person grantor trusts through the most complex, irrevocable trust being drafted today.  Among the trusts and concepts to be discussed will be Testamentary vs. Inter-Vivos Trusts; Single Person Grantor Trusts; Married Persons </font>Trusts (A-B, Disclaimer, QTIP); Reciprocal Unmarried Partner Trusts; Spendthrift Trusts; Special Needs Trusts; Charitable Lead and Remainder Trusts; Gift Trusts; Irrevocable Life Insurance Trusts; Rabbi Trusts and Intentionally Defective Grantor Trusts.

column1: Hospitality and Tourism Terminology and Conversational Spanish Course
column2: The study of Spanish grammatical structures and interactive practice scenarios will provide you with a solid foundation for enhancing conversational skills needed in the hospitality and tourism industry. Lessons focus on basic customer service terminology, conversational skills, and commonly encountered cross-cultural issues. You will also compare and contrast the differences between U.S. and Latin American hospitality practices. Benefits individuals working in professional settings where bilingual skills are needed to communicate across cultures, and assist Spanish-speaking clients and customers with hospitality, accommodation, and entertainment service-related issues.

column1: Tort Law Course
column2: Fundamentals of basic tort law. Torts to be covered include negligence, medical malpractice, misrepresentation, defamation, privacy, unfair competition, products liability, wrongful termination, assault and battery, and malicious prosecution. General areas for review are standards of care, proof of breach of care, causation and damages.

column1: Successfully Navigating Disability Benefits for Adults Course
column2: Examine the laws and intricacies that govern benefit programs, including Social Security Disability Insurance (SSDI), Supplemental Security Income (SSI), Medi-Cal and Medicare for those living with disabilities.  Learn how to evaluate the various benefit options that are available and how to get the best approval ratings and successful delivery of services.

column1: 10-Pack Permit
column2: If you are not commuting to campus regularly, a 10-pack permit option might be the best choice for you.  A Blue 10-pack is sold for Blue lots and a Red 10-pack is sold for Red lots, based on availability. A 10-pack permit provides ten daily parking permits to use any day you want within the fiscal year.

column1: Post Arrival for J-1 Scholars

column1: H-1B Visa and Green Card
column2: H-1B Visa   Sponsorship The H-1B is a nonimmigrant classification used for the sponsorship of international faculty or staff who will be employed at UC Riverside. The H-1B visa is employer specific and position specific. Thus, employees must obtain a new H-1B visa approval for each new position and new employer. For more information, please visit the USCIS website.

column1: Prospective International Scholars
column2: Prospective International Scholars and Researchers   For Prospective Visiting Scholars and Researchers: You must be invited by an academic department or lab that will serve as your host. To learn about potential hosting opportunities, please directly contact the principal investigator (PI) you would like to work with through their department website. If you are extending an invitation with an academic department at UCR, you may begin the application process.

column1: Travel
column2: Traveling For International Students Riverside is a city in Riverside County, California, United States. It is part of the Greater Los Angeles area. It is located approximately 60 miles (97 km) east of Los Angeles. Named for our location beside the Santa Ana River, we are one of the largest cities in Inland Southern California.

column1: New International Students
column2: Welcome New International Students Follow your dreams to sunny, Southern California! Wherever your journey started, you will find a home at the University of California, Riverside (UCR). There are a number of things you need to do to prepare for your start at UCR. Please see the list below for more information. Undergraduate students should also check their MyUCR account often.

column1: Consumer and Safety Information
column2: Federal regulations require that institutions provide enrolled and prospective students specific consumer information about financial aid, campus, facilities, student athletes websites, important resources and disclosures, as well as information to promote campus security and fire safety, and to prevent drug and alcohol abuse. Because of the nature of federal, state, and institution guidelines affecting financial aid programs, the information contained in this website is subject to change.

column1: Workshops
column2: Attend One of Our Workshops Attend a Workshop! Each quarter, we host several workshops on key financial topics, such as learning how to budget, how to build credit, planning for a move off campus, among others. These workshops are open to all students on campus.  Follow us on Instagram @ucrfinwell to stay up-to-date on upcoming workshops.

column1: Make an Appointment
column2: Individual Coaching Appointments Are you worried about any aspect of your money life? Curious about credit and want to know how it works? Thinking about buying a car and don't know where to start? To book an individualized appointment, please fill out the appointment intake form.

column1: Education Abroad 60th Anniversary
column2: For 60 years, Education Abroad at UCR has encouraged students to enhance their education and expand their worldview by experiencing life in another country or culture. This entertaining evening of awards, dinner, and cultural performances is a celebration of our past, present, and future:

column1: Highlander Abroad Referendum Overview
column2: In the Spring of 2019 the student body of the University of California, Riverside (UCR) approved implementation of a Highlander Abroad Referendum (HAR) fee of $2.00 per quarter (Fall, Winter, Spring, and Summer) for all undergraduate students in support of expenses related to learning abroad, less the “return to aid” portion (25% or $.50 per student/per quarter off the top). HAR went into effect Fall 2019 and is subject to reaffirmation by the student body every five years. Allocation and Governance

column1: Budget Plans and Reports
column2: The Education Abroad office submits an annual report summarizing how HAR funds are used. HAAC members review and vote on any changes to the original budget plan and any proposed use of carry-forward funds. This information is also reflected in the HAF Annual Report.   HAAC Annual Report for academic year 2019 - 2020

column1: Highlander Abroad Advisory Committee
column2: */ /*-->*/ The Highlander Abroad Advisory Committee (HAAC) decides how the HAR funds should be allocated. Members work closely with Education Abroad office, voting for budget plan proposals that will best serve UCR’s student body.

column1: Stories from Abroad
column2: */ /*-->*/ Stories From Abroad Education Abroad is your gateway to the world! UCR students just like you participate in our international programs. They take classes, have internships, conduct research, learn languages, volunteer and work around the world. Experiencing life in another culture and building new skills helps UCR graduates become more competitive in their career search.

column1: Education Abroad Frequently Asked Questions
UC Staff & Faculty Resources
column2: Welcome to UCR Education Abroad! We are committed to working with you to deliver the highest-caliber international experiences to all UC students.  To keep things as streamlined as possible, we group education abroad opportunities into three types:

column1: Resources for Family and Friends
column2: */ /*-->*/ A Note to Family and Parents Congratulations to your student for deciding to learn abroad!

column1: Education Abroad Alumni
Education Abroad Scholarships
column2: */ /*-->*/ Applying to multiple scholarships increases your chances of receiving funding. While each scholarship has its own level of competitiveness, all have the same goal of helping students to learn, intern or work abroad. We encourage you to read each website carefully for eligibility, application instructions, and deadlines.

column1: Get Ready to Travel
column2: */   Congratulations on being accepted to an education abroad program! The next couple of months will be an exciting and active time as you get ready to travel. Please read the section below. The resources and instructions listed are important ways for you to prepare for your time abroad.

column1: What to Do While Abroad
column2: */ We hope you are enjoying yourself!  Please keep in mind your safety, priorities, and responsibilities while abroad. Check this page for updates and announcements that may affect you.   Questions? We’re here for you. Please reach out. By Email: educationabroad@ucr.edu

column1: Program Overviews
column2: */ /*-->*/ Three Program Types, with hundreds of programs to choose from!   Learn abroad with your UCR professor, taking UCR courses on a global stage through a Faculty Led Education Abroad Program (FLEAP), participate in the UC systemwide network through (UCEAP), or find additional options through the Opportunities Abroad Program (OAP).

column1: Finances
column2: */ /*-->*/ Paying for Your Education Abroad Experience Did you know that in some cases learning abroad can be less expensive than staying on campus?

column1: APRU Virtual Student Exchange (VSE) Program
column2: The APRU Virtual Student Exchange (VSE) Program, led by The Chinese University of Hong Kong, makes international education accessible by allowing students to take academic courses and participate in co-curricular programs without the need to leave home. It opens up international education for all students by providing an immersive virtual student exchange experience through digital technologies and platforms and creating encounters with new ideas, cultures, experts, academics and students from around the world. Through collaboration with APRU VSE Program, UCR is offering a special 10-week series of workshops on "Studying and Living in an American Research University." Students will learn about the American university system, behaviors and expectations in the classroom, employment options and career development, leadership opportunities and collaboration on campus, the basics of American culture and adjusting to new cultural environments, and other useful information to help them be successful when they study in the U.S.

column1: Education Abroad
column2: Education Abroad provides UCR students a gateway to high-quality international opportunities, offered through academic coursework, experiential learning, immersion to cultivate intercultural understanding and collaboration. We help students acquire the skills to work in a global marketplace, and promote access to global experiences as an integral part of a UCR education through student support services, including program advising, financial counseling, academic integration, and resource sharing. We will help you find a program that works for you!

column1: Faculty Led Education Abroad Programs (FLEAP)
column2: Enjoy the ease of taking an international UC Riverside class with a UCR professor! Spend the summer traveling and learning alongside UCR classmates in UCR professor-taught courses on a Faculty Led Education Abroad Program (FLEAP).

column1: International Education Week 2022
column2: UC Riverside is a vibrant global community leading positive change in every direction. Join us for International Education Week 2022! Through cultural and educational programs, social events, and dynamic discussions of complex global issues, International Education Week at UCR will celebrate our global connections, share our international stories, and expand our cultural awareness of UCR’s growing international community.

column1: International Affairs Recognition Awards
column2: International Affairs Recognition Awards The annual International Affairs Recognition Awards were created to recognize exceptional students, scholars, faculty, and staff who have had a significant impact on the international community at UCR. Their contributions help enrich the international experience at UCR and enhance UCR's global engagement.

column1: What We Do
column2: Our Vision   Our vision is to enhance UCR’s position as an outstanding public research university by building a vibrant community where global knowledge, peoples, ideas, and skills are constantly evolving. We believe international experiences are essential to professional and personal success in our increasingly global society.  Learn more about our strategic international goals

column1: GradSuccess
column2: Welcome to GradSuccess at the University of California, Riverside!   GradSuccess supports graduate student retention, degree completion, and post-degree career outcomes through a diverse range of programs, events, expert consultations, and peer support. As graduate students, you are the engine of a research university, and GradSuccess is your fuel. GradSuccess programs and services are also open to postdocs! Please contact our Director (scroll down for contact info) if you have any questions.

column1: Academic Student Employee (ASE)
column2: General ASE Employment Information ASE’s are Teaching Assistants (TAs), Teaching Fellows, Associate _Ins, Readers, and Tutors.   Graduate students may be employed during the academic year on a part-time basis (up to, but not exceeding 50% time) as a Teaching Assistant (TA), Associate In_, or Teaching Fellow.  These appointments are awarded by academic programs.

column1: Graduate Student Researcher (GSR)
column2: General GSR Employment Information GSR’s are students who perform research related to the student's degree program in an academic department or research unit under the direction of a faculty member or authorized principal investigator.   Graduate students may be employed during the academic year on a part-time basis that does not to exceed 50% time.  These appointments are awarded by academic programs.

column1: UC Open Access Policy for Theses and Dissertations
column2: The University of California (“University”) is committed to disseminating research and scholarship conducted at the University as widely as possible. Such commitment encompasses the scholarship generated by the University’s graduate students. The University affirms the long-standing tradition that theses and dissertations, which represent significant contributions to the advancement of knowledge and the scholarly record, should be shared with scholars in all disciplines and the general public.

column1: Postdoctoral Studies
column2: Welcome to the University of California, Riverside! The campus has a lively community of over 200 postdocs working in diverse disciplines. Postdoctoral Scholars are automatically members of the Riverside Postdoc Association (RPA), which is an active community that seeks to engage with postdocs to improve and promote their welfare and interests living in Riverside and working at UCR.

column1: Graduate Advisor Resources
column2: Graduate Advisor Definition and Expectations  The Graduate Advisor is the official representative of the Graduate Dean in matters affecting graduate students of the Advisor's academic unit.   Graduate Advisors have a shared objective to enroll students of high potential whose interests and abilities are compatible with the graduate program and to guide students to successful completion of the academic program.   There should be a close working relationship between the Graduate Advisor and the Graduate Division.

column1: Photography Policy
column2: Photography Policy Our staff works hard to maintain a beautiful setting for your casual and special event photos. Because we are largely self-funded, admission donations and photo shoot fees enable us to recover some of our costs for staffing, maintenance, and operation. We welcome personal photography of plants and nature and hope you will share your photos with others to enjoy. Individual photographers are not charged a fee, but we encourage you to make an admission donation at the Gardens entrance.

column1: Rentals
column2: Meeting Room The UCRBG Meeting Room and patio are used for official Gardens activities and programs, including lectures, workshops, member events, and special events such as plant sales and fundraisers. The Meeting Room may be also rented by UCR and outside groups whose purpose is compatible with the mission of the UCR Botanic Gardens. In order to protect our collection and facilities, the Gardens lawn is not available for rental, nor do we permit private parties, weddings, or receptions at this time.

column1: Tour the Gardens
Twilight Tours in the Gardens
column2: Several times during the summer, typically July and August, Gardens staff and docents lead after-hours Twilight Tours of the Botanic Gardens. This is the perfect time to enjoy the Gardens in the cool of early evening as the sun is setting and wildlife is beginning to stir. Light refreshments are served following the tour to add to your enjoyment. These events usually fill quickly and have a waiting list, so be sure to check our calendar often. Please wear appropriate footwear.

column1: Primavera in the Gardens
Rose pruning demonstration
column2: Every January the public is invited to the UCR Botanic Gardens to attend the annual Rose Pruning Demonstration, which takes place in one of our Rose Gardens. Botanic Gardens staff, volunteers and local experts demonstrate how to prune hybrid tea, floribunda, miniature roses and climbers, and are eager to answer questions and teach guests how to prune roses. Come out and learn how to take care of your roses, and you may even win a raffle prize.

column1: Plant Sales
column2: For over four decades the UCR Botanic Gardens has hosted the largest plant sale events in the Inland Empire. These events were redesigned to focus on plants propagated from our own unique collection and bring in local vendors to broaden the selection of plants suitable for the inland region.

column1: Spotlight on the interactive Botanic Gardens GIS Map
UCR Botanic Gardens
column2: A Nature Oasis and Living Museum in California's Inland Empire

column1: Members Annual Meeting
column2: Friends members are invited each June to attend the Members-only Annual Meeting and reception, hosted by the Director and Gardens staff, where they are presented with an overview of the past year in the UCR Botanic Gardens illustrated by beautiful photos of the Gardens. New garden installations, facility improvements, educational and outreach activities, and fundraising events are reviewed, along with a budget summary including a recap of how membership and donor funds have been used. Future goals, including short and long term plans, are presented as well.

column1: Events
column2: Calendar of Events Please join us for an upcoming UCR Botanic Gardens event. Most of our events are open to the public, while "Members Only" events are limited to members of the Friends of the UCR Botanic Gardens. If you are not currently a Friend, please consider becoming a member.

column1: Art in the Gardens
column2: Every November the UCR Botanic Gardens hosts an outreach event where curated items from local artisans are offered for sale. Come spend a pleasant afternoon strolling through Alder Canyon, where California artists and craftspersons are showcased representing a variety of media including ceramics, jewelry, mosaics, metal work, fiber arts, wood, and photography. Art in the Gardens is a great opportunity to shop from local artists while supporting the programs and activities of the UCR Botanic Gardens.

column1: Bird Walk & Breakfast
column2: The UCR campus is a bird hotspot for both permanent residents and seasonal migrating species (see ebird.org). The UCR Botanic Gardens hosts periodic early morning bird walks in the Gardens, timed for ideal sightings and led by birding experts from the UCR faculty and staff. Walks are followed by a continental breakfast where participants share sightings and observations and learn more about the local avifauna.

column1: What's in Bloom
column2: The UCR Botanic Gardens are ever changing and throughout the year there is always something in bloom. To enhance your visit we feature a monthly "What's in Bloom" overview at the Gardens entrance and on the website. Select the links below to view a monthly listing of plants in bloom.

column1: Directions
Wildlife
column2: The UCR Botanic Gardens is a certified National Wildlife Federation (nwf.org) Wildlife Habitat, providing shelter, water, and food sources for a myriad of reptiles, amphibians, and mammals. All of these animals are important to the Gardens’ ecosystem, which also provides a habitat corridor for animals moving among protected spaces in Riverside. Please respect them and their home and do not approach or disturb them. We ask that you report any rattlesnake sightings in the Gardens to a staff member.

column1: Our Staff
column2: The UCR Botanic Gardens is managed by a Director who reports to the Dean of the UCR College of Natural and Agricultural Sciences (CNAS). The Gardens employs five full-time permanent staff, and three part-time staff, Administrative support is provided by the CNAS BEES administrative unit, and assistance with facilities, internet technology, communications, and other needs are available from campus service units. The Director and staff are responsible for the administration, maintenance, and enhancement of the Gardens collection, gardens, and other features.

column1: SRC South
column2: Reservation Fees Room rental rates are waived for registered student organizations, however, other fees may apply. Campus departments and off campus groups are responsible for facility rental and other applicable charges.

column1: Facilities
column2: The UC Riverside Student Recreation Center (SRC) features state-of–the-art weight and cardio equipment, a rock wall and boulder (The Rock), a recreational/lap swimming pool, a spa, a Multi-Activity Court (MAC) Gym, our Arena lower and upper courts, five Multi-Purpose Rooms (MPR), tennis, racquetball and squash courts, an indoor track, a classroom kitchen, conference and training rooms, Glen Mor fields, the Blaine Sports Complex, and our amazing Challenge Course.

column1: Youth Programs
column2: Youth Programs provide a healthy and safe lifestyle using positive experiences, sports, activities, games and educational instruction. Our programming instructs and shapes essential skills including teamwork, leadership, adaptability, flexibility, conflict resolution, brainstorming, creativity, social skills, attention-span, resilience, confidence and many more.

column1: SRC North
column2: Reservation Fees Room rental rates are waived for registered student organizations, however, other fees may apply. Campus departments and off campus groups are responsible for facility rental and other applicable charges.

column1: Outdoor Excursions
column2: Learn skills, meet friends, reduce stress, promote inclusion and sustainability, and feed your inner desire to explore through our outdoor community.

column1: FitWell
column2: */ /*-->*/ FitWell is a SRC fitness program that fosters a healthy lifestyle and lifelong wellness. Access group fitness classes and choose from more than 100 cardio machines featuring TVs and iPod/iCloud syncing. Visit the UCR Student Recreation Center and challenge yourself in any of our free group fitness class and learn from our certified personal trainers!

column1: Cooking Well
column2: Participants of all skill levels are welcome to the SRC cooking demonstrations, located in the Classroom Kitchen. Our kitchen is fully equipped with the tools necessary for our chef to improve your personal wellness through any of our healthy cooking classes. With the help of Chef Val, you will pick up valuable cooking techniques. So join us for our next event, because We're Cooking Well and eating better!

column1: Programs
column2: Recreation offers outdoor trips, SCUBA certifications, cooking demos, team sports, fitness classes, personal training, chair massages, dance, martial arts, swim lessons and workouts, youth summer camps, rock climbing, and life skills workshops. Our programs, services and events at UC Riverside Recreation is available to all Highlanders.

column1: Activity Classes
column2: Practice judo throws, salsa moves, and karate kicks in our fun recreation activity classes. Learn from expert instructors in classes suitable for all levels. Don’t forget, you can register in person at the SRC front counter or online.

column1: Competitive Sports
column2: Whether you are a seasoned athlete or a newcomer to competitive sports, there is a spot for you! We offer traditional team sports through Intramural Sports such as soccer, flag football, volleyball, basketball and softball; but also events such as tennis, badminton and beach volleyball. With Sport Clubs, you will get the opportunity to travel and compete against other schools. Whether you’re a star athlete searching for competition, or a newcomer in search of a good time, come sign up for a team and get in the game!

column1: Aquatics
column2: The SRC has a 237,000 gallon pool and a 20-person spa available for your aquatic adventures. The pool contains a lap swim area, recreational swim area, a vortex/current channel, a sand volleyball court, and a large deck with lounge furniture. It is available for lap swimming, recreational swimming, programming and rentals.

column1: LOCKERS/LOST and FOUND
column2: Note: The Recreation department is not responsible for items left overnight. Lockers are for day use only and overnight locks will be cut and discarded. Contents from overnight lockers will be placed in lost and found.

column1: Awards
column2: */ /*-->*/ 2022 C&I Rooftop Project of the Year - Read more details here. 2017 NIRSA – 2017 Outstanding Sports Facility -

column1: Rec Governing Board
column2: The Recreation Facilities Governing Board is an advisory board to the Chancellor and is comprised of undergraduate and graduate students. The board is charged with oversight of operational policies and approval of the annual budget and facility usage fees. Other responsibilities include representing student concerns, issues and ideas to the Recreation Department administration, and to serve as a liaison to ASUCR and GSA on matters relevant to campus recreation.

column1: Memberships
column2: If you’re a UCR student, you’re already a member! The cost of your gym membership is included in your UCR tuition, which dates back to two student referendums passed in 1990 (currently adjusted to $20 per quarter) and in 2010 ($149 per quarter). We are conveniently located on campus and offer a wide array of amenities and services. For further information, please contact Andrea Wood at andrea.wood@ucr.edu.

column1: Hours
column2: The UC Riverside Recreation department manages the hours and operation of the UCR Student Recreation Center. Please see the UCR holidays/campus closures for planned campus closures. The Recreation department strives to offer UCR students the best physical and active lifestyle we can, check our hours during some of our campus closures for a modified schedule.

column1: History
column2: Recreation within the UC Riverside campus emerged in the 1970’s when Butch Mayo, the UCR recreation intramural director, introduced the Intramural Sports

column1: Personal Training
column2: Reach your fitness goals faster. Our certified personal trainers can design an inspiring personalized fitness program just for you. Whether your goal is weight loss, stress reduction, increased strength or overall wellness – our trainers can help. Benefit from their motivational power and expert advice on exercise, nutrition, flexibility, strength training and more.

column1: FitWell Equipment Info
column2: Your training options are endless at the UC Riverside Student Rec Center! Strengthen every muscle group in our 21,000-square-foot, two-story weight room. Choose from more than 100 cardio machines featuring TVs and iPod/iCloud syncing. Multiple machines and ample equipment means you never wait to lift, climb or run.

column1: Custom Excursions
column2: Take your pick from either California or Arizona hotspots, and leave the rest to us. Each excursion is customized to suit your group’s level and interest. We'll plan, design, provide transportation, guided instruction and most equipment items for your group of 8-10 people. Pricing is based on destination and activities. Most trips accommodate ages 17+, but we can also create youth excursions for ages 13-17.

column1: SRC Child Care
column2: Located in the Student Recreation Center North Conference Room in between the front counter and the racquet ball courts. We offer a wide variety of educational games, activities and services designed to keep your child engaged and happy whilst you exercise and take part in SRC programs. Our talented staff have passed an extensive background check, are CPR/First-Aid certified and are trained extensively to provide a safe, welcoming and nurturing environment for your children.

column1: Visitors
column2: As a member of America’s most prestigious public university system, UC Riverside is one of the most dynamic campuses in the nation. We invite you to explore everything we have to offer — in person or online. Start your journey with UCR: View our campus map, explore our degree programs, or schedule your campus visit today.

column1: Camp Highlander
column2: The award-winning year-round Camp Highlander is a camp experience like no other. Camp Highlander offers indoor and outdoor traditional camp activities, leadership, STEM and sports which focus on essential skill development, learning and fun. At Camp Highlander we celebrate play and fun learning. We provide a broad academic focus combining engaging activities with STEM elements including Astronomy, Neuroscience and Earth Sciences. Through our collaboration with NASA and its GLOBE program we strive to support our youth on a journey to becoming citizen scientists.

column1: Scuba & Certifications
column2: Earn nationally recognized certifications through the UCR Recreation Outdoor Excursions program. Our trainings are open to everyone, conveniently located at the SRC for registration, and considerably more affordable than anywhere else in Southern California! Contact us at oe@ucr.edu, (951) 827-7040 for more information.

column1: Group Fitness Class Schedule
column2: From yoga and BOSU, to cycling and Zumba - our fitness classes are the perfect way to get fit, make friends and shake it up. Group fitness classes are included in your SRC membership (with exception to clinics) and there is no additional cost to participate. Rec It at the SRC today! NOTE: We are open to all UCR students, as well as faculty and staff SRC Members. Registration is required for all classes. Please see the schedule for more information.

column1: Outdoor Events
column2: Join us on an outdoor adventure as we challenge ourselves, learn new skills, strengthen relationships, promote diversity and sustainability, and feed our inner desire to explore! OE offers fun-filled road trips to some of the most beautiful places in the western US! For water trips, you must be able to swim. Swim lessons are available at the SRC Pool. Sign up for a trip at the OE Shop today and return with stories to share, memories to relive, photos to exchange, and friends that will last a lifetime.

column1: Help
column2: Common Questions We’ve developed the information below to assist applicants with the most common questions regarding the UCR JOBS application system. Please review the information carefully. Para ver la traduccion de estas preguntas en español, por favor haga clic aquí. Do I need to set up a new account if I already had a previous account on the old UCR JOBS site: hr.ucr.edu/jobs? Yes.  A new account will need to be created in order to apply for current positions on the new UCR JOBS website.

column1: Health and Safety
column2: UC Riverside cares about its students’ and employees’ health and wellbeing. That’s why our Healthy Campus initiative was formed in 2016 — to help our students, faculty, and staff achieve greater school and work-life balance. Learn more about the group and how it’s making UCR a healthier place to live and learn.

column1: How to Apply
column2: UCR strives to accommodate applicants with disabilities. In the event that your disability prevents you from completing the online application process, please contact us so that we can provide options to assist you in completing the application process. Please contact disabilitymanagement@ucr.edu or (951) 827-2561 for assistance.

column1: A-Z Listing
column2: A-Z alphabetical listing of all department websites and resources at the University of California, Riverside.

column1: Overview
column2: Learn from anywhere, anytime. Learn about our online programs, and the resources available to help you facilitate your academic success.

column1: University Pathways
column2: Prepare to make a successful application to your desired undergraduate or graduate degree program at UCR with our University Pathways programs. Combine advanced English instruction and test preparation with academic skills training, and UCR credit classes.

column1: UCR Profiles - Search & Browse
column2: Search & Browse UCR Faculty & Staff

column1: Textbooks
column2: At UCR University Extension, we give you the option to shop competitively for your classroom textbooks. See our helpful tips for ensuring you get the right one.

column1: Certificates and Credentials
column2: Find your unique path to success by developing your skills with a certificate or credential from UCR University Extension.

column1: Library Privileges
column2: As a UCR University Extension student, you may obtain a UCR Library card from the Rivera or Orbach Science Library Circulation Desk or use a UCR Card for library services.

column1: UCP
column2: Gain access to courses in over 80 undergraduate majors, and 50 graduate programs. UCP students can earn one or more certificates, depending on the length of stay and number of units taken.

column1: Drowning Prevention Resources
column2: Drowning is a leading cause of injury-related deaths (especially among children under the age of five). Each year, near-drowning incidents result in life-long disabilities. The University of California, Riverside has put together a list of resources to help prevent the cause of drowning accidents.

column1: How to Earn a Certificate
column2: Earn your professional certificate through UCR University Extension to put you on a successful trajectory.

column1: Career Resources
column2: Not sure what career suits you best? Take an aptitude test or learn how to write a stellar cover letter and resume to solidify the perfect job.

column1: Healthcare and Wellness
column2: Leverage your medical and healthcare experience to carve out an exciting new career pathway with a certificate that intersects with law, forensics, or a focused population.

column1: UCR Jobs Ayuda
column2: Preguntas Frecuentes Hemos desarrollado la siguiente información para ayudar a los interesados con las preguntas más comunes sobre el sistema de solicitud de empleos de UCR. Lea cuidadosamente la información. ¿Necesito crear una cuenta nueva si ya tenía una cuenta en la antigua página web de UCR EMPLEO: hr.ucr.edu /jobs? Sí. Una cuenta nueva tendrá que ser creada para solicitar su ingreso a puestos desplegados en la nueva página web de empleos de UCR.

column1: Lets Login
column2: Ready to get started? Find all the steps you need to login to your virtual classroom and get started on your educational journey.

column1: Concurrent Enrollment
column2: Fall 2021 Concurrent Enrollment is planned to operate using a modified approval process given the mandated campus closure. Prospective students should monitor this page for additional updates.

column1: Discontinued Classes
column2: At times it is necessary to cancel, move, or postpone a course. Find out all the information you need should this happen to you.

column1: Online Resources and Tutorials
column2: Find the resources you need to help you stay on track with your education.

column1: Take a Seat in our Virtual Classroom
column2: We now provide more than 400 online classes a year to nearly 6000 students in a variety of academic disciplines. Good online teaching involves designing an engaging learning experience using a variety of instructional tools and media, and then developing a strong online presence through interactions with students.

column1: Business
column2: If you're seeking upward mobility in your career or a wide-open door to future success, our business programs will equip you with the knowledge and skills to thrive and become the business professional you've always envisioned.

column1: International Experience Home Page
column2: Achieve your goals one step at a time with the University of California, an exceptional experience, and quality academic programs.

column1: International Programs
column2: Choose the program that is right for you. From learning English, professional certificates, or degree pathway programs, we have everything you need to advance your goals.

column1: Using Special Collections & University Archives Materials
column2: Use Materials in the Reading Room Our materials are shelved in closed stacks and do not circulate outside the Special Collections Reading Room on the 4th floor of the Tomás Rivera Library. All researchers need to register in the Special Collections Request System. While walk-ins are welcome, researchers are advised to request materials ahead of time to avoid delays.

column1: Past Workshops & Events
column2: The Special Collections & University Archives department actively pursues opportunities to engage with local UCR, as well as broader, communities. These activities include collaborating with UCR professors in their classes, conducting workshops, and hosting other types of events. Some of the workshops and events that our staff have conducted or participated in are included here. Click the below links to view the recordings of the events.

column1: SCUA Unprocessed Collections Policy
column2: Unprocessed Manuscript and Water Resources collections are generally open for research use, provided they are not restricted. However, the Special Collections and Archives staff may need to delay access for a reasonable period of time to survey the records for confidential information and/or personally identifiable information. Therefore all requests for unprocessed materials must be made at least 72 hours in advance of visiting the archives. Please contact specialcollections@ucr.edu for more information or to request items from unprocessed collections.

column1: UC Riverside Library
column2: The UCR Library serves as an information commons and intellectual center for the campus and is the focal point for research and study at UCR.

column1: Research Guides
column2: The following research guides were created by our Librarians and Archivists in order to provide more ready access to the collections and facilitate research with Special Collections and University Archives materials. These guides colocate resources in Special Collections and University Archives according to their subject matter. These are intended to provide an overview on their subjects and help navigate the collections.

column1: Speaking Across Time: Indigenous Languages of the Americas

column1: University Archives
column2: University Archives is the designated repository for records, documents, publications and other material pertaining to the University of California, Riverside.

column1: Water Resources Collections and Archives
column2: The Water Resources Collections & Archives (WRCA) acquires, preserves, and provides access to materials that document water-related issues throughout the United States and beyond, with a particular emphasis on issues affecting the state of California.

column1: About
column2: About the Special Collections & University Archives Department

column1: Collections
column2: Collecting Areas The Special Collections & University Archives department at UC Riverside contains a large number of collections across a wide range of interests. Our holdings amount to over 750 archival collections totaling over 8,000 linear feet of materials that includes documents, correspondence, diaries/journals, maps, A/V recordings, and more.
