column2: Participants are introduced to basic social graces, with the goals of providing a framework for comfortable and respectful interaction with others. Provides skills and self-confidence for success in a variety of social and employment situations. Among a wide variety of topics are business lunches, food and wine, restaurant dining, basic do's and don'ts, success dressing, invitations, breaking engagements, dinner parties, and etiquette for particular foods.

column1: Sustainability and the Built Environment Course
column2: This course examines the fundamentals of sustainable design and construction concepts and practices in context with Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED®) as the basis for instruction. This course emphasizes the principles, practices and applications of integrated project delivery methodologies, sustainable construction applications and current industry innovations in sustainability as it relates to the built environment.

column1: Building High Performance Teams Course
column2: Explores the principles and dynamics of high performance work teams.  Topics include strategies for team development -- forming, storming and norming, motivating others to serve as a team, the inner workings of the team -- strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats (SWOT), managing conflicts, team communication, decision making, soliciting feedback and instilling the mission, vision and values of the team.

column1: Communicating Effectively Course
column2: Effective communication skills are essential in the exchange of information and ideas, both verbal and non-verbal, within our daily lives and in our work environment. Effective workplace communication is important to companies because it allows them to be productive, and operate efficiently and effectively. Understanding each of the three parts of communication, and how each part impacts the final message, is critical to effective communications.

column1: Compensation Administration Course
column2: A survey of compensation programs as applied to the various segments, functions and levels of the work force, including legal provisions. Topics include job evaluation and analysis techniques; relating job performance to compensation; wages and incentive plans; utilization of wage and salary surveys; highlighting and communicating contributions to health care, retirement and other benefits within compensation plans; evaluating outsourced contractor compensation levels and agreements; training and development and other non-financial compensation issues.

column1: Developing Your Analytical Skills Course
column2: Developing your analytical skills is a methodical step-by-step approach to breaking down complex problems or processes.  The overall process of defining the problem; formulating the hypothesis; collecting the facts; and conducting the analysis that finally leads to developing the solution is the strategy to analytical thinking.  Since thinking analytically is crucial to optimizing job performance, participants will learn the methods and strategies in solving problems in their work environments.

column1: Discovering You Course
column2: Assess and reflect on how you can be the best version of yourself. Examine the ways you can improve self-awareness in intrapersonal and interpersonal intelligence using a variety of self-assessment exercises. Learn how to make the most of your potential to advance your career, increase employee engagement, achieve better performance outcomes, enhance professional growth, and explore other benefits that come from working with a win-win perspective.

column1: Effective Performance Management Course
column2: This course focuses on creating and managing a high performance workforce, which is the critical component of organizational success. You will examine the current thinking and the impacts on human performance including the aging workforce, globalization, the home-based workforce, technology and management of knowledge. You will address ways to achieve performance goals by monitoring and measuring the effectiveness of performance for both individuals and the organization. Measurement tools and techniques will be explored, as well as how to design and deliver performance recognition and rewards. The design and implementation of training programs for adult learners will also be covered and will include job skills, career development, leadership development and team building skills. You will learn how to create an effective and efficient performance support system to achieve optimal organizational and individual performance.

column1: Effective Public Speaking Course
column2: Learn tips to become a confident and effective public speaker. Whether you want to expand your public speaking skills, or just get better at presenting in front of people, these tips can help you meet your target goals. Public speaking can be intimidating for many individuals; however, like many skills, it can be perfected with time and practice.

column1: Effective Resumes & Career Preparation Course
column2: This course is designed to prepare participants for career development opportunities. Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to create an updated and competed resume that represents their skills, experience, and education background. Students will also learn how to write an effective cover letter, and prepare for a capstone presentation.

column1: Emotional Intelligence in the Workplace Course
column2: This course provides an in-depth understanding of the five fundamental pillars of emotional intelligence, which include self-awareness, self-management, self-motivation, social awareness, and relationship management. The course incorporates real-life case studies to illustrate the dynamic role and importance of emotional intelligence. A talent assessment is included to help participants identify their aptitude, preferred learning style, core competencies, and values. A preferred whole-brain thinking assessment, along with a listening and team assessment, is also included. This course is a valuable resource for those considering improving their relationships with people, achieving higher productivity, performance, and profit.

column1: Emotional Intelligence Workshop Course
column2: Emotional intelligence is the capacity of being aware of and controlling one’s emotions to handle interpersonal relationships in an empathetic manner. Once we become aware of ourselves, we become more conscientious of our emotions and how they impact our relationships with others. Understanding your emotional intelligence will allow you to enhance your social awareness, self-management, self-awareness, and relationship management styles. By understanding the four domains of emotional intelligence, we can practice and improve our relationships.

column1: Employee Benefit Administration Course
column2: Analysis of employee benefit planning, policy formulation, organization and implementation in relation to the overall personnel program. Concepts covered include the advantages and disadvantages of fixed and flexible benefit packages, cost containment and the influence of employee attitudes concerning benefit planning. Emphasizes the need for employee-employer communications relative to benefits and forecasts future development trends in employee benefits.

column1: Employee Recruitment, Selection and Retention Course
column2: Examination of the recruitment and staffing process, including preparing a job analysis and description, recruiting, interviewing and selecting candidates, conducting tests and background checks, selecting and evaluating references, constructing the "offer," and preparing documentation for new hires. Participants explore the legal aspects of recruitment and selection, reviewing applicant pools, equal opportunity considerations and other legal requirements to minimize legal challenges to the search process. Global issues related to retention are also covered, including analyzing the importance of "fit," ensuring applicants are effectively trained and supported, and how to minimize turnover within the organization.

column1: Employee Training and Development Course
column2: The course provides an in-depth investigation of employee training and development as a tool to achieve critical organizational tactical and strategic plans. The focus will be on the design of training programs and the simultaneous measurement of training results. Students will be introduced to modern learning theories and resources, and will learn how to design, plan and organize training programs for employees. The course will also cover how to measure the effectiveness of training programs through measurement and evaluation.

column1: Global Leadership and Intercultural Competence Course
column2: Business today is global – your continued success requires a new set of skills! In our current, competitive economy, numerous managers already are, or will become, global managers. Although managers may work in their home countries, they are significantly influenced by global events and frequently have to manage multicultural workforces. In this course, we will focus on exploring the challenges and opportunities facing global managers, and how to lead and succeed in a multicultural business world. We will examine cultural, organizational, and managerial environments and strategies to develop a variety of necessary skills in areas of communication, leadership, negotiation, and global team management. We will investigate the evolving role of cultural diversity in the workplace, and best practices in applying cultural understanding among its leaders and non-leaders. Measurable, data-driven outcomes are key indicators of success in today’s multicultural and globalized workforce. How employees interact with their leaders, colleagues, and customers are significant factors in their pursuit of successful career development. We will discuss the various tools leaders use to establish metrics in intercultural competence.

column1: Labor and Employee Relations Course
column2: Participants survey the major aspects of labor-employee relations in union and non-union environments. Topics include: constructive employee discipline and employee relations issues; current laws and compliance, including the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA), sexual harassment, discrimination, Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), and wrongful discharge. Time is also given to discuss strategies to help maintain proactive communication with employees and current issues in employee relations.

column1: Human Resources Management Course
column2: A comprehensive overview of the mission, purpose and structure of human operations within an industrial, service or public organization. Concepts covered include the function of human resources as it relates to organizational mission; the fundamentals of employee selection, performance appraisal, discipline and compensation; management and organizational structure; supervision; communications; legal issues; training and staff development; relations with unions; strategic planning; and current trends in human resources management. This course is appropriate for human resource professionals, managers, supervisors and individuals interested in organizational leadership and development.

column1: Leadership Principles and Practices: Supervision and Teambuilding Course
column2: Participants examine skills and strategies to more effectively supervise workers, build and utilize teams and improve leadership qualities.  Case studies explore leading organization design systems and processes to enhance productivity and improve workflow.  Specific topics include:  time management, productivity improvement strategies, cutting waste, eliminating duplication of effort, mistake-proofing and communication skills.  Emphasis is placed on the use of cross-functional teams, delegation tactics and the skills supervisors commonly use to improve flexibility, reliability, quality, customer service and profitability.

column1: Essence of Business Communications Course
column2: This course introduces forms of communication most typically used in business.  The emphasis is on how to make communications successful through clarifying the audience and the intended message and then developing persuasive and logical communications.  The course includes communicating in print, electronically and in personal presentations. Students receive practical advice and feedback.

column1: Empowering Leaders Course
column2: Develop yourself as a leader and bring positive change to your environment. Leadership skills can be applied to any situation, and are highly sought after. Learn to encourage an environment of exploration and innovation and create optimal performance outcomes.

column1: Managing High Performance Teams Course
column2: This course focuses on the supervisor and the skills needed to be successful at developing people, the relevance of emotional intelligence, and creating effective high-performance teams to meet organizational goals.

column1: Managing Through Workplace Inclusion Course
column2: A healthy work environment is critical to the success of an organization. Employees who enjoy their job have better attendance, and are more productive in their job functions. This course examines the strategies and techniques supervisors can use to ensure organizational values, goals, and objectives are met--even in the presence of organizational discord or management conflict. The course will explore the role of diversity in the workplace, and how to create an environment in which men and women of different cultural, ethnic, religious, socioeconomic backgrounds, and disabilities can work together in a harmonious atmosphere.

column1: Motivating, Managing, and Developing Others Course
column2: This course introduces a variety of methodologies, techniques, and strategies available to business leaders and managers seeking to improve their staff's capabilities, engagement, innovation, and flexibility. The course examines the attitudes and attributes successful coaches and mentors use to empower others. The focus is on self-examination, discussion and reflection; in-class research and practical role-plays; and exploration of the magnitude of what it means to focus on others in order to achieve high performance and effectiveness in the workplace. Topics include the impact of emotional intelligence, the appropriate application of different management styles, identifying how to get the most out of individuals and to motivate employees, and how to recognize and manage difficult employees. Participants are introduced to their various roles as a leader, counselor, listener, facilitator, and director. Students will learn how to develop action plans for staff development and training.

column1: Managing Through Workplace Inclusion Course
column2: Examines the strategies and techniques supervisors can utilize to ensure that organizational values, goals, and objectives are met--even in the presence of organizational discord or management conflict. Topics include work-related scenarios that often result in conflict; identifying, understanding, and managing differences between self and others; developing and maintaining effective working relationships; accepting and providing feedback; problem-solving techniques; mediating and when to elicit help; creating an environment of inclusion; 360° accountability; supporting diversity and inclusion; eliminating disparity gaps; and meeting organizational goals. The course also explores the role of diversity in the workplace, and how to create an environment in which men and women of different cultural, ethnic, religious, and socioeconomic backgrounds and disabilities can work together agreeably.

column1: Navigating Crucial Conversations Course
column2: This course provides students with an examination of communication when the stakes are high. When a crucial conversation fails, consequences can be severe; learning how to open the dialogue creates shared meaning. Crucial Conversations discusses how students can learn to handle disagreements and high stake conversations in any situation, including careers, relationships, and in their communities. Through lectures, team-based exercises, and demonstrations, students turn skills learned into behaviors that improve decision making, commitment to action, productivity and relationships. Students also gain exposure to an understanding of the power of dialogue through ideas, theories, feelings, and mind-mapping.

column1: Moving Through Change Course
column2: Change significantly impacts an overall organizational culture, and can have a huge effect on employees. This course discusses the various strategies necessary to be a successful mentor and change management leader. Participants will develop a personal change management action plan which will enhance mentoring and leadership skills. We will examine how to use change as a motivating factor, how to move beyond resistance, and how to create buy-in from your superiors, and from those whom you supervise.

column1: Moving Through Change:  What's In It For Me? Course
column2: Discussion of the strategies and techniques to be a successful leader, guiding others through change management. Topics include: influencing the change process, pushing past resistance, identifying key stakeholders in the change process, getting buy-in from those you supervise, implementation process in change management, using change for reorganization and continuous process improvement, and seeing the end result.  Students will also develop a personal action plan for change management.

column1: Organizational Leadership Course
column2: We will explore common mistakes made in today’s organizational leadership roles. Participants will investigate leadership styles, and decision-making processes relevant in today’s global marketplace. Effective leaders and leadership styles cannot be put into the same box because there are many different dimensions of leadership. Participants will analyze the various leadership styles necessary to function in today’s culturally diverse workplaces. They will learn how to transition their organization and teams, at each level, toward collaboration and empowerment to further the success of their organizations.

column1: Quality Customer Service Course
column2: Participants examine best practices in customer service and how organizations use customer service to expand their customer base. Topics include initiating and sustaining quality improvement in customer relations, measuring customer satisfaction, developing and using performance indicators, differentiating customer service approaches, certification options, and the role of technology, workforce management and outsourcing in customer service.

column1: New School of Medicine building begins construction
column2: UC Riverside began construction Friday, Oct. 22 of a new School of Medicine building that will allow for growing class sizes and increasing the number of physicians trained in the underserved Inland Southern California. Campus and community leaders celebrated the start of the project at a groundbreaking ceremony at the project site south of the existing School of Medicine Education on the east side of campus.
